It removes an obstacle to the complementary workings of the youth social security and educational allowance systems and provides an incentive to young people to continue study.

Third, the benefit entitlement of a married person whose spouse is on AUSTUDY is to be limited to half the normal combined married rate and the spouse's AUSTUDY allowance will be disregarded under the benefit income test. This would give the same entitlement to a couple consisting of one beneficiary and one AUSTUDY recipient as currently applies to couples where both are receiving benefit or both are receiving AUSTUDY. The effect of the income test on these couples would be rationalised since the AUSTUDY allowance would no longer monopolise the available income concessions, so work incentives would be restored.

Mr President, the Social Security Act provides for periods for the non-payment of unemployment benefit where a person is unemployed because of some voluntary act, misconduct as an employee, refusal to accept a job offer or failure to make reasonable attempts to find work. When someone fails one of these tests, the non-payment period is 2 weeks in the first instance, 4 weeks for a second, then 6 weeks, 8 weeks and so on up to a maximum of 12 weeks.

In this Bill, additional criteria for cessation of payment or for periods of non-payment of unemployment benefit are applicable. Where a person refuses to comply with a request to attend a CES office, benefit will cease to be payable. If a person fails either to attend a departmental interview or to respond to departmental correspondence such as a review form or questionnaire, a period of non payment will apply. Furthermore, the existing non-payment periods applicable in such situations are to be increased and made more effective as an incentive to remain in or find new employment. A second incident will now draw a 6 week non-payment period and each successive incident an extra 6 weeks, with no maximum period prescribed.

The Social Security Act also provides that a person who reduces his or her employment prospects by moving to a new place of residence without a sufficient reason for the move incurs a twelve week postponement period of payment of benefit. It is a sufficient reason, however, if the person moves to live with a family member who is already resident in that new place of residence or near a family member who is already resident in the new place.

This Bill provides that it is also a sufficient reason, and so a person will not have payment of his or her benefit postponed, if the move is necessary for the purpose of healing or alleviating a physical disease or illness suffered by the person or a family member.

Both income and assets tests apply to beneficiaries aged 25 years or more. At present, there are some concessions in these tests for younger clients. The assets test is applied to only those beneficiaries aged 25 or older and a parental income test in addition to the usual income test is applied to JSA recipients who are not independent from their parents' financial and social support.

In the interests of improving equity between beneficiaries in similar economic circumstances but different ages this Bill will extend the assets test to all beneficiaries younger than 25 and to those JSA recipients who meet parental independence criteria and who, therefore, are judged to be self-supporting. Furthermore, job search allowees still dependent on their parents will now be subject to a parental assets test, a real measure, as is the family allowance supplement assets test, of the family's capacity to support itself.

People who leave full-time education and register for unemployment benefit or JSA have to serve a 6 or 13 week benefit deferment period depending on their circumstances. This is to avoid making the income support system an easily accessible alternative to pursuing further studies. On the other hand, there is only a one week deferment period for payment of sickness benefit to school leavers. This is anomalous given that sickness benefit is really for people who lose earnings through being temporarily unfit for work.

Accordingly, people who leave education and claim sickness benefit will now have to serve the same deferment period as do unemployment benefit claimants. People who would suffer severe financial hardship through this initiative may claim special benefit.

It is a requirement of the Act that applicants for sole parent and class B widow's pensions pursue their entitlements to child and spousal maintenance before having access to social security payments. This concept, which puts the onus on former partners and non-custodial parents to live up to their financial responsibilities to their children, is to be adapted and extended by this Bill to recipients of all other pensions and benefits. No additional pension or benefit and no mother's/guardian's allowance will be paid for a dependent child where the parent has not fulfilled the maintenance action requirement.

To do this, the parent must take reasonable action to obtain child maintenance if entitled to make such a claim and if the Secretary thinks it reasonable to pursue the claim. As is the case with sole parent pensioners, this requirement may be waived in circumstances which might cause unusual difficulty or distress, such as where there might be violence or another health or safety threat to the client or child from the liable parent, where rape or incest is involved, or where the absent parent's whereabouts or identity is not known.

This Bill also corrects problems associated with the application of recent initiatives which provided for increases in the rates payable to sole parents with children in receipt of JSA and for the removal of additional sole parent entitlements to pensioners with children aged 18 to 24 years.

A provision to withhold pension or benefit from people who have not pursued their entitlement to compensation will be introduced. This will make sure that insurers meet their proper responsibilities and that the social security system is not required to support people who could receive the same or more substantial support from compensation payable to them by an insurer or an individual.
Mr President, this Bill makes an important amendment to the treatment of income for a deserving group of people claiming or receiving social security pensions and benefits.
Payments made by the Australian Government as compensation for Nazi persecution during World War II will no longer be treated as income under the Social Security Act.

Austria makes these payments to people because of the persecution they have suffered, including loss of health, property, education and official status. The Government sees it as inappropriate to continue to regard these special payments as income.

This amendment, which takes effect from the date of the Government's announcement on 4 December 1989, is a logical extension of the earlier decision to disregard as income restitution payments for Nazi persecution made by the Federal Republic of Germany.

On 10 February 1990, Spain became an important partner in the network of social security agreements between Australia and other countries. This Bill provides for implementation of the agreement with Spain.

There is also a refinement to the provisions relating to the overseas payment (or ``portability'') of Australian pensions. As from 1 July 1990 wife's pension and class B widow's pension will be paid overseas for a maximum of only 12 months. For those pensioners already overseas at that date, payments will stop 12 months later, at the end of June 1991.

Wife's pension is paid with little requirement for residential contact with Australia. Sole parent pensioners, who are in a comparable position to class B widows, already have a 12 month restriction on the overseas payment of their pensions. The Government believes that Australian taxpayers should not have to provide income support to non-residents in these circumstances and this Bill corrects the perceived anomaly.

The Social Security Act currently provides for the back payment of family allowances and family allowance supplement to the date of birth of the child where a claim form is lodged within 4 weeks of the birth. In the case of multiple births involving 3 or more children, the 4 week period may not give parents enough time to lodge claims. This Bill recognises the difficulties that these parents face and will allow them up to 13 weeks in which to lodge a claim for family allowance and family allowance supplement. Where a claim is lodged within this period arrears will be paid from the date of the multiple births.

Mr President, the whole country was shocked at news of the Newcastle earthquake at Christmas time last year. Part of the Government's immediate response was to make sure that emergency income support was immediately available to people who needed to claim benefit as a result of the earthquake. This was done by waiving the usual benefit waiting period and by doubling the rate of the first week's payment to meet the urgent need of the Newcastle people.

This Bill formalises the arrangements that were announced on that sad occasion. It also provides, should the unhappy need arise, for similar arrangements to be made in future where the Minister determines that a major disaster has occurred. This could include natural devastation such as fire, flood or earthquake or other disasters such as a chemical spillage or burst dam. This would facilitate an urgent response to urgent circumstances with a minimum of red tape.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
WOOL TAX (Nos. 1 TO 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1990
These Bills will amended the Wool Tax Acts (Nos. 1-5) 1964 to increase, effective from 1 July 1990, the maximum rate of wool tax imposed by each Act from 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

An operational rate of wool tax lower than or equal to the maximum rate may be set by regulation. The recommendations of the Wool Council of Australia are taken into account in setting the actual limit.
At present the operational rate applying for each Act is 8 per cent although the maximum rate is set at 10 per cent.
The five Wool Tax Amendment Bills are similar in their text and each amends an Act which deals with a different method of selling shorn wool.
The need for five separate Acts arises from a constitutional requirement that laws imposing taxes should deal with one subject of taxation only.

The minimum rate of wool tax may be imposed under each Act remains unchanged at 5.25 per cent. This is equal to the sum of the minimum rates for market support, promotion and research and development as specified in the Wool Marketing Act 1987.

The market situation for wool has changed significantly since the days of the high prices which peaked at more than 1250 cents per kilogram in early 1988. During late 1988 and early 1989 prices fell by 30 per cent and reached 893 cents per kilogram clean at the end of the 1988-89 season. The Australian Wool Corporation stocks increased from almost nothing at the start of the season to 188,000 bales by the end of the season.
Since the commencement of this season in July 1989, we have seen prices fall to close to the minimum reserve price of 870 cents per kilogram.
Australian Wool Corporation stocks have risen rapidly as the reserve price scheme purchased wool to support the floor price.

Currently Australian Wool Corporation stocks amount to around 2.5 million bales. In the course of purchasing that stock the Corporation has used the $1.8 billion reserve of woolgrowers' funds in the Market Support Fund and borrowed additional funds. These borrowings are expected to exceed $1 billion by the end of this season.

The cause of the present problem is a combination of increased supply of wool, following good seasonal conditions and a build up in sheep numbers, and decreased demand for our wool. The fall in demand for our wool is largely due to the absence of China from the market and the wool processing industry's reaction to the high prices of two years ago. Uncertainty is developing about future purchases by the USSR and Eastern Europe.

There is little doubt that the wool industry is in for a difficult few years as it seeks to bring supply and demand for wool back into balance. While this balance is being achieved, Australian Wool Corporation stocks can be expected to grow, unless there is a rapid unexpected turnaround in the market.

Under the Wool Marketing Act, the wool industry, through the Wool Council of Australia and the Wool Corporation, is responsible for the management of the reserve price scheme. Wool growers provide the funds necessary to support the scheme.
Consistent with these responsibilities, a number of options and possible market scenarios have been examined for next season.

It is clear that if the Australian Wool Corporation continues a high level of purchases at auction, the Corporation will need to borrow additional funds. A substantial increase in the market support component of the wool tax will be required to adequately service those borrowings and the physical cost of holding stocks.

In setting the maximum wool tax rate at 20 per cent, the Government is of the view that this rate is consistent with an appropriate mix of policy measures designed to ensure the continued viability of the wool industry and the reserve price scheme itself.
Two things also need to be recognised.

First, the wool tax is not a Government tax in the generally accepted understanding of ``tax'', as funds raised by the wool tax are transferred to the wool industry and the Commonwealth does not benefit.

Secondly, provision is available for the market support component of the tax to be ultimately returned to the growers through revolvements of the Market Support Fund. The timing is determined by the Wool Council.

At its Conference later this month, the Wool Council will be making recommendations to the Government on the apportionment of the wool tax between market support, wool promotion and research and development.
The Bills involve no additional financial cost to the Government.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990
This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to various bounty Acts.

The Bill's major purpose is to implement certain initiatives arising from the Australia/New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement (`the Anzcerta Agreement'). The 1988 review of that agreement resulted in an `agreed minute on industry assistance', signed on 21 June 1988, under which Australia and New Zealand agreed that, from 1 July 1990, neither country would pay production bounties or like measures on goods which are exported to the other country.

In the last year, as principal bounty Bills or bounty amendment Bills have been presented to the Parliament, a provision to preclude the bounty being paid on bountiable goods exported to New Zealand after 1 July, 1990 has been inserted, to give effect to Australia's treaty commitment. In 1989, the Bounty (Ships) Act, and the Bounty (Photographic Film) Act both contained such provisions, in sections 9 and 8 respectively.
This Bill proposes to amend four current bounty acts.
(The Bounty (Books) Act 1986)
(The Bounty (Computers) Act 1984)
(The Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act 1985), and
(The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981)
To similarly provide that from 1 July 1990, bounty is not payable in respect of goods which are for export to New Zealand.
The desired prohibition on payment of bounty will not however, extend to goods exported through New Zealand to other destinations.

The other amendments in this Bill are of a minor technical nature and are explained in greater detail in the clause notes to schedule 1 of the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. The opportunity has also been taken to repeal ten superseded bounty Acts and three superseded subsidy Acts, as the relevant bounty or subsidy periods have expired, the time within which to make a claim has elapsed, and there is no outstanding prosecution or recovery action under any of them. The Acts proposed for repeal are in schedule 2 of the explanatory memorandum.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to participate in the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1989-90, I have to say that it gives me no great joy to be standing on this side of the chamber again. Whilst I acknowledge that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has, in raw terms, won more seats than the coalition parties, it did so through no ability of its own, through no superior management of the economy and, sadly, not even because more people wanted it there. When one looks at the statistics, they make the opening remarks of the Governor-General at the opening of Parliament seem rather hollow and inappropriate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 24 March, the Australian people gave to the Labor Government an historic and decisive fourth mandate-a mandate to continue the urgent and sweeping task of national reform in the 1990s.

In fact, as we know, the Australian people did not directly give the ALP a mandate to government. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that, on a two-party preferred percentage based on the House of Representatives votes, the ALP failed to reach 50 per cent; in fact, with the votes of all the people who helped the ALP get into office, it got only 49.9 per cent of the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what percentage of the vote? It was 38 per cent.
—As Senator Michael Baume has said, the ALP got well less than that-it was lower than 40 per cent, if I remember correctly.
—It was 38 per cent.

—It was 38 per cent of the vote of the Australian people, and the Government got its historic fourth term. On this side of the chamber we, in the Opposition, got in excess of 50 per cent of the vote. Obviously the Government has not quite got the mandate that the Governor-General informed us of, but it has control of the treasury bench. While it is in that position it ought to remember that its mandate is not decisive; in fact, it is not even the Government's. Having had its numbers man persuade the Green movement to vote to give its second choice to Labor, it is yet to be seen whether it now ditches the Green movement. We will see whether the new Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) gives the Green movement all the promises that were given by Senator Richardson.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are many, including those in the Labor Party, who believe that the Party has already sacrificed too many of its principles to woo the Green vote, and that it is time to get back to the real issues. Senator Walsh is not alone in his criticism of his own political party, the Labor Party. He questions whether the Government has the intestinal fortitude to take the tough decisions. In fact, he made some comments just recently about people's spines not being quite as strong as they should be. He ought to know. Senator Walsh has been a member of the inner Cabinet for seven years. So if he thinks his former ministerial colleagues are weak, he is more than likely correct. I note that former Minister Barry Cohen has been similarly critical of his Party's performance. I suggest that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will find that he can no longer silence his back bench with promises. The Government realises that there is no point being in government if it cannot get its wish list onto the agenda.

The Governor-General's Speech was very typical of this Government. It had many words, but there was little of real substance. If the Speech were intended to give us all a warm feeling in our bellies with talk of the lucky country and the clever country, it fell pathetically short of its objective. Indeed, the contents of the Speech were an insult to any thinking Australian. One needs only to compare the rhetoric of that day with the reality of the appropriations-the balance sheet-to see just how hollow it is.

The Government talks of the strong growth in the economy, the surge in business investment and employment. It promises to continue the broad-based structural reform. I ask: Where is this strong growth? Where is this reform? The reality is that Labor's economic policies to date have failed. They have failed the Labor Party economic strategists, and they have failed the people of Australia. What we have today is an Australia not mildly out of kilter with the rest of the world, but woefully off course. While the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talks about the need to reduce inflation further, the truth is that we really need to start to reduce inflation, not just talk about it. Something has to be done about it.

The consumer price index has been rising steadily since the March quarter of last year and there appears to be little relief in sight. The balance of payments, or the numbers, as our Treasurer is so fond of referring to them, have been predictably awful for months. Every month it becomes increasingly more difficult to find something different to say about them. For two years the Opposition parties have been saying that the economy must have a change of direction. In that time the Government has been trying to tell us all to be patient, that things will get better, and that they are just taking longer than was first thought. I think it is about time that this so-called world's best Treasurer started to take a little notice of what is really happening in the economy and out in the community and did something about it.

In 1983 the ALP policy assured us that several elements of Labor's economic strategy would lead to improvements in the balance of payments. That statement was abysmally out of kilter. The Treasurer, in the 1988 Budget Speech, said:
This year our balance of payments deficit will be halved from its peak of just three years ago.
Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
Dear, oh dear! In the 1989 Budget Speech, Treasurer Keating said:
Last year inflation was too high.
And the balance of payments did not fall as we expected, leading to higher interest rates.

I wonder what excuses we will hear this time. It is a tired charade being played for no-one's benefit. The agenda outlined for this fourth Labor Government contains no hope for the future and no new direction, just a prescription for more of the same. In fact, It could easily have been written in a vacuum; that is the extent of its relevance to Australia in the 1990s.

The Labor Party has made no acknowledgment of the difficulty confronting farmers forced into high debt levels because of the Government's inability and incompetence at managing interest rates. The present crisis in the wool industry is a direct result of Government policy that is inappropriate and misdirected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! They have stuffed the wool industry.

—I would not use those words, but the Government has caused immeasurable damage to the Australian farming community, especially the wool producers, with the interest rates impost. Our over-inflated dollar and our inflated interest rates are killing this country surer than any plague.

SPEECH.PARA: Today our wool industry is in crisis. What industry will it be tomorrow? Which industry will be next? When all the rural industries start to get hit to leg with higher interest rates, which are grinding them into the ground, what will produce the export income for Australia to give us the standard of living we all desire? By the turn of the century the number of viable farms in the rural sector will drop below 100,000. Farms are becoming non-viable at a faster rate than at any other time in Australia's history. That is occurring despite the fact that Australian farmers are recognised as among the most efficient in the world, despite the fact that technology in Australian agriculture is utilised faster than almost anywhere else, and despite the fact that we have sound management and favourable seasons.

What will happen if we go into a season of drought? We have just had horrific floods in the western areas of Queensland and New South Wales, which have caused untold damage. It will take those areas a great deal of time to get back on their feet. What will happen if we go now into a drought? Will Australia then ride on the sheep's back, on beef's back, on grain's back, on the back of primary industry generally?

It is difficult not only for the rural sector; business confidence also has been shot to pieces and investment has ground to a halt. We all know what is happening in the cities around Australia. But what do Government members do? They snipe at each other and talk about ministerial discipline. It is about time they applied some discipline to the management of the economy. Where is the discipline when our net foreign debt of $23.3 billion, or 13.8 per cent of gross domestic product in 1983, has blown out to $137 billion by June 1989. That is quite an achievement, is it not, Senator Baume?

TALK.START.PARA: —Even for them.

—Even for this Government that is a record. It is something this country cannot afford, but the people of Australia have been forced into it. This Government is to blame. What sort of understanding of the economy does this Government have when our Treasurer predicts falling interest rates and the reality is that in May 1990 we have interest rates of 19 per cent or 20 per cent.
—They always forecast that before an election.

—That is right. It does not matter whether one is a farmer or in business, or even a small person wanting to buy a motor car, interest rates affect everybody. They are making it very difficult to buy even a motor car. Of course, all that follows the constant predictions during the election campaign, as Senator Baume said, that interest rates would soon be on the way down. I would like to see interest rates falling soon as that will at least give back some incentive to the people in the community who pay interest. At the moment, all incentive for people to invest is being knocked out by high interest rates.
—They are going broke.

—They are going broke at a great rate. Senator Baume is quite right. The policy of sustained high interest rates alone has been enough to slow down housing sales and close shops. Just recently I was in a country town in the south of New South Wales and something like 100 shops were for sale. The only problem was that there was nobody there to buy the shops because nobody wanted to invest in a shop in a country town or city anywhere in Australia because of high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Australian population a second mortgage has definitely replaced the first child. The social impact of the Labor Government's economic policies on Australian society is immeasurable. We have only to look at all the promises made and broken in the past to see that obviously they are going to be broken again by this Government. In the 1987 Federal election, the Prime Minister made a historic commitment to end child poverty by 1990. Here we are in 1990, and it did not even rate a mention in the Governor-General's Speech. A new underclass in society has been created by the new economic order of Australia. We are breeding a new generation of hopeless and helpless people, and we are not realistically doing anything to prevent it. This lucky, clever country has nearly 94,000 households, or 200,000-plus people, living in caravans and other temporary dwellings and nearly 30,000 living in impoverished dwellings.

It is not only the economy but also the entire fabric of Australian society that are being totally mismanaged by this Government. The social injustice caused by the Government will be difficult to repair irrespective of the financial commitment it gives to it. The same applies to road funding. It is only because so many lives were lost over the Christmas period that the Government has decided to review its priorities for roads and rail. I look forward to the Federal Government introducing initiatives to upgrade our national transport infrastructure, including roads and rail. I applaud the brave commitment of the new Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Bob Collins, to achieving meaningful reforms on the waterfront but, like any good poker player, I will wait to see the colour of his money before I believe that he can deliver the goods. So far there have been words, but he will be judged on achievements.

Appropriately, that leads me to the question of airline deregulation. I hate to keep quoting from the Governor-General's Speech, but many of the lines are so classic that they will become appalling reminders of the Government's failure to deliver and they must be repeated. On the question of airline deregulation, it was said that `the Government will ensure that new entrants to the airline industry have fair access to major airports'-provided they do not want terminal space because the Prime Minister's friends have that all tied up-and so the new airlines will be given a fair go. I am encouraged by the assurances that the environmental impact study on Sydney's third runway will be completed this year. I am hopeful that at last the Federal Government, having secured its members' seats around Sydney Airport for another term, will now have the courage to build the third runway and so help ease Sydney's legendary airport congestion problems.

On pollution grounds alone, the Government ought to be pursuing additional runway space in order to reduce the amount of fuel wasted in holding pattern exercises that have become a predictable, regular aspect of flying through or to Sydney. In fact, last night, coming in from the country, the aircraft I was travelling in was held for 50 minutes circling around the top of the Sydney area. Of course, the people who came down from Brisbane were held for a similar amount of time. It is time that the Government did something about upgrading the radar and facilities at Mascot so that Sydney, which is the gateway to Australia-as a senator for New South Wales I am very proud of that, and I am quite sure that Senator Puplick is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone leaves there.

—Senator Ray comes from the State of Victoria, but go anywhere in the world and people realise that Sydney is the gateway to Australia. That airport needs to be upgraded so that people can fly in very easily. Additional appropriations are required as one result of the airlines dispute.
—Collins reckons Darwin is the gateway.

—Senator Mc- Kiernan comes from Western Australia. I can assure him that Sydney is the gateway to Australia. Something has to be done about proceeding with Badgerys Creek-and done quickly, not just at a time which the Government keeps on pushing off. First of all, a third runway has to be put into Kingsford-Smith Airport. This Government has told the electorate that it needed more time to get its act together. It has been given this record fourth term. The Government now has the extra time, and for the sake of all the people in Australia it will want to get it right this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4), Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2), with particular reference to the challenge facing the Government in the area of the defence of Australia. I am glad to see Senator Robert Ray, the new Minister for Defence, in the chamber today, because it is on his shoulders that a heavy burden rests. In my view, he has inherited a distortion of the defence budget which is going to lead to difficulties for the defence of Australia for many years to come. Senator Ray will be judged in years to come on his ability to cope with a budget which has been heavily proscribed by his predecessor and restricted so that he is left with very little area in which to move.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great sympathy in fact for Senator Ray facing this dilemma, because it is obviously not of his personal making, but it is a situation for which the Government of Australia must stand responsible. For seven years this Government has had the defence of Australia in its hands, and the problems which we face today, when we look at the defence of Australia, are fairly and squarely the responsibility of the Government of those seven years.

Just before the election, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced that there would be cuts to the forward estimates of the defence budget for the next three years in order to pay for its election sops and that that would amount to $241m. The difficulty that we face with those future cuts is that they need to be taken in conjunction with an announcement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the election campaign that Australia would take over the administration and running of the North West Cape facility. We have not been told what the expenditure impact will be for Australia, but some authorities are suggesting that it could be in the region of $30m.

When one puts those two facts together, and also recognises Mr Beazley's rush to re-equip the forces all at one time without proper staging of this re-equipment, Senator Ray will be faced with great difficulties unless he is able to get his Government to put more resources into the defence area or to walk away from the decision which the Treasurer announced in February relating to the forward estimates.

It is particularly important that the Government look again at what it is planning to do in the defence area because, although there is a wind of change-one might say-in eastern Europe and there are hopes for the future of peace and stability, those disarmament arrangements have not, in fact, flowed over to our region. As the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) said just recently, the changes in Europe may well have a detrimental effect on our region in that there will be arms suppliers looking for new markets. The opportunity exists for fire sale bargains to be available to nations in the Pacific and South East Asia regions, no doubt eventually adding to increased tensions in our region.
I would like to quote from an article in the most recent edition of the Pacific Defence Reporter, written by Denis Warner and entitled, `Interdependence not disarmament'. The article states:

By the end of this year Japan will be spending more on defence than any other US ally, and over the next three years there is likely to be a 10 per cent to 12 per cent reduction in the strength of American forces in Japan and Korea, where the US is already moving from a leading to a supporting role with the ROK forces. At the same time as one American speaker explained, if the Cold War is alive and well it is in Korea. The central North Korean objective remains unchanged: get the Americans out of the country . . . The situation is very dangerous and extremely worrisome.
Against this background, of course, we face the possible removal of the American bases in the Philippines. This would also, of course, remove an important element of regional stability.

Although there is great economic growth taking place in the Pacific Rim, there are real problems remaining in security areas amongst our neighbours. There are changes taking place but they do not mirror the changes that are taking place in Europe. In fact, with the rise of new power centres in India, China and Japan and the increased armaments being produced by India and China we have reason to be concerned for the future stability of our region.

Mr Warner concludes that for the middle and smaller powers of our region this is a time not for disarmament but, to borrow from the title of the symposium he was quoting, for `security through interdependence'. Therein lies Australia's future role, in my view-to be good neighbours, to be interdependent with our regional friends and to make sure that peace does break out all over our region.

Too often in the past we have been surprised by small nations in our area suddenly facing internal difficulties, some of which have had an impact directly on us, as in Fiji and the coups and in the appeals for help from Papua New Guinea. Obviously, we are not in an area in which we can take great comfort in foreseeable stability, and this could well have an impact for us. I am sure I do not need to labour this point, but I am concerned that there is an expectation in some parts of our country that, because of the changes in Europe, we should be seeing reduced defence expenditure in Australia.

The recommendations of Dr Paul Dibb in the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities in 1986 and the subsequent White Paper of 1987 in their way set out the parameters we would have to address during the decade ahead. Already, in the three years since the White Paper came out, there have been so many changes that I would not think it would go amiss if the Government were prepared to do an update of the White Paper-at least a discussion paper based on the changes since the White Paper was produced. It would be in Australia's interest to reassess our region and the impact of the changes throughout the world on our defence needs. Yet the Government seems to be just treading water and, if anything, slipping below the surface.

The White Paper and Dr Dibb spoke in terms of 3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) being needed to achieve the capabilities that Australia requires to maintain independence. Yet only last week in the Senate Senator Robert Ray told us that 3 per cent of GDP was not the eleventh commandment. It may have been a clever quip but it worries me that it may be an indication of either the Minister's approach to the subject or his expectation that his Government would not support him in getting the resources necessary to fulfil the White Paper's requirements. I think that what he meant was that the money was not forthcoming, and it would not be forthcoming, so he would be required to make the best of it.

What is the best of it? The current situation is that, despite having spent millions and millions of dollars, we have no real ability to protect our harbours and shipping lanes from mines. We have no proper mines countermeasure capability in this country. We have had a parliamentary inquiry into the subject, which was very damning of both the Navy and the Government and, still, we are dancing around, drifting around, and going under. It is an area of great importance. If there is any likelihood of our being harassed at sea, of being held to ransom, by any country in our region which wants to exert political pressure on us, one of the most effective ways would be to mine our ports or shipping lanes, threaten to do so, or claim to have done so. That would bring Australian trade and that from our trading partners to a standstill. I cannot think of a much more effective way in which to bring a country to heel than to stop its trade altogether.

In addition, it is widely acknowledged that we have inadequate surveillance. We have a huge continent with vast parts of the country uninhabited. It would be easy for drug runners, gun runners or nations of evil intent to make a landing. Yet, despite spending millions of dollars on the over-the-horizon radar, we are still not in a position where we can say that our radar gives us a network of surveillance over the country. Although I acknowledge that steps are being taken in that direction, it has placed a huge demand on the defence budget and there is still no coverage in place.

Equally important is the need for a decision to be made on the provision of airborne early warning aircraft. That decision still appears to be some way down the track. During Kangaroo 89 the previous Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, had a look at the airborne warning and control (AWAC) aircraft which were lent by the United States for the exercise. The Minister seemed pretty keen to get those aircraft into place, but still no decision has been taken; obviously no resources are available. The combination of the over-the-horizon radar and the airborne early warning aircraft is vital in a country with such vast spaces, such a long coastline and such a small population. We need superb surveillance in our north. A few well-manned reserve units patrolling in their local areas, as is done by Norforce, although it is a little start and one to be welcomed, certainly will not protect us from invasion or from harassments from countries which wish to put pressure on Australia.

Another matter facing us is the totally inadequate mobility of our defence forces. One of the issues that has been raised in recent times is the Government decision to sell the Chinook helicopters. There is no alternative in the Defence Force capital equipment to replace the Chinooks. There was an opportunity for Australia to join an upgrade program, through which the United States put about 500 Chinooks. We could have joined that upgrade program so that our Chinooks would have had their life extended by 25 to 30 years, and that would have brought down dramatically the cost of operating them. Instead, the Government decided to sell the Chinooks.

The helicopters are sitting at Amberley waiting to find a buyer, and in the meantime we are not even able to bring them into use to help during our floods. For the ability to get artillery into difficult areas in the north of Australia there is no equal. The Government has taken a wilful and misguided decision which has reduced our ability to support troops in the field.

We have no decision yet on a helicopter platform. The absence of that was terribly evident during our abortive attempt to go to the aid of Australians in Fiji during the coup. The debacle, as one might have described it-as it would have been if they had to go into Fiji against opposition-is one that our troops should never have to face. In my view it is quite disgraceful that of all the options that are available-and there are many to provide helicopter platforms to increase the capability of our defence forces-no decision has been made.

We have great difficulty in being able to operate our troops in the north and to get them to remote areas. This was clearly one of the lessons learnt by exercise Kangaroo '89. Still the Government dillydallies about a decision to improve our ability in that area. It is well recognised-I have certainly helped by keeping the public informed-how undermanned our Army is. The total Defence Force has gone from 72,000 when this Government came to office seven years ago to 68,000 now. I believe that this is suiting the Government very nicely. It is a subterfuge or an underhand way of reducing the manpower costs in the defence forces. Yet when the day comes we will ask, `Why was this allowed to happen?'.

We have a lack of specialists in all three Services. Last week we received the last of 75 FA18s. Is it well understood-I doubt it-that we do not have the air crews and the maintenance teams to keep those FA18s in the air? The Royal Australian Navy is desperately short of ships engineers. In all three services we are unable to fill positions for computer specialists and communication specialists. We have something like 350 officers short in the Australian Army, positions that have had to be filled by reservists coming in on full time duty. The high wastage rates that we have been facing for so long have meant that over the last couple of years we have had a quarter of our Defence Force replaced by newcomers with basic training only. The difficulties that we are now having in recruiting people to the defence forces are all problems which contribute to the reduction of our defence capability.

What is the Government doing? As I said at the beginning of my speech, the Government is cutting $241m from the defence budget over the next three years. The Government is adding an expense of perhaps $30m for North West Cape. The Government is failing to make the decisions that are necessary. It seems to have no will, no heart, to make defence decisions. The Government is being hamstrung by Minister Beazley's contracts for the next 10 to 15 years, contracts that are somehow like a bride wanting to have the whole house furnished, lock stock and barrel, in the first year of marriage, no worry what it does to the budget-carpets, curtains, electronic gear and a video as well. Mr Beazley, without thought for the future, pushed it all along too far, too fast.

What is happening in manpower terms? We are recruiting foreign mercenaries into our defence forces and, as we discovered the other night at Estimates Committee B, no proper thought has been given to what we will do about people who come here as a result of our recruiting and who are not Australian citizens. We are recruiting Swedish pilots, for example. It is a condition of service that a member of the Australian Defence Force must be a citizen. Quite clearly, that has not been sorted out. We are faced with the situation of having people in our Defence Force whom we have recruited from foreign countries and who are not citizens. I, for one, am concerned that that should have been allowed to happen. How could the Government have allowed it to happen without proper planning and without an explanation to the Australian people?

Just recently we announced, with quite a fanfare, that we would have Australian women on warships. I am happy to see women get a proper go in the defence forces of Australia. As honourable senators would realise, for a long time I have been pushing for them to take their place in Defence Force employment in a meaningful and planned way. Instead we have had an unplanned recruitment of women to fill the places we cannot get men to fill, but without proper organisational arrangements, without planning for their future career development, without planning for how their recruitment fits into the Defence Force's needs. In my view, the announcement the other day was, once again, totally unplanned. I asked at Senate Estimates Committee B how women will be recruited, how many women there will be at sea this time next year, what ships women will be placed on and what the cost of converting the ships will be. Nobody could answer. The implication was: the announcement has been made and we will work it out later. Clearly it was a political announcement under instructions from the Government, and it is saying, `We will muddle along and try to do something about it later on'.

I would like to put on record some of the costs of having to recruit and train new people to cope with the enormous losses from the defence forces that we have been facing for the last four or five years. I am quoting from the Army submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Cross Committee, in 1988. The costs of training then-and that was back in 1988-included the following examples: to train a recuit, $9,396; to educate an Australian Defence Force Academy graduate, $222,000; to take that Academy graduate and give him or her training at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, which is required after graduating from the Academy, a further $175,000. So we are up to about $400,000 for an Academy graduate to actually enter the Army. Duntroon training for non-Academy graduates cost $260,000. A regimental officer's basic course at the Armoured Centre cost $340,774. Apprenticeship training cost $100,000. The cost of putting an armoured corps subaltern into the field was between $600,774 and $737,774. The training of a corporal radio mechanic was assessed at about $115,259.

We have enormous costs in training people to replace those that we have lost. Yet this Government seems unprepared to divert that money into meaningful personnel measures which will keep those people in the forces, thus not only making them happier in the career that they have chosen but also, importantly for Australia, retaining the experience levels that we need in a defence force. A defence force is not just a question of machines; it is a question of man power and woman power. The whole equation demands capabilities in both areas.

The Government should maintain the expenditure which it set out pre-February this year in its Forward Estimates. The Government should announce a timetable for achieving the capabilities, which we still so badly lack, which were set out as requirements in the White Paper of 1987. The Government should use the advice which has been long available to it to implement dramatic and sustainable personnel retention measures.

In conclusion, the experience levels of our forces have to be retained if we are going to have a viable Defence Force in a difficult and uncertain future in our region. Our Defence Force personnel must be made to feel appreciated because, as I said earlier, our capability does not relate just to machines. Men and women are a critical part of our defence formula. For seven years the Labor Government has produced these problems and they will not be able to be cured overnight.

In the light of the growing manpower and weaponry of some of the countries in our region, and of the uncertainties which we face as a result of the disarmament measures in eastern Europe and their flow-on effects to our region, it is absolutely vital for Australia to be both independent of and interdependent with our neighbours in our region, to demonstrate that we have a deterrent capability, the willpower to defend our country, the men and women with the experience levels to do just that on our behalf, and that the physical capability and machinery that is required, the weapons of war and the surveillance measures, are in place. Senator Ray has an enormous challenge facing him. His Government has to listen to the needs of the Australian nation because, otherwise, I fear very much that Senator Ray will be found wanting, as has his Government to date, in the defence area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity today to address the general question of Parliament's control over the Executive. When this matter was raised when I was at school and university it seemed to be a somewhat theoretical matter that could be left to another day and did not have an immediacy that it is now clear to me it has.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address the question of Parliament's control over the Executive in relation to three specific areas. Firstly, I refer to Question Time, that time of our day that many people believe forms the major part of parliamentary work. Of course, we know they are misunderstanding this matter, but nonetheless that is the element of the parliamentary day that receives the most publicity and about which members of the public have the most understanding. Secondly, I refer to the question of Parliament's control over the Executive with respect to the Senate Estimates committees that have been sitting over the past week, and which will probably be tabling reports later today. Those committees have the opportunity to peruse the expenditure planned to be spent by separate departments, and that gives honourable senators the opportunity to ask quite detailed questions in relation to that expenditure. Thirdly, I want to look at the question of Parliament's control over the Executive in relation to Senate standing committees, and, in particular, to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

I will commence by dealing with the Estimates committees that have been sitting over the past week. It may seem to those unfamiliar with these committees-that is probably the case with school children and many members of the public and, quite frankly, it is probably the case with many members of the Press Gallery-that these are boring committees that talk about nothing but who wants what money, and that if one was an insomniac one might attend, but otherwise not. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth, and without labouring the point I want to refer to the Estimates Committee of which I was a member this time, which gave those honourable senators who wished to avail themselves of it the opportunity to make inquiries into the cost of one of the more prominent and strongly contested pieces of legislation that this Parliament has seen in the last half-decade-that is, the legislation relating to war crimes. The expenses associated with the passing of that Act are to be found primarily in the Attorney-General's portfolio. Without going into a lot of detail I think it is fair to say that if the Commonwealth expects change out of $10m from that exercise it is barking up the wrong tree.

It is an interesting exercise to go to that Estimates Committee and look at the explanatory details provided by the Attorney-General's Department. We find, if we look at the special investigations unit, which is the unit set up to make these special investigations, that the total cost of the war crimes legislation is not to be found under that item. In fact, we have to go to a number of other subprograms in the Attorney-General's portfolio before we can get to the total cost.

This was a divisive piece of legislation. We could argue that its impact still is divisive. I do not want to raise today the merits or otherwise of that legislation. I simply want to say that it is the Senate Estimates committees that provide the opportunity to follow up legislation-after it has been passed in the House of Representatives where the Government knows it has the numbers and after it has passed through this chamber-and can pick up the detail and the cost of what it is that Parliament has chosen to do. In that way, it can scrutinise the cost of the Executive plans. Change out of $10m is not likely, in my view.

There is another perhaps more topical and recent example of how Senate Estimates committees can be used to ascertain the cost of Executive action. We all know that in the last couple of weeks a particular drug trial in Sydney was called off, primarily as a consequence of remarks made by a member of the Executive, Senator Tate. We had a long debate in this chamber and numerous remarks were made in addition to a censure motion of Senator Tate for the remarks he made which occasioned the trial to be called off. Through the Estimates Committee, honourable senators are able to ascertain just exactly what that cost the taxpayer.

As I recall, the cost to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) was in the order of $36,000, possibly $46,000. Of course, there would be additional costs to the Australian Federal Police for calling off that matter. I do not want to make an issue today of the cancellation of a trial in progress-of Senator Tate and Yooyen-as a consequence of remarks made by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). I simply want to underline that it is the Senate Estimates committees that give parliamentarians-honourable senators and, through them, if they are courteous to their lower House colleagues, House of Representatives members-the opportunity to ascertain the cost of these sorts of actions.

These matters are raised in the media on a day-to-day basis. I just wonder whether members of the public appreciate the extent to which parliamentarians peruse these matters long after they have ceased to be headlines of the day. I suspect they do not have a significant understanding of that because one of the main criticisms I frequently hear of parliamentarians is that all we want to do is chase the headlines of the day. Far too little attention is given, not just by the Press Gallery but by ourselves, to highlighting the fact that the majority of our work lies in following up these matters long after the media have lost interest in them.

I was not on the Estimates Committee that perused the estimates for further expenditure in child-care, but I hope that when I have the opportunity of perusing the Hansard of that Committee I will find significant questioning of the Government's announcements during the election of what it was going to do with child-care. Anybody who looked at the Government's press releases would see that the Government had not so much the courage but the gall to promise to the Australian electorate, `Vote for us and this is what we'll do, not just for this Parliament, but for the following parliament, and for the first year of the Parliament after that'.

That is how confident an Executive we have, an Executive that thinks it can go to the Australian people and make promises not for one parliament or the next, but into the one after. Those promises should be very clearly stuck on the front page of every outline of expenditure for the Estimates Committee dealing with child-care until the expiration of the time period for which this Government promised certain action would be taken. But, as I say, I have not been on that Committee. I hope that when I peruse the Hansard record of its proceedings, I find that questions were asked in respect of that matter. I raise it only to highlight the wide range of issues that can be further attacked, if you like, through the Estimates Committee; namely, the war crimes issue, the calling off of the Yooyen trial, child-care and many other issues.

During the hearings of the Estimates Committee of which I was a member a matter was raised that caused me particular concern in relation to Parliament's control over expenditure. One honourable senator asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, who was in attendance, what was the per diem rate that counsel were paid for a particular matter, As I recall, this took place during questioning of the Trade Practices Commission. The officers detailed a number of cases that the Commission had been handling.

In regard to, I think, the Arnotts matter, the officers were asked: `How many counsel did you have? Were there juniors with senior counsel? If so, how many and how much were they paid?'. There was some consternation and a couple of tete-a-tetes between the Minister and officers before the answer was provided that, should senators wish to look to the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department, they would see how much was paid over one year by way of counsel fees to various counsel. If one did this, one would be able to see that Mr A received $200,000 and Mr B $300,000, and that, hopefully, Mrs C received $600,000 and Mrs E $100,000. Of course, that would not be sufficient because it would not enable honourable senators to see whether particular counsel were being paid a daily rate far greater than that of other counsel; in other words, the extent to which the Commonwealth was engaged in bargaining with its counsel.

The explanation was given, that once the total amount is known, one then knows who is getting the maximum amount and one can see whether any vested interest is being served. But, of course, that does not answer the question of whether particular counsel are being paid far more or far less than others and what sorts of deals are being entered into. I think this is a fair and legitimate inquiry of Parliament. Just how much are we paying a counsel to represent us in matters run by the Trade Practices Commission?

Regretfully, that matter was not resolved that night. But the attention of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, who is at the table, was drawn to the resolutions and orders of the Senate, which have continuing effect. In particular, his attention was drawn to the resolution No. 3 dealing with statutory bodies and accountability, which is outlined on page 123. The resolution states:
That the Committee . . .
recommends . . .

(i) that the principle, espoused by the Senate in 1971 and 1974, that there are no areas of expenditure of public funds where Statutory Authorities have a discretion to withhold details or explanations from Parliament or its Committees unless the Parliament has expressly provided otherwise, be re-affirmed;
This was an area of expenditure where details were withheld. I will come to the explanations for that in a minute. The second part of this resolution states:

(ii) the affirmation, in accordance with this principle, that the right to privacy of individual counsel accepting a brief on behalf of the Commonwealth for which money is appropriated by Parliament is supervened by such acceptance, subject to the reasons for the information being clearly defined and to the proviso that injudicious or unwarranted invasion of privacy is not the intention of the Parliament or its Committees;

This resolution makes two things abundantly clear. The first is that in 1980 the Senate was of the view that the view it had expressed in 1971 and 1974 should stand. The Senate is still of that view because these resolutions and orders have continuing effect. So the view is that there are no areas of detail within expenditure beyond Parliament's inquiry. Furthermore, counsel, by accepting a brief from the Commonwealth, lose their right to privacy.

I am sorry that the Minister at the table, Senator Cook, was not convinced by this argument and has offered to come back with a further explanation of the Department's position. I look forward to receiving that information, because the Minister was also reminded of a report from the then Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

You may remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, a member of another Estimates committee in 1986 asked the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) what Geraldine Doogue's salary was. I thought it was a fair enough question. Everybody was dying to know what Geraldine Doogue was paid by the ABC. What did the ABC representative say? `I am sorry, market confidentiality applies there.' What a lot of rot. If we allowed that sort of thing to go on, what we would have is statutory authorities-and, for that matter, individual departments, to the extent that they can contract-putting confidentiality clauses in any contracts that they like and using those clauses as a shield against parliamentary inquiry. Then there would be no way that taxpayers would be able to find out how their money is being spent.

The executive arm of government is only too keen to tell the public what it wants to do with its money. The point I am making here is that the Estimates committees give other parliamentarians the opportunity to ascertain exactly what the Government has done with the money. It is simply not acceptable to have sections of the community, who may have in some other respects certain privileges, claim that it is inappropriate that the details of their contracts with the Commonwealth be revealed.

In my view, if counsel accepts a brief on behalf of the Commonwealth knowing that it is being paid for by the taxpayer, that person has no right to say to the taxpayer, `You are not going to find out how much I am paid.' If the taxpayer is footing the bill, the taxpayer is entitled to know. I look forward very much to the Minister's response to that Estimates committee inquiry.

The third matter that I said I wanted to raise, which I will deal with secondly, is parliamentary control over the Executive in relation to Question Time, Estimates committees and certain other Senate committees. I have dealt with the question of Parliament's control through the Estimates committees, and I now want to deal with the third area I raised which is other Senate committees. I have recently had the pleasure of being put on the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. This is a committee that scrutinises individual Bills to see whether the rights and opportunities of individual Australians are in some respects inadvertently being limited or trampled on by what an Act or a Bill seeks to do. In that respect it is very similar to another committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

I have had the privilege of serving on that committee as well. That committee peruses the regulations and ordinances that individual Ministers are entitled to make or proclaim. It scours through them to find whether, in making those regulations and ordinances, the rights of individuals have been trampled on. That is perhaps putting it a bit loosely, but I think it is a fair description of what that committee seeks to do. When that committee finds a problem with a regulation or ordinance, it writes to the Minister and says, `Look, perhaps you may not have realised this, but inadvertently these rights are being limited here. You could achieve your policy aim and nonetheless not tread on this individual's rights'.

It has been a very successful committee. Ministers understand that that committee has never lost. Whenever it has said to a Minister, `Fine, if you want to dig your heels in and refuse to make this change, we will seek to get the Senate to disallow your regulations', one of two things have happened: either at the last minute the Minister has changed his mind and given in; or the regulations have been disallowed.

It is in a similar vein that, as I understand it, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee does its work. I look forward to the day when members and senators on both sides will, in a bipartisan way, support amendments to Bills that reflect the desires of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I think that day is probably some long way off, because while members of the opposite side of this chamber-that is, members of the Labor Party-are happy and have been happy in the past to bring in a bipartisan way an individual Minister to order for inadvertently trampling on individual rights through regulations and ordinances, I am not sure that members on the other side would be ever given the liberty to bring their whole Executive to order for doing exactly the same thing in a Bill that was coming before Parliament.

I wish to make another point with respect to that committee by giving one example that we saw last year of how effective its work is. What happened with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Commission Bill, or package of Bills, was that the Committee went through them, noticed a number of problems with them, and indicated those problems in either its digest or its report-I am no sure which. What happened? The House of Representatives noticed the content of the report and the Government, of its own volition, amended the Bill in the House of Representatives.

Some people would say, `Well, you know when you got the Bill up into the Senate chamber, in those respects it had been fixed up. So that was the House of Representatives doing a good job; of course, that is rubbish. It was not the House of Representatives doing a good job; it was the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills doing a good job and the House of Representatives having the brains to see that if it did not put its house in order with respect to those matters, then this chamber would. In other words, it was the committee work of this chamber that fixed up elements of that Bill, in reality, and not the House of Representatives. I raise that matter just as a separate example of how Parliament, and especially senators, can through their work peruse the work of the Executive and keep some control.

The last matter I want to raise relates to Question Time. I recall a former senator, Reg Withers from Western Australia, whom my colleague Senator Knowles knew well, saying that it was not properly titled Questions Without Notice in that it should more properly be called Questions Without Answers. In the five years that I have been here, that has certainly been the case. It is the one hour in the day here and the 45 minutes in the House of Representatives when the media are particularly interested in what happens. It is seen as being the theatre of Parliament, and certainly because of that members are encouraged to perhaps be a bit more vociferous than they otherwise might be.

It really is a matter of regret-this is the whole point that I am trying to make by raising these points today-that Question Time is the focus of the media's attention. If people do well in Question Time, they are perceived to have their act together. If Ministers, or for that matter those asking questions, are not so gladiatorial in their style at Question Time, then it is easy for the media perhaps to make an assessment that they are not as good as someone who is a gladiator. I think that is a mistake, because the job of being a parliamentarian and the job of being a Minister is in both cases a far bigger job, a far greater role, than simply being a big mouth at Question Time and being a winner in the gladiatorial debate that goes on in that short space of time.

There is no better example of someone who sees himself in that gladiatorial role than Treasurer Keating. Perhaps one need use only that example to show how unimportant Question Time, in one sense, ought to be. The media write the Treasurer up as being someone who knows how to go in with boots and all and who knows he is in charge. That is how the Treasurer has got his reputation-primarily through the manner in which he has conducted himself in Question Time. He has got a good reputation as being a tough, hard-headed political fighter who will win the day because of that.

Of course, if we look outside Question Time at what the Treasurer has done, particularly at the moment and over the past five years, what we see is a disaster. He admits himself that we are down the Argentinean road. I am not sure whether we have given up on the J-curve and gone to some other letter. There is a view that we are beyond treating J as an L and running along the flat-that we are now running downhill badly in terms of the economy.

I provided to the media about a month ago some material which showed that, on 10 key economic indicators, we were last behind six or seven Asian countries. Our neighbours, with whom we now purport to take a senior role, must be laughing behind their hands. Either the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seek to take a senior role on the Asian stage and march up on any occasion to offer advice to these countries, which are doing far better than we are. They must think it is a huge joke.

When I and other senators were at school, we were taught that these countries were poor Third World nations that needed our support. Those countries have managed to pick themselves up by their bootstraps and get their act together. Yet Treasurer Keating, who has such a good reputation because of the manner in which he conducts himself during Question Time, has not been able to bring this country back together. In fact, he has pulled it further and further down.

So we have to ask ourselves what we achieve by Question Time. It is meant to be a time when members of parliament on both sides can peruse the Executive and find out what the Executive is trying to do. In part, the media has made Question Time almost an art form for people not to give answers at all. We frequently find very long-sometimes boring, sometimes not boring-answers that nonetheless do not address the specific points raised in the questions. Sometimes we have two or three minutes of simple abuse of the previous Government, which held office back in 1983-it should almost be part of ancient history books now. We are in a situation where this Government's Ministers come to Question Time and generally during the first few minutes of an answer the Minister says, `What would you have done?'. That is after seven or eight years. That is the vision that this Government's Executive now has. Its members cannot come through Question Time without referring to what would have happened nearly eight years ago. If this Government runs its full term we will have had a decade of Labor and it will be saying, `Well, a decade ago', and looking back into the past. That is not a productive way to answer questions.

Some Ministers take up five or six minutes of Question Time with the express purpose of doing one of two things. Either they make some sort of statement that they could make in another fashion without taking up time in Question Time, in which case there is some particular information which they want to put forward and for which they have arranged a dorothy dixer-in a sense that is marginally excusable-or they simply take up time so that there will be fewer questions. So we have Question Time reduced to an absolute farce. The point I am making is that this is not something that has happened in the last year.

Mr Acting Deputy President, had you and I been in this chamber in 1971-I had been out of school only two or three years-we would have heard nearly 34 questions a day asked in this chamber. In 1976, it had shifted down to about 31 questions a day. If we move on a bit, in 1979-80 there were still 28 questions a day being asked. We have now moved down to an average last year of 16 and a bit questions a day. It is a very serious reduction of the capacity of this chamber to peruse the Executive that is achieved by Ministers simply rambling on and not addressing the specific points raised by the questions that honourable senators put to them.

Some Ministers might think this is a smart way to go about it; they might think they are achieving something. But in my view, they are denigrating the parliamentary process and the institution of Question time by continually behaving in this fashion. We all understand that there will be occasions when the Government want to protect one of its members or one of its actions and it will necessarily tactically decide on that day that it has to ramble on as much as possible to keep the Opposition off the scent. No-one is complaining about that. That is a matter of parliamentary tactics. But to do it on a daily basis, to deprive honourable senators of the opportunity to ask questions, is quite another thing.

Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, says that he is very concerned with the conduct of Parliament and with the conduct of Question Time. He has instructed his Ministers to answer double the number of questions in a day. On that basis, the Senate should now be receiving 32.8-say, 33-questions a day. In the first couple of weeks until, I think, Wednesday we were getting only 19 questions a day. That is no big deal compared with what the Prime Minister has told his Ministers: double the number of questions. Last week Senator Robert Ray said that he was not concerned with the question asked. He had the answer he wanted to give and that was the answer that he was going to give.

It is my view that the situation needs urgent attention. Speaker Rozzoli in the New South Wales lower House has restricted answers to five minutes. We could look at alternative systems where up to four times as many questions are handled in one day as are handled in this chamber, which would give far greater opportunity for Parliament through Question Time to pursue the actions of the Executive. Until this Government realises that something needs to be done about that institution of Parliament-and, for that matter, until the chamber takes the matter into its own hands and deals with those people who refuse to see the merit of these matters-we are in big trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Appropriations (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1989-90, the Appropriations Bill (No. 3) 1989-90, the Appropriations Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91. It is very timely that I follow my colleague Senator Vanstone because she has made some very telling points about the way in which this Government conducts itself in the Senate, which also extend to the way in which it conducts itself outside the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990 election is well and truly over and the Hawke Labor Government has a major task of tackling the problems that it has spent the last seven years creating. For the first time since 1980 a majority of Australians at a general election have not supported the Australian Labor Party. I do not say that in any way to excuse the coalition for failing to win a majority of seats. However, it means that, on the basis of preference votes, the Hawke Labor Government has been re-elected with a weak and diminishing mandate while employing campaign tactics of a very dubious nature.

In Western Australia Labor won eight out of the 14 seats. It is equally relevant that, after the distribution of preferences, nearly 53 per cent of Western Australians voted against the Hawke Labor Government. This Government has a moral responsibility to take heed of this voter sentiment and act accordingly. It seems, however-sad as it may be-that there is very little intention to be honest with the people of Australia or to carry through or even consider policy changes that may be in the national interest.

It is all too clear in the stance of the new Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the political tactician has entirely taken the place of the Treasurer. We are firmly told that we live under the best of all taxation systems in the best of all possible worlds. Maybe he should talk to more individuals and small businesses that are rapidly going to the wall as a direct consequence of his colossal and ever increasing taxing policies. No thought is to be given to reforms of direct and indirect taxes that might encourage savings and productivity and lower interest rates. The only change to indirect taxes is to increase them.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer can trumpet around day in and day out and say that they will not consider a consumption tax. As we well know, that is simply not true. We have a form of consumption tax at the moment. We have yet another Bill to increase sales tax even further on luxury vehicles. If that is not a form of consumption tax, what is? No recognition will be given to the candid admissions of Senators Walsh and Button that the only answer left to this Labor Government to depress demand is to engineer a recession. Yet the Treasurer, himself, on 12 February said:
The economy is slowing down, I mean, policy is working.

They are his words; not mine. Proof of just how well policy is working is evident in the latest bankruptcy statistics for the March quarter-showing a rise of 27 per cent over the same period in 1989, with a 74 per cent rise in Western Australia. Labor policy is clearly working exceptionally well in my own State, with a warning last month that one-third of our 70,000 small business enterprises are in serious trouble. It concerns me that that increase for the March quarter of 74 per cent of businesses going bankrupt does not take into consideration those businesses that have simply shut up shop before they have gone broke. That would make the figure a whole lot worse, not only in terms of the number of small businesses that have gone out of business, but also of the number of people who have lost their jobs and their security as a direct consequence. This Labor Government will not appreciate hearing from Senator Walsh or Senator Button the truth that was so carefully concealed from the Australian people during the election campaign-that the vaunted accord does nothing to give Australia what it needs so badly, increased productivity.
