We have two senators-one an ex-minister and one a current Minister-who are saying that there should be an increase in productivity. What is happening? Messrs Hawke and Keating say `Not on. We are just going to have nominal wage increases regardless of productivity and regardless of whether that sends businesses bust'. This Government clearly has no vision at all for the future of Australia. Senator Walsh has stated that the level of nominal wage increases under the Accord remains undesirably high and that there has been a failure to deliver improved productivity. Has the Government done anything to increase productivity? No, it has not done a thing and it has no intention of doing so. Businesses of any kind do not mind paying people more as long as they get more in return, but they cannot afford to go on paying more and getting nothing.

Australians were warned at the beginning of April by the Business Council of Australia that we must raise national productivity by at least two per cent annually if we are to cut our inflation rate to that of our trading partners and avoid the harsher alternative of lower real wages. Only a week later, the National Institute of Labor Studies reported that productivity growth is likely to remain sluggish and that far from improving, it has deteriorated. The blame for inflation is laid squarely at the feet of this weak productivity and the rising labor costs that the accord fails miserably to restrain.

Small business cannot afford any more labour costs without a comparable increase in productivity. When will the Government recognise this? The Government has had seven and a half years to recognise it and continues to ignore it. Australians will wait in vain for this arrogant, tired Labor Government to change policy so that the accord can no longer operate with its blessing to lock us into an uncompetitive inflation rate.

So, too, will we wait in vain for honesty and action in regard to the problem of overseas debt that ultimately will drive us down to the level of the Third World, if we are not already there. My colleague Senator Vanstone talked a little while ago about the countries that we were once told were way behind us and considered Third World countries. On 19 January it was reported that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development figures-quickly dismissed by the Treasurer, I might add-showed that Australia owed $55 billion to international banks. This puts Australia fourth in the international table, behind such notorious economies as Brazil, Mexico and the Soviet Union and ahead of Argentina. If that is not a disgrace, then what is? What did the Government do? Nothing.

In February we were warned by Access Economics Pty Ltd that under the continuation of present policies, in which this Government continues to have blind faith, net foreign debt will rise from 32 per cent to 42 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) within five years assuming that the terms of trade in the world economy remain stable. If, however, a more gloomy forecast prevails, then by the year 2000 our foreign debt will be 56 per cent of GDP.

We are indebted to Professor Blainey, who reminds us that on the two previous occasions in our history when debt servicing rose above the level of 25 per cent of export income, massive recessions were the result-in the 1890s and 1920s. Foreign debt servicing now consumes 20 per cent of export income. What will the Government do? It will do nothing, because the Treasurer-the Deputy Prime Minister of this country-and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say that everything is going along just fine. Again, I respectfully suggest that they go out and talk to some people in the real world and not just talk to themselves. This is a problem that, to say the least, is not going to disappear now that the election has been won. It would seem, however, that the Government will not admit to the extent of the problem, let alone fight for a solution.

Interest rates continue to be a massive drain upon business and home buyers despite their much vaunted, yet marginal, easing. Improving home affordability can have little to offer those who, in this Labor-created recession, will lose their jobs and their incomes. It is a real tragedy to talk to people from some of the financial institutions at the moment who say that people are literally walking in their doors, throwing the keys down on the counter and saying, `Get me out of my home'. The tragedy is that many of them cannot afford to stay in their homes and many cannot afford to leave their homes because the value of their homes has diminished and yet their interest rates have gone up and their income has gone down.

A marginal drop in interest rates-which is likely to be reversed later this year-will not alter the essential position of families surveyed by the Real Estate Institute of Australia in six electorates in March. Those families quite clearly said that they needed to boost their after tax income by $100 per week before they could afford home loans. It is nothing short of appalling to think that that is what this Government has done to people trying to buy homes. The Hawke Labor Government cannot evade prime responsibility for the fact that over the past 10 years the income needed to fund an average mortgage has increased by 250 per cent while household incomes have risen by less than half that amount. One Western Australian seat included in the survey was Moore. It registered a swing, after preferences, of 6.3 per cent against Labor.

Another intractable problem for which the Hawke Government must urgently find some answers is health care. We heard plenty of abuse of the coalition policy during the election campaign, including the notable lie that we were going to abolish Medicare, but very little recognition of the inexorable pressure that Medicare in its current form places upon the health system. At the outset of the election campaign, on 24 February, the former Minister for Health-he is very wise to be `former' before it gets worse-boasted that Australia's public hospital system was, `getting on top of waiting lists'. I do not know what fairyland he was in when he said that, but obviously, as a Minister for Health, he had become tired and jaded like the rest of this Labor Government because he had not gone out to the public hospitals to find out whether the waiting lists existed or not. But obviously there is one person in this Government who has found that waiting lists do exist and that Medicare is rotten, or lousy-call it what you like-and that is Mr Hawke. He has not relied on Medicare. He has gone to St Vincent's Private Hospital!

Mr Hawke cannot very well tell us all that Medicare is you beaut, fantastic and the best thing since sliced bread if he is not prepared to use the public hospital system himself. But then again he might have gone along to one of the public hospitals in Sydney and found himself at the end of a 100,000 waiting list. His little operation could not wait. In the final days of the campaign, the lid was just starting to come off this Medicare fiasco.

On 22 March it was reported that a new children's ward in the Armadale-Kelmscott Hospital in Perth in the outer suburbs was empty. High patient numbers had caused cost overruns so the necessary medical staff could not be employed. Prior to the election, the State Minister for Health categorically and unequivocally denied that the 30-plus bed ward was going to close in the Kalgoorlie regional hospital. What happened post-election? It closed. On election day, all a bit too late for maximum impact, the West Australian reported that public hospitals in the State were in crisis, with the announcement of a closure of 12 beds at the Rockingham Hospital, and a restriction on elective surgery to three cases per week in one of the most rapidly expanding parts of the metropolitan area. At the Geraldton regional hospital a $700,000 budget blow-out resulted in the closure of a 24-bed surgical ward requiring patients to travel 450 kilometres to the metropolitan area.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the surgeons moved out.

—That is quite right, Senator, the surgeons did move out, and such closures are only likely to continue. It is ironic to learn that despite the spending of $8.3m on building improvements at the Geraldton Hospital elective surgery was cancelled from 12 April. More and more West Australians are learning the hard way that they are not getting value for the health dollar under Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: The following day, 27 March, West Australians were told of the closure of 20 beds at the Bunbury regional hospital and the suspension of elective surgery at Bentley Hospital with the closure of a surgical ward. It is a measure of the severity of the crisis that in Geraldton-as Senator Panizza interjected a little while ago-surgeons offered to defer payments of fees for three months to avoid the closure of the surgical ward.

On 5 February the Chairman of the State Committee of the Australian Association of Surgeons, Mr Nash, wrote to the Australian Financial Review pointing to a key factor in this increasing bed shortage as a 40 per cent coverage of the population to a level giving them surgery in a private hospital, compared with 80 per cent in 1970. So in 20 years it has dropped to half. A waiting list of 18 months described by Mr Nash, with elective surgery down to two cases per month over the last three years, I believe tells its own story. The fact that prior to this he had been able for 25 years to book one to five patients each week for elective surgery in public hospitals shows how Medicare has operated to deny hospital beds to uninsured Australians. What is probably the worst aspect of this is that people do not know that the situation is as bad as it is until such time as they need to use a public hospital, or until they have a friend or a relative in need of a public hospital.

The other side of the story has also been well reported since the election with 800 of the 2,000 private hospital beds in Western Australia lying idle each day while the same number of privately insured patients occupy public hospital beds to the exclusion of many of the people that Medicare was designed to help. This coming Saturday the State Government of Western Australia is facing two by-elections because the former Premier and the former Deputy Premier have seen fit to flit the State. There are many reasons why they want to do that too.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Premier before that, too.

—And the Premier before that; exactly, Senator. Former Premier Burke has also decided to flit the State. We have seen a massive exercise in pork-barrelling by the new Premier, Dr Lawrence. We have this whole scenario that I have gone through of crisis in public hospitals right throughout the State with wards closing hand over fist and, guess what? The Government has found millions of dollars-I think it is about $2.3m-to do an upgrade of Fremantle Hospital. I would not deny that Fremantle Hospital could do with an upgrade, but is it not somewhat ironic that one of the seats up for grabs next weekend is the seat of Fremantle? Here we have all these hospitals starving to death in the regional areas and Dr Lawrence, Dr Feelgood, says, `We will look after Fremantle'. It is just appalling when, as I said before, in Geraldton patients now have to travel 450 kilometres to get surgery. The Government says, `We will pork-barrel Fremantle because there is a vote in it for next Saturday'. The private sector resources are fully capable of treating many of the patients currently drawn into the public system where, of our two major hospitals, outpatient clinics at the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital are cancelled one day each week and, more seriously, orthopaedic surgery is cancelled at Royal Perth Hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: A week before last I asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who represents the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) what was being done about this dreadful state of health in the public hospital system in Western Australia. He did not know. That is a bit of an indictment as well. With the situation as bad as it is in Western Australia he did not have the faintest idea whether anything was to be done, whether anything had been done, or whether anything was likely to be done. That is the reality of the way in which the Government is treating people who have had faith in such a lousy system.

I come back to the problem between private and public hospitals. The cause of this tragic misallocation of resources was underscored on 4 May with the release of statistics showing that in the March quarter of 1990 some 12,000 Western Australians opted out of private health cover, bringing to 60,000 the total for the year, and a grand total of more than 400,000 since December 1983. The Government will tell us that is because people have faith in the system and that it is such a fantastic system. That is not the truth.

The reason that people are opting out of private health insurance is that they cannot afford to pay three times. They cannot afford to pay the mandatory levy, they cannot afford to pay the other 66 per cent out of general revenue, and they cannot afford to pay private health insurance. Something has to go towards keeping their houses, feeding their families and, unfortunately, private health insurance is the one that goes. They only find out that that was a wrong course of action to take when they get sick. What that really means is an extra cost of $33m to the State's public hospital system, worsening the effects that are already taking place. A 1.2 per cent drop in private cover on a national basis means that a further 182,000 Australians are now uninsured and will be the sole responsibility of the public hospital system.

Prior to the election the Government refused to spell out to the people of Australia what it was going to do to try to correct the ills of Medicare. Will it decrease the rebate? Will it increase the levy? Will it shift more costs onto the State governments? What will it do? If anyone can find out what the Government is doing, he is doing very well, because it is one of the best kept secrets that this Government has. All it will do is continue to watch the decline of the health system and not say what it will do about it to correct it. This Labor Government does not have the luxury of pretending that the private health system is outside its concern. Despite its socialist rhetoric, Medicare was deliberately based upon the assumption that a large percentage of Australians would maintain their private cover.

Maintaining private cover really does not help people all that much these days. Sometimes I cannot believe the people of Australia. If any government were to tell them that they could insure only the front ends of their cars or the backs of their houses they would go berserk. But they seem to accept the fact that they can be insured for only 85 per cent of their health costs.

In a situation pretty close to me a person spent time in intensive care wards in both public and private hospitals for four or five weeks. This person had top private health insurance and was paying the levy and taxes but has been hit for thousands of dollars. Why can we not have a health system such as that proposed by us prior to the election-one that allows people to insure for the gap so that they can go to the hospital of their choice and have the full options available to them?

A Government that removes all the incentive for younger Australians to maintain private insurance, with the consequent pricing out of others, must bear full responsibility for the inevitable collapse of Medicare. When elderly Australians cannot get elective surgery in such areas as hip replacement that will allow them to remain living independently, inevitably they end up in nursing homes or hospitals. Sadly, this costs the taxpayer even more. I do not criticise the elderly for wanting a lot of the surgery that is now capable of being done. It is to their benefit and it is to the benefit of all Australians to ensure that those who need that type of surgery can get it and continue to live independently. Early in March it was pointed out by a geriatric specialist at the Gairdner Hospital that the policy of this same Labor Government has created a serious shortage of nursing home beds in the western suburbs of Perth, with its growing elderly population. In the catchment areas for the Gairdner and Osborne park hospitals there were 59 nursing home beds per 1,000 population over 70, compared with 97 for the Royal Perth Hospital catchment area further east. In the western suburbs, 174 beds had been closed, with 44 more closures pending.

Where are we heading? The situation is getting worse and worse. Yet, only the week before last, Senator Tate, the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, said that he did not have a clue what would happen. The end result is 30 elderly patients with the choice of remaining in their public hospital beds or moving to a nursing home in Midland, a considerable distance away. The bureaucratic inflexibility of the Hawke Labor Government in this related area of health care worsens the Medicare mess in our public hospitals, with valuable beds occupied by those with nowhere else to go.

Pharmacists and others who last year had dealings with the Minister for Housing and Aged Care would not be surprised to learn that the specialist, in writing three letters to the Minister, received but one fatuous reply to his suggestions of improved consultations over this question. Clearly, the Minister did not even understand the question raised by the pharmacist. But then, when we look at the way in which the Minister conducted himself during the entire pharmacy debate last year, we should not be surprised at that either. He does not understand pharmacy or the problems of the aged; he does not understand many things. It is very sad and very tragic that this whole mess is now being put before us with no possible solutions.

I am convinced that the creative thinking that will be needed through the 1990s to tackle such problems as external debt, low productivity, declining availability of health care and the achievement of the essential balance between economic growth and protection of the environment will come only from John Hewson's coalition team.

Unfortunately I have run short of time. I would like to have discussed many environmental issues. During the next three years this Parliament will be faced with the challenge of maintaining a proper balance between the protection of the environment and the sustaining of economic growth, without which Australia will not be able to protect its heritage. Unfortunately, the Government once again saw fit to pander to a special interest group and therefore make sure that proper, thorough debate on the issue was stifled.

A clear distinction is emerging between those of us who believe that sound economic growth and environmental protection are interdependent and the dark green lobby, which denies this truth and the practicality of any solution that involves the free market. We are beginning to realise the authoritarian agenda of the dark green environmentalists, who in Tasmania want to preserve the environment even from bushwalkers-as you, Mr Acting Deputy President would be well aware, as this is happening in your State-and they want to eradicate introduced species of fauna, including trout, and destroy existing hydro-electric schemes so that a drained Lake Pedder becomes accessible only to a selfish, fanatical elite. I think there will be a big discussion about the environment and about economic growth, because Australia certainly needs to protect both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start my remarks in this debate as Senator Brownhill did-by picking up a copy of the Governor-General's Speech on the opening of Parliament. It was a well delivered speech but I am sure he did not write it; the Government wrote it. So any remarks I make are not a reflection on our Governor-General but a reflection on the Government. One would think that the Government would tell the truth at least in its publication at the opening of Parliament. But it did not take long for the Government to wander off the path. On the second line of the Governor-General's Speech-if one leaves out the words `honourable members of the Parliament of Australia'-we find a lie. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On 24 March, the Australian people gave to the Labor Government an historic and decisive fourth mandate . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—It was historic in that the Labor Government got up a fourth time, but the word `decisive' is what I want to discuss. Even Senator Tate would agree that the words `decisive fourth mandate' are questionable.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the results of the election. I have a publication here put out by a government agency which states that the percentage of first preference votes for 1990 showed that nationally the Australian Labor Party scored 39.44 per cent while the coalition scored 43.19 per cent. In my State of Western Australia the Liberals alone scored 43.91 per cent and the National Party of Australia scored 2.42 per cent, giving a total of 46.33 per cent. Having got that result of 46.33 per cent, and on a two-party preferred basis we scored about 51.7 per cent, one would think that we would have held at least half of the seats in Western Australia. There are 14 seats in Western Australia, the latest being Pearce, which was well won by former Senator Fred Chaney. The Government finished up holding eight seats and the coalition six.

On those figures one would think that we would be somewhere near holding government; but lo and behold, Labor still has a 10-seat majority. In the days when Bjelke-Petersen was winning elections with 39 or 40 per cent of the vote, what did they call him? Using these figures, there is no way in the world that the Government could have written a speech like this saying that it had a decisive fourth mandate. It should have just left it as being an historic win and that is all.

What is decisive about the results? The minor parties had a lot to do with this election. I am pleased to note that the Australian Democrats scored their worst result in Western Australia. Perhaps the voters of Western Australia judged them as they should have judged them. The Greens also had quite an influence in the election by their preferences. The Greens' and Democrats' preferences held this Government in office. Those two minor groups were able to make all the promises they wanted because they did not have to deliver. Only two parties can deliver on the promises they make and they are the Labor Party and the Liberal-National coalition. The ones in between can deliver nothing.

It will be interesting to see how many of the Government's promises will be delivered, in light of the state of the economy, over the next three years-if this Parliament lasts that long. Probably not all of us will be here at the end of those three years for one reason or another, hopefully not because of misfortune. The voters of Kingston in South Australia, which is the House of Representatives seat the former Leader of the Australian Democrats ran for, obviously did their figures. They questioned and obviously costed the Democrats' promises because the result did not come out the way the Democrats had expected. The present Australian Government did win, but certainly not decisively.

A lot of comments were made in the Governor-General's Speech and I would like to pick up one of them, and that is, the Government wants Australia to be the clever country as well as the lucky country. I believe that this country is not clever at present because it is the country of lost opportunities. It is quite the opposite of a clever country. We have lost competitiveness with our overseas trading partners. I am afraid to say that we have lost the pride to work. We have lost industries-the Sarich industry is a good example-to other countries. If productivity has not declined it certainly has not improved. Australian industries have been selectively assisted, as in the Kodak affair. I want to see Australia become a clever country, but it has been anything but clever.

The primary and resource industries are the only ones keeping Australia afloat at present, yet they were hardly mentioned during the election. The primary and resource industries still have a bright future. I know that there are problems in certain industries. The wool industry is probably the one that has the biggest problem at present though this is not quite so evident to Australians during the election. Those involved in the wool industry were raising concerns 18 months ago about the problem of the high reserve in our wool market. I do not intend to enter into a debate on the marketing system right now because we will debate that later in the week, but concern was expressed that there was not enough wool flowing through to the factories overseas and that too much was being stockpiled in Australia. With the right management of the Australian Wool Corporation and better marketing research, we will get the industry going again. It will probably take two to three years for the wool industry to return to its rightful place as Australia's largest export earner.

A few other things have contributed to the current position of the wool industry. Overproduction is one. We have roughly 22 million sheep too many in Australia at present. This has brought about a downturn in the wheat and cattle industries because farmers and pastoralists have turned to sheep rather than wheat and cattle. This will even out in time. One of the reasons that the sheep population has grown so much in the last three to five years is that we have not had a king-sized drought. I do not wish that on any of the agricultural areas of Australia, but we have to expect one because in time they come back to haunt us. However, I can still see a bright future in the primary and resource industries.

The economy did not play a big enough part in the Federal election. For the last 18 months the coalition has been propounding in this place and in other places that the economy was not quite right, though the Labor Government obviously convinced enough voters in the last election that what it was saying was right. Although the coalition was propounding this, no-one was taking any notice. In fact, the Government was doing its best to make sure that no notice was taken. It is peculiar that on the Monday after the election everything was revealed-not quite everything, but Senator Walsh let the cat out of the bag. This is not the only election in which that has happened. There was a similar fiasco after the Western Australian State election of 1989. The coalition told the media and everyone else that there were problems in Western Australia with Western Australia Inc. No-one wanted to believe this. The Government said, `Look to the future. Don't look behind'. One always says `look to the future' when one does not want to look behind. Within weeks all was revealed. With the Federal Government, as time goes on, more and more is being revealed.

So where does the problem lie in this matter? I do not blame the Government for covering up its misdemeanours and misquotes or for simply getting its figures wrong, but when we were propounding and questioning there was one section of the community that certainly did not help us-that is, the media. During the Federal campaign, as in the State campaign in Western Australia the media questioned the credibility of our leaders. They questioned the credibility of Andrew Peacock and the credibility of our Leader in Western Australia, Barry MacKinnon.

Instead of questioning what the Government was doing, the media made a big play of the supposed divisions within the Liberal Party and any divisions, if there were any, between the Liberal Party and the National Party. The media did not make a play of the divisions that existed in the Ministry of the Hawke Labor Government. There was Senator Button, Senator Richardson and Mr Kerin, all of whom probably did know what they were about and who were concerned about the situation, but there were some divisions with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and some Ministers against each other.

But the media failed to expose that. All the media were interested in was Andrew Peacock's credibility. Of course, as the results showed, the media convinced enough people that Andrew Peacock may have lacked credibility. But when Senator Walsh took the lid off, on the following Monday there for everyone to see was the fact that what Andrew Peacock was saying, and what we were saying, was correct.

I move on to what has to be done and what reforms the Government intends to undertake in the next three years, as mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech. The Government has reforms, which we have needed for a long time, high on its list of priorities, or so the Government tells us. The Governor-General's speech referred to the waterfront, telecommunications, land transport and coastal shipping. Of course we need reforms in all these areas, but we need them sooner rather than later. Although the Government has a rather slender majority after the last election, I fear that it may take things fairly easily and slowly on the reform that is so badly needed to get us into a position to compete with our trading partners. I refer especially to waterfront reform, having regard to the Inter-State Commission report that was brought down and which we discussed in this Parliament last year, for which the Government has formulated a package. The Government now seems to be slightly on the side of delay, but the waterside workers themselves are urging the Government to get on with it because of the package that they have been offered. If I may say so, it is a rather good package for the waterside workers; hence, I can see why they want to get it.

The report brought down cited the average age of our waterside workers around Australia as 57; it would be now 58. If the Government delays introducing these reforms, these people will get older and older when at this time they are anxious to take their packages and get out, and let younger people come in with new ideas and get things moving.

Telecommunications needs reform. We need some competition. One can see for oneself that because of Telecom Australia's monopoly, the average cost of a simple car phone is around $2,000 whereas overseas, including New Zealand, the cost is $100 or $200. That is why competition is needed.

Land transport also needs to be treated with haste. Road systems around Australia are breaking down, as I have said many times in this place, mainly due to a lack of funding. But our road system is also breaking down due to an increase in the amount of traffic on it. Other kinds of transport should be used, such as shipping and rail. Coastal shipping has also got to be addressed quickly, for the reasons I have given.

I now come to railways. The Government has mentioned what it intends doing in the next three years in that area. Australian railways have to be updated, but Australian National has to be worked on the most. I have believed for a long time that all the capital cities of Australia should be connected by a standard gauge railway controlled by Australian National. All capital cities are connected by the standard gauge, except for Adelaide and Melbourne, but standard gauge trains can go via Sydney. The point has certainly arrived in history when we have to operate one system between the capital cities and update the wagons and locomotives and the way that the system is operating, so that locos and crews do not have to be changed five times between Sydney and Perth, or whatever they do, and the cost of rail freights can be reduced so that rail can once again compete with road. There is no way on this earth that road transport should be able to compete with rail between Sydney and Perth or Melbourne and Perth. It is absolutely ridiculous and the problem has got to be addressed.
My last point relates to migration. I believe that in a downturn of the economy-I will refer to a downturn rather than a recession, or whatever the economists argue it is--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is next week.

—That is next week. I believe that migration, whether in this climate or not, should always be suited to what Australia needs at a particular time. I believe that the accent on migration, especially at the present moment, should be on areas in which migrants are needed. Over the last so many years, migrants to Australia have been going mainly to the populous areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, some populous areas can do with a certain number of migrants, but 140,000 to 150,000 migrants a year are moving into areas of high unemployment. It is all right for professionals, who can get jobs, or business migrants who set up businesses, to move into those areas, but far too many migrants are going into those populous areas where housing, which is already tight, has to be provided, or where land has to be provided for that housing, in addition to all the support structures needed for those people, whereas parts of the country cannot fill their work vacancies. We have that much unemployment in the cities that some migrants finish up on the unemployment benefit.

Australia has to address this matter. Senator Walsh has pointed out that a yearly increase in gross domestic product of one or 2 per cent is needed to make up for the 140,000 to 150,000 migrants coming to Australia every year.

I know, as Senator MacGibbon pointed out the other day that it is a bit hard to get people to work in areas in which they do not want to work. It is an Australian's right to work where he wants, but if workers want to live in an area where they cannot get a job, and they consciously do that, I believe that the Department of Social Security should not have to support them for the rest of their days. I believe that one should look for work where work is available.

I return to the question of migration. If people want to migrate to this great country of Australia, I believe that they should contribute something when they come here. Perhaps arrangements can be made, for people willing and prepared to work in remote areas, whereby something is built into the points system.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is there already. Are you saying that the points should be higher?
—They should be higher. We have a problem. The problem lies not only with machinery operators, labourers or others; it also concerns the professionals.

SPEECH.PARA: It was mentioned in this place last week that there is an oversupply of doctors in Sydney and Melbourne, yet I live in an area where it is very hard to keep a doctor. The only way we have kept doctors and kept up the health side of the area in the last 10 or 15 years is, thankfully, by getting Asian doctors who have come over and are prepared to work in these remote areas for a friend. We have had an Australian doctor for only 12 months during the last 20 years. He chose to go back to Queensland, which was his right. The only way we were able to replace him was, once again, by looking for an Asian migrating doctor.

There are other areas. The pharmacy area is the same. Then there are remote industries. Iron ore industry operators have been supplied, mainly by the New Zealand labour that comes over. The grain industry has been helped out by United Kingdom migrants-farm workers that come out here on 12-month working visas. On we go.

Migration should work as to make sure that those industries in those remote areas are assisted to keep their work forces full. Some of the remote areas are not all as remote as the Pilbara, the Kimberleys or whatever. They are places within a maximum of 300 kilometres of a capital city. The same goes for the gold industry, which has its own problems.

It is a stark reality that we on this side of the chamber are in opposition for the next three years, or whatever the term of the Parliament may be, but I am looking forward to working with my colleagues to make sure that we are on the other side next time. Just like after losing a grand final, especially one that we should have won, it is a bit hard to crank up next year. I had that experience in 1964, when my club was the hot favourite and did not quite get up. The year after it was a bit hard to get intensity up, but the side easily won the premiership the year after and if history repeats itself, that is what we will be doing the next time around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has looked, with as much dismay as, I suppose, most Australians have, on the brawling within this Government-not because of the brawling but because of the fact that after the election, for the first time, members of this Government have admitted the truth about the serious economic problems this Government has got us into.

SPEECH.PARA: That brawling is significant not simply because it represents a lack of discipline or an unprecedented departure from the traditions of Cabinet solidarity. It is far more important because of the fact that it not only reveals the Government's lack of will to correct the problems that so many members of the Government are now prepared to recognise publicly but also reveals, significantly, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has an impossibly short fuse and, therefore, does not possess the person management skills to be an effective Prime Minister and that this Government's economic policies have been in disarray because this Government is in disarray.

Previously, that disarray had been behind closed doors. All that has happened now is that it has become public. Now we see the brawling. Now we see the reasons why this Government has not undertaken the sorts of economic measures and has not followed the sort of economic management which are vitally needed in Australia and which this Opposition has been recommending to, and pressing upon, this Government for years.

I find it interesting that Ministers like the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) are prepared to say, after the election, the sorts of things they were not prepared to say before an election. In fact, this Ministry deceived the Australian people about the state of the economy. It deceived Australian people about what would happen over the next three years if a Labor Government were elected.

For the Ministers who are now suddenly finding-re-finding, for those who did have it before-some capacity in their personalities to tell the truth, the sudden discovery is extraordinarily timed. In fact, it is timed to meet their self-interest. We find the disputes that are emerging within this Government are related, perhaps, not necessarily to a sudden outbreak of honesty but to questions of self-interest and power struggles within this Labor Government. That cynicism which has prompted the admission of truth about the seriousness of our economic future, I believe, is something for which the Australian public will not forgive those Ministers.

It is all very well for Ministers like Senator Button to get up and say, `The differences between us are simply those of emphasis'. I think the Australian public can judge for themselves whether Mr Keating's extraordinarily vindictive assault-we do not know what goes on behind closed doors, I suppose, but I mean his verbal assault-on Senator Button was clearly part of a power struggle within the Australian Labor Party which relates to Mr Keating's unbridled --

TALK.START.PARA: —Alan Ward's article is probably another part of it-in Saturday's Australian.

—Yes, as Senator Newman says, it is probably another part of it. It clearly indicates that the power struggle for leadership within the Labor Party is incapable of being restrained once the discipline of coming towards an election has been removed.

SPEECH.PARA: We noted that, when I asked Senator Button last week whether he would resile from or regret any of the comments he made that prompted Mr Keating's savage attack, he said no, he did not resile from them. The comments I put to him were these: Senator Button said, `In the current economic downturn of some severity it is unrealistic to talk about rising living standards'. Senator Button did not resile from that. No-one said that sort of thing before the election. A clear governmental deception of the Australian people-that is, if Senator Button is now to be believed-took place before the election.

The second point he refused to resile from was, `The economic outlook for Australia over the next few years will be very difficult'. According to Mr Keating, before the election, everything was on track; recovery was on the way; the Government had the settings right; and, if I recall, he said that one set of appalling balance of payment figures were `pretty good numbers'. The third point that Senator Button refused to resile from was his comment: `Opportunities for micro-economic reform in Labor's third term were lost and time has to be made up'.

Quite frankly, I agree with all of those points that Senator Button has made. I commend him for making them. I am appalled that he did not have the desire to be as honest before the election. Let us have a look at how significant these--

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't want you to get too upset, Senator.

—I am glad that Senator Button does not want me to get too upset. I ask him, then, whether he will give us an undertaking that he will display the same honesty before the next election as he displayed post-election now. That is an interesting challenge, and I offer it to Senator Button.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the great achievements of Senator Button's adversary, the Treasurer. I must say that by commending Senator Button, I am by implication saying that Mr Keating has led us into an economic disaster and that the policies that he has implemented have deepened and worsened Australia's economic position, despite the fact that he was rescued partially by an unprecedented increase, an unexpected increase, in our terms of trade which has prevented a much more disastrous situation hitting Australia.
Today in the Australian Financial Review David Clark has a reasonably sound analysis of `the world's greatest Treasurer'. He asks us to look at the achievements of Paul Keating. He says:
Consider the evidence.
Firstly, the state of the economy. Australia currently has:
An inflation rate more than double the average of our major trading partners and up to three times as high as that in those economies to our north with whom we are trying to compete.
The highest mortgage rates in the Western world.
Lending rates to business up to three times as high as those in most similar economies.
Wage growth 1.5 to two times that of similar economies.

One of the highest gross debt interest payments to export income ratios-over 20 per cent-outside of Latin America and Eastern Europe and one of the highest principal plus interest payments of export income ratios anywhere.
Over the 1980s, Mr Keating was quick to put the boot into any commentators who doubted his Budget forecasts but how many treasurers in Australian history have a record like his 1988-89 one?
Take his current account deficit forecast for 1988-89. The forecast was for a CAD of $9.5 billion. The outcome was a mere $17.4 billion.
As a percentage of GDP, the CAD was forecast to be only 3.0 per cent. The outcome was 5.2 per cent-
Almost double-
As a percentage of GDP, only Thatcher's Britain had a CAD as bad as this in the advanced world.
Mr Clark goes on:

Note that Mr Keating's overall forecasts were far worse than expected, even though our terms of trade . . . were far more favourable than expected. The forecast was for a 9.0 per cent improvement; the outcome was a 15.6 per cent one.
Mr Clark goes on:

. . . Mr Keating has proven himself to be the greatest media manager in Australian political history. Look at the army of commentators, editorialists, and economics editors who believed that the J-curve would come to our rescue--

I might say that the Opposition continually said that it would not, and the Opposition once again was totally right. It is about time some of those hot-shot economic commentators recognised that the people who have been consistently right in the economic debate have been those in the Opposition-and ever since we have been in Opposition. It is the Treasurer who has created this atmosphere, created this situation which Australia now faces, as Senator Button says, a very difficult economic outlook-an economic downturn of some severity.
Mr Keating assured us all in 1988 that we had finally solved our foreign debt and current account problems. All the economic commentators said, `Yes, he is a very clever fellow'. Mr Clark goes on:
. . . Mr Keating told us that the replacement of a large Budget deficit with large Budget surpluses would guarantee a significant and permanent fall in interest rates and our current account deficit.
Look at what has happened: we have record interest rates and a disastrous current account deficit, which is forecast to continue for quite some time. Mr Clark concludes:
In short, Australia has never had a politician with such blind faith in simple Economics I style geometry and with such ability to pass on such a faith to the media.

Frankly, it is more than time that the media recognised that its faith was misplaced. The Opposition has been calling for a long time for major corrections to the Government's economic policy, in particular, in micro-economic reform. The Treasurer stated that Government Ministers, particularly Senator Button, should be lifting their ambitions for a change-not just talking about actually getting them done. I suppose that when one looks at Senator Button's achievements one can understand Mr Keating's impatience. What we have to recognise is this: the power struggle between these two men over the pace of economic reform and the nature of economic reform has been going on for years.

I refer Senator Button-I am glad to see him at the table-to our debate on the Industry Commission Bill of 5 December last year in which I dealt with the fact that Mr Keating stole control of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) away from Senator Button, over Senator Button's dead body in the Cabinet, because he clearly did not want Senator Button to have control of the micro-economic reform inputs that the IAC was responsible for. In fact, we had lots of stories in the media about how the IAC had been a flop under Senator Button and that Mr Keating was going to put it right. In fact, what Mr Keating did was to try to kill off the IAC.

I have to say that Senator Button did a far better job with the IAC than did Mr Keating. We can see by looking at the IAC report for last year just what Mr Keating did to destroy this vital element in our trying to fix up what was wrong with the Australian economy. In the last year in which Senator Button was the `responsible Minister', the IAC received 10 references from him. In both the years that Mr Keating was responsible the number of references was five-exactly half the work load that Senator Button had got the IAC to do in this vital area of micro-economic reform.

We can see the extent to which it was running down, and being run down, because in the last year in which Senator Button was responsible 11 reports were completed by the IAC. By last year Mr Keating had run it down to four-almost a third of the number of reports presented by Senator Button. Of course, Senator Button is the Minister who Mr Keating says is not pulling his weight in terms of micro-economic reform.

We can see that these personality battles between Senator Button and Mr Keating are one of the reasons why this Government has been unable to come up with coherent micro-economic reforms. The IAC's effectiveness was not only blunted; its staff disappeared and its leader left. As was stated in the article in the Business Review Weekly by Chris Wallace:
The IAC suffered a prolonged period of drift after Keating took it from Senator John Button's Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce . . . after the 1987 election.

I stress that the Industries Assistance Commission had a vitally significant role in restructuring this country. But, as a result of deliberate Government policy, it was put into the political wilderness for the last two years. Chris Wallace went on to say:

Initially, Keating pursued his micro-economic reform program without much recourse to IAC resources. Perceptions of the Commission's power and significance slid as it was obviously bypassed in the policy-making process, and many good staff left.

This was all as a result of these battles between Mr Keating and Senator Button extending over two years. That is the important point. It is no wonder that the Government cannot get its reform package right when the Ministers themselves cannot agree and when they fight over the mechanisms and who should control them, the mechanisms that are supposed to be an important part of this reform.

It is not as if just the Opposition has been calling for a better job by the Government. Since the beginning of this year the following organisations and institutions have called for significant policy changes: the Reserve Bank, the Business Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Bureau of Industry Economics, various State employer organisations, including the Victorian Employers Federation and the Queensland Employers Federation and leading members of the Government. The Australian Labor Party, including Senator Button, Mr Dawkins and the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has also called for significant policy changes. Where are they? When is the Government going to tell us what it is going to do?

So far we have had a clear indication from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday 12 May that one of the people vitally involved in this micro-economic reform of getting Australia's costs down, of getting us on the right track, is already preparing his excuses for failure. I am referring to Senator Bob Collins. In that article Senator Collins agreed with some wharfies he saw that it was not good enough to look at the wharves when looking at things that have to be done to correct our balance of payments problems. The article states:
Collins said later: `I got it delivered to me right between the eyes, there and then on the wharves of Melbourne. And, of course, they're right.'
What are they right about? They are saying it is not fixing up the wharves that matters; it is a whole lot of other things. Of waterfront reform Senator Collins says:
`The thing about waterfront reform is there always has to be a sexy issue in politics.
That issue becomes the benchmark in measuring the success or failure of the Government . . .
Senator Collins went on to say:
. . . during our last term, interest rates and overseas debt became the issues. Now these have translated into the new catchcry of micro-economic reform.
`You see, it's very easy to understand, it's also easy for the Government's opponents to exploit. It's a highly visible issue-
that is, reform of the wharves-
to measure success or failure by. And yes, of course it's silly to think waterfront reform is the be-all and end-all of getting our balance of payments right.
He then tries to downgrade the significance of waterfront reform by saying:
. . . reform of broadcasting, the issue of foreign ownership of television, the question of Telecom's monopoly-all those are potentially more important to micro-economic reform . . .

That is just incredible. Unless we fix up these basic elements that affect the costs of exporting and, in particular, reform of the wharves we face an economic disaster. Yet here is Senator Collins trying to downplay the significance of it by saying that it is not of all that much consequence, and trying to suggest that the current wool issue is far more important than the fundamental one of fixing up the costs of exports. I was intrigued to see that Alan Ramsey, who wrote this article, went along with that view. He said:

. . . Australia's current account deficit is still going sour at the rate of $1.9 billion a month . . . By comparison, reform of the waterfront will mean annual estimated savings of some $620 million a year.

This was clearly an attempt, no doubt assisted by Senator Collins, to say, `Look, waterfront reform is only minor compared to the big problem'. Let me stress to Senator Collins that the extraordinarily unnecessary costs, $620m a year, that is added to the costs of our exports is pricing them out of our markets.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, will be absent from the chamber today on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Richardson in relation to his own portfolio should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Will the Government agree to a joint Commonwealth-State royal commission, called for by both the Government and Labor Opposition in New South Wales, to investigate the activities of the Mafia in the terms agreed by the New South Wales Parliament, that is, the involvement of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the New South Wales Police with the Mafia in the illegal growing of marijuana crops in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales and in the Brindabella Ranges in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT); corruption involving the cultivation and distribution of marijuana in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and, in particular, the Griffith area; and the relationship of all the above with the death of Assistant Federal Police Commissioner Winchester, and related allegations of police corruption and any commonality of personal interests involved therein?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is, of course, aware of the resolution passed in the New South Wales Parliament and has also received a letter from the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Nick Greiner, concerning this matter and embodying his call for a royal commission to be supported by both the Federal and New South Wales governments. I think honourable senators will be able to accept readily that the Government has no desire whatsoever to sweep any matters under the carpet and, through various mechanisms, has taken the matters surrounding the growing of marijuana in this country extremely seriously.

ANSWER.PARA: The real issue, I believe, is not whether the matters raised by Mr Hatton have needed or do need investigating but, rather, the most productive way to proceed from this point onwards. I think it is important to reiterate some of the points I have made in answers from time to time, both last May and again in this session, about what has happened and is happening in regard to these particular plantations and the involvement of the so-called Mafia.

Firstly, of course, honourable senators will be aware that Mr Ron Cahill, the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate for the ACT, has been conducting since August 1989 possibly the most comprehensive and detailed coronial inquest ever held in this country to determine the cause and manner of death of Assistant Commissioner Winchester. Mr Cahill has already indicated that he will be examining the relationship of Operation Seville to Mr Winchester's death, commencing in the middle of next month.

Honourable senators, and particularly Senator Hill, would be aware also that since 30 May 1986 the National Crime Authority has had a national reference, codenamed Vigilante, into the Mafia and its activities in Australia. Since that reference commenced it has preferred 641 charges against 103 people. Honourable senators will recall that, in relation to Operation Seville, some 11 persons were subject to committal proceedings-the Queanbeyan proceedings-and, though no prosecutions followed, the magistrate himself indicated, as I have, that this was due chiefly to the failure of an indemnified witness to live up to the undertakings he had given.

As I have advised the Senate previously-in fact, last May-the National Crime Authority has investigated Australian Federal Police involvement in Operation Seville and concluded that there was no evidence of criminality involved. It did recommend to the Commissioner of the AFP that appropriate disciplinary action be taken, and I am advised that that was indeed undertaken. I should also point out that all police forces around Australia have made significant seizures and arrests in relation to marijuana cultivation and distribution over the past 10 years.

Given that background let me return to the coroner's inquiry into the death of Mr Winchester. No-one can deny that it is a serious and detailed public inquiry. Indeed, Mr Cahill is leaving no stone unturned in his examination of all matters likely to have some relevance to Mr Winchester's death. A number of people, including Mr Hatton, have claimed that the Coroner has insufficient powers adequately to undertake his task, which is to determine the manner and cause of Mr Winchester's death. But, of course, an Australian Capital Territory coroner can summons persons' papers, can call persons to answer questions on oath and grant a certificate which renders admissions of self-crimination of a person inadmissible against that person in a subsequent criminal trial. In addition, the Director of Public Prosecutions has a general power to give undertakings that evidence given in proceedings will not be used in criminal or civil proceedings.

Since this very thorough process, bearing directly upon the concerns expressed in New South Wales by the Parliament, and the Premier, is already under way, it is the Government's view, after careful consideration, that the coroner's inquiry should be allowed to run its course rather than that we duplicate this with a totally new mode of investigation-a royal commission. I do, however, give this Government's commitment that if at the end of Mr Cahill's inquiry there are remaining issues or if new issues come to light they will be investigated. If, in our view, that requires a royal commission, that is what we shall have, but at this stage that requirement is not clear. In the fight against organised crime Federal cooperation with the States and Territories is vital. We welcome the New South Wales Government's willingness to cooperate and we reciprocate that willingness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the Minister for his answer. I ask him a supplementary question: Does he not accept that the coronial inquiry by Mr Cahill is limited to matters relating to the death of Mr Winchester whereas the inquiry called for by the New South Wales Parliament-the Government and the Opposition-goes far beyond the scope of the coronial inquiry, including, as I said, into matters involving corruption, the cultivation and distribution of marijuana in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, and in particular the Griffith area, and generally speaking into the activities of the Mafia and organised crime in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have indicated that the coronial inquiry does have a specific object, that is, to find, if possible, who is responsible for the death of Colin Winchester. It is an inquiry into the manner and cause of his death. It will be very clear to honourable senators, and indeed to the whole Australian population, that Mr Cahill has adopted a very exhaustive examination of all matters which might have any bearing on the manner and cause of Mr Winchester's death and has indicated his desire to undertake a complete examination of the relevance, if any, of the matters loosely titled the Seville matters to Mr Winchester's death, and that will commence next month.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also indicated, as to the broader issues which Senator Hill refers to, that the National Crime Authority has been undertaking, under the Vigilante reference, a very exhaustive examination of precisely those matters-the Mafia and its activities in Australia, particularly in relation to the cultivation of marijuana crops and their distribution. It is in that situation, where there are two different types of inquiry under way, with different rules of evidence and objectives--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a public inquiry.

—Indeed, that is a major distinction. The Government has indicated that if, at the end of the coronial inquest, further matters need examination, the question of whether one goes down the route of a public inquiry or a royal commission is one that we will very seriously consider. But, this Parliament, indeed this chamber, was most insistent on setting up the National Crime Authority precisely to avoid the recurrence of royal commissions, which hold their hearings in public, so there would be a continuing royal commission, if you like, conducting its inquiries in private, which is the National Crime Authority. The Parliament-indeed the Senate-insisted on that distinction and therefore it would be a very grave matter to undertake a royal commission. Naturally, we will, as I have said, await the end of the coronial inquest before we decide whether a royal commission is warranted.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to an article which appeared in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Runway EIS Firm May bid for Work'. The article quotes Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd director, Mr Bill Woodhead, as suggesting that Kinhill was likely to tender for some engineering work on the third runway. In the light of these statements, and the very serious concerns of the many people who stand to be affected, can the Minister give an unequivocal guarantee of the integrity of the environmental impact statement being undertaken into the proposed third runway for Sydney Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give that guarantee. I did note the article in the Sydney Morning Herald and indeed the adjournment debate speech from Mr Punch in the House of Representatives last week. The fact is that the processes that were adopted in appointing Kinhill were proper and scrupulous. The thing is, of course, that the number of companies in Australia that are capable, that have the engineering and other professional resources available to conduct an investigation of this complexity, is very limited. It would be fair to say that most, if not all, of them would have the potential for having a role to play at least in tendering for a work, in an engineering sense, on an airport because that is where their expertise lies. Kinhill has a very high reputation in this regard and in fact was responsible for the environmental impact statement (EIS) work and site location work on behalf of the Government when Badgerys Creek was selected in 1985.

ANSWER.PARA: The comments that have been made are not surprising. It is traditional for this to happen. Certainly from considerable experience, I know that prior to the release of an environmental impact statement all of the parties involved in the matter, particularly those on the anti-side of whatever particular development is being investigated, position themselves prior to the release of the document. That is precisely what is happening now. There is no great front page news attached to that.

On the current timetable, the EIS will be released on 31 July. But all of these comments entirely miss the mark, of course, in respect of the credibility of the result. The environmental impact statement will stand or fall on its own merits. As I say, Kinhill has a well-established reputation that I am sure it is not likely to put at risk by producing a flawed document. As I explained in the Senate last week in response to another question on this issue, the reason for the delay in the production of the EIS is the need to conduct scrupulously further investigations, particularly in the area of potential noise problems at Sydney airport. That is being done.

In concluding this answer, it might be instructive to remind the Senate of the process. When the document is produced on 31 July, it will be subjected to an intense period of three months scrutiny which in fact is in excess of the statutory requirements. It will be a very open process indeed. The Government has bent over backwards to ensure that the process will be as open and effective as possible in that it will be providing $100,000 to parties that have a close interest in the third runway to ensure that the EIS will be subjected to the most rigorous scrutiny.

At the end of that time the proponents will prepare a response to those objections. Those responses and the original draft will go to the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. That will result in the responsible Minister, Mrs Kelly, sending to me any comments or recommendations that she has on the final EIS before I make a decision as to whether the runway will go ahead.
Therefore it can be seen that all of these side issues that are being raised, predictably enough, at this time are side issues. The credibility of the EIS will stand or fall on the document itself.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY: KNOWLEDGE OF DEATH THREATS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and relates to the National Crime Authority (NCA) and its knowledge of death threats. I refer to the failure of the National Crime Authority to inform Mr John Hatton, a member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, of a death threat against him in 1980 which it allegedly became aware of in 1987. Given the likelihood that the conspirators are still around and given Mr Hatton's continuing interest in organised crime, does the Minister condone the NCA's excuse that it did not feel obliged to inform Mr Hatton of the threat because of the historical nature of that threat? Does the Minister consider that this is an acceptable practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that if any person in Australia is subjected to a death threat and a competent authority can make an assessment of that threat and pass on knowledge of it, that should be done. Particularly where a person as prominent as Mr Hatton has taken certain risks in exposing his knowledge of the activities of organised crime in Australia, then that sort of threat, if it has any basis, ought to be made known to him as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: There are many of us who are subjected to such threats and I believe that it is extremely important, not only for the person concerned but for the family and others, that measures be taken as soon as possible once a proper assessment of the threat is undertaken. So, in answer to Senator Vanstone, I do believe that such threats ought to be notified to the person concerned as speedily as possible and the National Crime Authority, in my view, should have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in the light of the Minister's answer, I ask a supplementary question. Did the National Crime Authority know of any death threats against Commissioner Winchester and, if so, were they communicated to the Commissioner?
—I have no knowledge of that particular matter.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate of the outcome of the meeting in Nigeria last week of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa so far as the question of sanctions is concerned? Is there any support for the view being promoted in Europe in recent days by President De Klerk that now is the appropriate time for sanctions to be relaxed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most important outcome of the meeting which I attended in Nigeria last week was a very strong recommitment made there by the Commonwealth to maintaining sanctions against South Africa until such time as there is clear and irreversible evidence of profound change in the apartheid system, not just the hope or the promise of such change. The Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on South Africa is comprised of representatives of nine countries; Joe Clark, the Canadian Foreign Minister, is chairman and Australia is a member. There are two members from Asia-Malaysia and India; four Foreign Ministers from Africa-Zambia, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Nigeria; and one from the Caribbean. So it is a very representative group. I think it is fair to say that the views of this group stand for those of the Commonwealth as a whole, with the conspicuous exception of one country, the United Kingdom, which, of course, continues to take a very different view about sanctions.

ANSWER.PARA: That meeting had the benefit of a quite substantial dialogue with Nelson Mandela who made very clear the African National Congress's concern and its assessment of the situation that continued pressure is necessary if the very welcome progress that was made a few days ago at Groote Schuur is, in fact, going to be maintained. The Committee was concerned that, as a result of the charm offensive-I suppose it can be described-of President De Klerk and, to a lesser extent, of his Foreign Minister, Pik Botha, in Europe in recent days, there is a view going around that the battle against apartheid is essentially won, or at least won enough to justify the resumption of commercial contacts between these countries and Southern Africa. With that in mind--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what is being said. Perhaps now he should be given some encouragement.

—Yes, Senator Hill can put it in those terms if he likes and I will respond to that. Faced with expressions of this kind, the Committee wrote to European Community (EC) foreign Ministers and, to the extent that they are not caught up in that, other members of the Group of Seven, to put the case in favour of the continued application of sanctions. On Friday last week I delivered that letter to the current EC President, Ireland, which was very timely because there has been a meeting over the last couple of days of all the EC foreign Ministers. I will incorporate the full text of that letter in Hansard for the information of honourable senators.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make, as quickly as I can, some of the central points in it because they go to the heart of the present debate about the applicability of sanctions. The point that we made is this: while this may be a time of unprecedented opportunity in South Africa, it is not yet a time of change. Not one of the fundamental pillars of apartheid has, after all, yet been dismantled. The Constitution itself has not yet been rewritten. Nelson Mandela has been released from prison but he is still denied the vote in his own land. The Population Registration Act, which classifies everyone by race at birth, remains wholly intact and its repeal is not in immediate prospect. The Group Areas Act, which determines where those of different race may live, remains fully in force with no timetable set for its repeal. The Lands Acts which underpin the whole indefensible Bantustan system, also remain unrepealed and unamended. Even the foreshadowed repeal of the Separate Amenities Act, which goes to determining access to facilities on the basis of race, has not yet been accomplished, although it may well be within the next few weeks.

Moreover, nor have the preliminary obstacles to substantive negotiations been removed. I am talking about the obstacles that have been identified as such by the Commonwealth and by the United Nations. Only a very small fraction of political prisoners have been released and the immunity from prosecution of returning exiles has not yet been guaranteed. Troops do remain in the townships and the State of Emergency remains in force. Other legislation such as the Internal Security Act, which is designed to circumscribe political activity, remains unrepealed.

Finally, despite the lifting of bans and restrictions on individuals and organisations which occurred on 2 February, repression does continue. According to South Africa's own Human Rights Commission, 324 people were being held under the State of Emergency as of the first week of May, with a further 74 detained under internal security and other legislation. Of course, it is the case that hundreds of people have been wounded and over 100 killed in confrontations with police since 2 February.

There may come a time, and we all hope it will be sooner rather than later, when substantive change has occurred, clearly and irreversibly, and when it would be appropriate to consider easing some of the external pressure that helped bring that change about. The very strongly held view of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers, reinforced by our close consultation with Nelson Mandela and others, is that that time for considering such action simply has not yet arrived. We understand but we do not accept the argument that good intentions should themselves be rewarded. We also understand but do not accept on the basis of the evidence before us the suggestion that white South Africans would be encouraged to accept necessary fundamental change by relieving them now of the economic and psychological pressure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. One of the reasons that we have had a very large number of questions in the course of the last two weeks is that you have asked the Ministers to confine their answers. Senator Evans in giving his answer has now reached the seven minute mark. He is also incorporating the text of a letter in order to inform honourable senators of the substance of the matters which he is now further canvassing. As you would know, this is a matter of some very considerable importance to a large number of senators and a very important subject which would be worthy of a ministerial statement at the very least. I do ask that you should require Senator Evans to comply with what his colleagues have been doing in his absence and heed your ruling to give succinct answers and not make statements.
—I had concluded my answer, Mr President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order, but I will remind Ministers that I have asked them to keep their answers as short as possible. Is leave granted for the text of the letter to be incorporated in Hansard?

INTERJECT.PARA: Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa

Current developments in South Africa give us all grounds for optimism that, after decades of tragic oppression and injustice, the end of apartheid and the creation of a genuine non-racial democracy may at last be in sight.

We know that you will share our view that the international community, which has so long condemned the evils of apartheid in both work and deed, has a continuing responsibility to encourage the process of reconciliation and democratic reconstruction that may be now beginning.

We write to convey our clear and firm view, as Commonwealth representatives, that such encouragement should not at this time take the form of lifting or modifying any of the sanctions against South Africa now in place.
While this is a time of unprecedented opportunity, it is not yet a time of change. Not one of the fundamental pillars of apartheid has yet been dismantled:
the Constitution has not yet been rewritten: Nelson Mandela has been released from prison, but is still denied the vote in his own land;
the Population Registration Act, classifying everyone by race at birth, remains wholly intact, and its repeal is not in immediate prospect;
the Group Areas Act, which determines where those of different race may live, remains fully in force, with no timetable set for its repeal;
the Lands Acts, underpinning the whole indefensible Bantustan system, also remains unrepealed and unamended; and
the foreshadowed repeal of the Separate Amenities Act, determining access to facilities on the basis of race, has not yet been accomplished.
Nor, moreover, have even the preliminary obstacles to substantive negotiations-identified as such by the United Nations-been removed:
only a small fraction of political prisoners have been released, and the immunity from prosecution of returning exiles has not yet been guaranteed;
troops remain in the townships and the State of Emergency remains in force; and
other legislation, like the Internal Security Act, designed to circumscribe political activity, remains unrepealed.
Despite the lifting of bans and restrictions on individuals and organisations on 2 February, repression continues:

according to the Human Rights Commission in South Africa, 324 people were being held under the State of Emergency as of 9 May 1990, with a further 74 detained under internal security and other legislation; and
hundreds of people have been wounded, and over 100 killed, in confrontations with police since 2 February.

There may come a time, and we all hope it will be sooner rather than later, when substantive change has occurred-clearly and irreversibly-and when it would be appropriate to consider easing some of the external pressure that has helped bring that change about.

But our strongly held view, reinforced by our close consultations this week with Nelson Mandela and other leaders of the opposition forces in South Africa, is that the time for considering such action has not yet arrived. We understand, but do not accept, the argument that demonstrably good intentions should be rewarded. We also understand, but do not accept, the suggestion that white South Africans will be encouraged to accept necessary fundamental change by relieving them now from some of the economic and psychological pressures so manifestly still pressing upon them.

We believe rather, on all the evidence before us, that the way to advance the process of normalisation and democratisation in South Africa is to maintain intact the full range of sanctions now applying; to reduce that pressure, before any of the necessary changes of substance have yet occurred, would be to run a very grave risk of aborting that process.
Nelson Mandela made the point to us this week, dramatically and forcefully, in the following terms:

``We call upon you, in your capacities as representatives of conscientious governments and peoples, as representatives of concerned and sovereign states, to impress upon your governments, and those governments you could influence, to halt and reverse the effort to untimely and wrongly lift sanctions against the South African Government. If this trend is not stopped all our gains will be reversed''.

We can only echo his words, and ask you to give them every possible weight, in the days and weeks ahead, in your own Government's consideration of how to respond to the rapidly unfolding developments in South Africa.
The Hon Mr Hari Kishore Singh
The Hon Alhaji Dr Rilwanu Lukman

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the President of the Senate. Is it a fact that the Department of Administrative Services is able to provide to electoral officers letterhead stationery on recycled paper? Is it also a fact that recycled paper is available through the Department of the House of Representatives?
