Is it a fact that recycled paper is not available through the Department of the Senate for the use of senators? If this is so, when will the situation be remedied?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that neither the Department of the Senate nor the Department of the House of Representatives uses recycled paper as a matter of course. Both Departments have tried all of the available recycled paper to test its effect on printing and photocopying equipment. The cost of recycled paper is 20 to 30 per cent higher than the cost of paper made from virgin pulp. If 100 per cent recycled paper were to be used, the Department's annual appropriations would need to be increased by $45,000. If 80 per cent recycled paper was used, an additional $14,000 would be required.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Department of Administrative Services has advised that recycled papers are not generally recommended for use in photocopiers, high-speed or laser printers. Gestetner Lasers Pty Ltd, the manufacturer of laser printers in senators' offices, recommends that 80 per cent recycled paper may be used in its laser printers, 50 per cent of the time. I must admit, having read that three times, that I think I will go back to Gestetner.

The Department's high-speed printing presses are sensitive to paper dust. Recycled papers are significantly more dusty than paper made from virgin pulp. Colour printing is particularly affected by paper dust. For these reasons, the Senate's printing unit has not as yet changed to the use of recycled paper, although quantities are being tested. The Department provides recycled paper in the form of writing and scribble pads. I am advised that every effort is being made to obtain recycled paper that is suitable for use in high-speed photocopying and printing machines and at comparable costs with current prices for paper made from virgin pulp. I will investigate one more part of that answer for Senator Bell and get back to him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I am sorry to load this matter on to him in the absence of his colleague but it is pretty urgent. In the Sydney Morning Herald this morning a story appeared which said that the Government is considering a proposal that age limits for children eligible for family allowance would be cut from 16 to 12 years. I ask whether the Government has changed its view of family allowances expressed clearly first of all by Senator Grimes, a former Minister for Social Security, to the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983 in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . family allowances are not and were never meant to be a welfare program in the strict sense. Rather, they are designed to achieve a broad measure of equity in the tax transfer system between those with and those without dependent children.
Further, I ask whether the Government contests the description used by the Institute of Family Studies only last year in its paper entitled Families and Tax, which stated:

Family allowances are the major policy measure that recognises the reduced capacity of people with children to pay tax because of the expenses involved in raising children. Because family allowances were introduced as a replacement for tax rebates for children, it is more appropriate to regard them as part of the tax system, and as such, a `negative' tax payment.

Finally, I ask whether a cut in or removal of family allowances for 12- to 16-year-olds would amount to a discriminatory tax hike for families with children-in short, the acceleration of an anti-child tax regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot disagree with much of what Senator Harradine said. The article in this morning's paper is inaccurate and the matter is not before Government, nor will it be contemplated by Government.

—Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce agree with the statement by the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr David Beddall, on the Walsh Report yesterday when he said that small business is going through a very tough cycle and that genuine hardship is being faced and people are feeling the pinch and that is very worrying? Further, Mr Beddall said that things could get worse before they get better. Does the Minister accept that Mr Beddall's statement has exposed the Treasurer's unrealistic assessment of the economic conditions facing small business and, if so, would he agree that it confirmed his own view that there is an economic downturn of some severity?

—That question is a bit desperate, almost bordering on the boring. We went through a little bit of this last week. As I recall, the Treasurer said nothing about the situation of small business. It is incorrect to intrude that part of Senator Olsen's question as being a view of the Treasurer when talking about small business. I have not seen the comments made by Mr Beddall on the Walsh Report but if what Senator Olsen says is correct, as I and some in the House of Representatives said last week, the current economic effects of high interests, for example, are very patchy in their effects. Small business is one of the areas worst hit by the high rates of interest charged by the banks. I do not find difficulty in talking about that sector of the economy in any different terms from what Mr Beddall had to say.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's selective response in talking about the patchy effect of high interest rates, and given that the major trading banks have to allocate extraordinary sums for bad and doubtful debts, does he not agree with the comments of Mr Nobby Clark from the National Australia Bank that next year is going to be far worse than this year and that we are in a severe economic downturn, which has been denied by the Treasurer?

—The honourable senator will recall that last week in this chamber I tabled a copy of the remarks that I made on the television program. I said that in my view those observations were correct. I am in no position to comment about Mr Nobby Clark's view of the world in 12 months time. My remarks were addressed to this current calendar year, and I think everybody else's remarks have been addressed to this calendar year. I am not in a position to comment on what Mr Clark has had to say except that he has always been a great apostle of doom.

—I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs whether he is aware that from time to time, in the course of counselling sessions, marriage counsellors may become aware of actual or potential criminal offences which have arisen in a domestic situation. What action has the Government taken to ensure that where serious offences are concerned they are brought to the attention of the appropriate authorities? What steps are taken to ensure the protection of the people involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators would agree that it is very important that there be no erosion of the high level of confidentiality and secrecy which normally attends counselling sessions in relation to the strain or stress involved in the possible breakdown of a marriage. Indeed, it is essential to successful counselling that that confidentiality be a part of the counselling process. However, it is clear that there are occasions where a counsellor can become aware of serious criminal offences revealed during those counselling sessions.

ANSWER.PARA: A clear set of guidelines has now been agreed between law enforcement authorities, Family Court counselling services and the three national peak organisations involved in marriage counselling to try to enable counsellors in certain restricted cases to make law enforcement authorities aware of the serious criminal offences that I have indicated. Where an approved marriage counselling organisation has knowledge of a serious current threat to life or limb of any party, where it has knowledge of the commission of a serious crime against a person, including rape, assault or murder or an ongoing serious threat of physical or emotion trauma to a child, then that matter will be immediately reported.

The aim of the guidelines is clearly to achieve a balance between the requirement for privacy and the overriding necessity to protect children and adults from violence or sexual abuse. This matter was first raised at the Australian Police Ministers' Council some two years ago and has been subject to very extensive discussion. I believe these guidelines will be very helpful; but of course they have to be put into operation. To that end, training courses are proposed in each State to enable discussions to take place between counsellors and police authorities to ensure that the guidelines are sensibly and sensitively adhered to in a way which enables confidence to be held in those seeking counselling in the general confidentiality of the discussions held.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs. I refer to the statement by the Minister for Small Business and Customs, David Beddall, on the Walsh Report yesterday.
—You have asked that question.
—It is a different question. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I want to emphasise my commitment to the deferral of the capital gains tax on businesses that are sold and rolled over into other trading operations.

Does the Minister agree that this is one of the strongest arguments against the Government's capital gains tax? Does the Government propose to consider this commitment of the Minister for Small Business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the honourable senator has raised this question about a capital gains tax because I think members of the Opposition have now lost three elections on the promise of abolishing the capital gains tax. As their present policy stands, if they were ever elected to government at this stage the capital gains tax abolition would be made retrospective for eight years which would be a beautiful windfall to some of the supporters of the Liberal Party, although now that the National Party in Queensland has been decimated I do not know whether it would be of such benefit to those opposite. I assume that Senator Boswell is talking about Mr Beddall's former chairmanship of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill interjecting-

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me answer the question thanks, Senator. In that capacity the Committee published a report. Mr Beddall has since become Minister and the Government's knowledge and commitment to small business has, undoubtedly, been strengthened by that appointment.

QUESTION.PARA: The Government is now considering its response to the Beddall report-House of Representatives committee report on small business in Australia. Many issues are raised in that report. The tax issues concern the Australian Taxation Office and in no way, in respect of any of the issues, can I pre-empt the Government's response to the report today. However, the question of a general roll-over provision in the capital gains tax does go to the fundamental design of that tax which seeks to tax capital on the same basis as income. I understand that that has never been terribly palatable to those opposite, but in terms of a properly designed and fair tax, the capital gains tax is designed to support the income tax base and be fair in its application across the spectrum of taxation-payers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the former Attorney-General has interjected about taxation. To moderate that principle of fairness and the design of the tax, supporting as it does the income tax base, would result in a different capital gains tax structure which could lead to ongoing taxation deferral. It could undermine both the equity and efficiency objectives of the capital gains tax. However, as I said, these issues are being examined by the Government. At an appropriate time a decision will be made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. On 1 January this year Mr Staples announced a community accord involving the three tiers of government-unions, business and the community sector-to deal with the national shame of homeless youth who are treated by government as out of sight and out of mind, as described by the Burdekin report on youth poverty. My question to the Minister is: What initiatives has the Federal Government taken since the Minister's speech on 1 January to set up this community accord as a matter of urgency to ensure a community-based response to the problem rather than a bureaucratic one, which has largely failed in the past and led to further juvenile detention and alienation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly the Australian Government does not treat Australia's homeless youth as out of sight out of mind. Homelessness has been a matter of continuous concern to this Government with the special assistance program (SAP) being expanded continually since its introduction in 1984-85.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Vallentine is aware that in 1989 the Commonwealth Government announced in the Budget that new broad spectrum initiatives for disadvantaged young Australians would be delivered over the next four years involving some $100m. This supplements funding already available under SAP which I have already mentioned. In respect of young homeless Australians these initiatives focused on improving their chances of achieving independence or at least moving to a more stable lifestyle. It sought to achieve this primarily through the programs offered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training for training and education, through the Department of Community Services and Health by providing more intensive support in medium to long term accommodation services, as well as health services for young people who would otherwise not have access to traditional medical services, and by social security measures designed to enable more sympathetic and flexible income maintenance provisions.

The Attorney-General's Department has also been involved with family mediation initiatives to assist in returning homeless young people to their families where appropriate. Mr Staples, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, did not announce the community accord but said that what was needed was such an accord on youth homelessness. He did so in the context of the Commonwealth's social justice strategy. One of Mr Brian Burdekin's criticisms of the delivery and availability of services for homeless young people was the lack of coordination at the bureaucratic level. What Peter Staples and other Government Ministers have put in train, firstly, is this bringing together at the Commonwealth level of all the departments involved in providing services to disadvantaged young Australians. At the second level it involves coordinating and planning the delivery of services and assistance through consultation with State governments, local governments, unions, service providers and consumers wherever possible.

The major responsibility for the welfare of children lies first and foremost with the parents and then, as a last resort, the State government. The Commonwealth has had some difficulty in getting some States to accept the extra funds where matching is involved and also to allow the necessary degree of Commonwealth involvement. The Commonwealth is very keen to see responses to youth homelessness being community based rather than bureaucratic.

Seminars to promote the youth social justice strategy were held in all States with a view to disseminating information about the package of initiatives and to gain input from community groups. Coordination committees have been established in all States and Territories with membership comprising all relevant funding bodies and in some States including consumers or advocates. Most States have now put forward their strategies for 1989-90 and had projects approved. The concern was to coordinate these new services with existing services, to fill gaps and to expand the range and types of services available. Initially, this was done by identifying high need areas and then developing a strategy tailored to meet the needs of those areas. The types of services approved have ranged from additional support workers to advocacy services with a special focus on more intensive support within medium to long term accommodation.

Finally, planning is currently under way for approving further new services in 1990-91. This will involve similar targeting and consultation processes to those which have occurred this year but should be more effectively carried out because of the experience gained this year and because there will be more time to undertake these activities in 1990-91.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the statement by the Minister for Small Business and Customs, David Beddall, on the Walsh Report yesterday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think I am more critical than the Treasurer on the banks particularly in relation to their treatment of small business.

I ask the Minister: does the view of the Minister for Small Business about banks reflect the Government's view or are these remarks simply another example of Ministers in this Government freely canvassing their own views about other Minister's responsibilities?

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as in a short program such as the Walsh Report this view can be encapsulated, I understand the view of the Minister for Small Business about the banks. It is something that has been written about by a number of economic journalists and it is something I have commented about here and elsewhere. The fact is that at times small businesses have been called on by the banks to pay quite punitive interest rates, given that we have an environment of high interest rates overall. I think those are the matters to which Mr Beddall is referring. I think that a distinguished correspondent of the Australian Financial Review has had something to say about that in at least one article and probably two. It is not a view unique to Mr Beddall or anybody else.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to press reports that price inflation in the United Kingdom has risen to an annual rate of 9.4 per cent? Is that inflation rate above that in Australia, which has a managed incomes policy under the Hawke Government? Can it be concluded that conservative economic policies of the Thatcherite type do lead to unacceptably high rates of inflation?

—I do not wish to be unfair and refer only to the Thatcher Government when saying that other countries have high interest rates. Countries with a different style of government from that adopted by Mrs Thatcher also have high interest rates. Senator Maguire's question illustrates the enormous shift in the nature of the debate in the Senate and the House of Representatives about economic issues. For five years I and my other ministerial colleagues have sat here and have heard about these economic miracles which were taking place in the United Kingdom. All these economic miracles were due to privatisation and a whole range of very strict economic policies taken by the Thatcher Government, and they were going to produce long term permanent miracles in the United Kingdom economy. Of course, they have not done so because apart from--
—They have done so.

—Senator McGauran of the National Party in Victoria says that they have produced economic miracles. I would like that recorded in Hansard. The Australian Government has concentrated, as far as it possibly can, on obtaining a proper mix between wages and fiscal and monetary policies. That is not true in the United Kingdom where there have been enormous fluctuations in wages policy and the consequences of wages policy adopted in that country.
—Come on, John! You haven't got to go to the other extreme.

—I know that Senator Walters has been deprived of half of her political vocabulary because Margaret Thatcher has hit the fence, but she should not let that upset her. Senator Walters will find somebody else somewhere. She will find some groupie leader somewhere else, probably in South Africa, whom she will be able to follow and have as a role model in respect of economic activities. Inflation in this country is now declining, and it is the Government's objective to reach a 6 per cent inflation rate by mid-1991. I have heard no such promising objectives emanating from the United Kingdom Prime Minister or any member of that Government at the present time.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What circumstances led to the failure of Australia to attract the Taiwanese/China Steel project?

—China Steel has not yet determined a location for the steel mill, although I think that presently Australia is not as well favoured as it was when the initial approach was made to this country by China Steel. I think that two considerations are predominant in the minds of the management of China Steel. The first is the small domestic market in Australia, and the second is the very substantial tax incentives which have been offered by Malaysia. I understand those to be the two considerations which are predominant in the minds of the management of China Steel at this time, but I emphasise that no final decision has been made about this matter at this stage.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that rationalisation of the structure of trade unions is an important factor in micro-economic reform? Has the Minister seen reports of a decision by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) executive last week to increase the pace of rationalisation? Do these reports suggest that the ACTU, in order to carry out this decision, has foreshadowed a process of federation in which unions would cover major industry sectors or groups of unions? If these reports are correct, can the Minister advise the Senate about the significance of the ACTU's decision for the cause of micro-economic reform? Finally, has the Minister any information to suggest whether the ACTU's policy of structural change is matched in the same practical way by peak employer organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers are yes, yes, yes, yes and no. If I can elaborate, however, in some brief detail on those answers so that the asker of the question can understand the significance of the cryptic yeses and noes, the rationalisation of the trade union structure is a major advance, if it occurs, in micro-economic reform.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister, having given the answers `Yes, yes, yes, yes and no', can only therefore go on to debate the answers that he has given, which is contrary to the Standing Orders. If the Minister has set up his answer to this particular question in order to put on that theatrical performance, good luck to him, but I put to you that, having answered the parts of the question by giving the information that is required in the question, in fact, going beyond that is now to debate those issues, and that itself is a breach of the Standing Orders.

—On the point of order, Mr President, Senator Puplick well knows that it is not necessarily the case that I would go on and debate, as he terms it, the answers. As I have already explained to the chamber, it is my intention to explain in some brief detail why the answers are in the form they are. They were, if you like, the most cryptic form of answers to the question. Since the questions did in fact, as I recall it, call for greater information than simple cryptic answers, it seems to me appropriate that I should give it.

—I have no power as to how a Minister shall answer a question. I accept that the Minister is now going to give a more detailed answer within the area of his responsibility and, therefore, I will allow the answer.

—I was going on to say that of course the rationalisation of the trade union structure in this country would be a significant help in achieving the micro-economic reform agenda set out by the Hawke Government for its historic fourth term. The rationalisation of union coverage, award coverage, in industry centres would also create career paths for workers in those industries, would break down the possibility of demarcation disputes and would create a number of other benefits such as the ability to introduce multiskilling. So in answer to the first question, there is considerable advantage in micro-economic reform.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go to the central question posed in this group of questions, and that is the proposal by the ACTU for federations of unions to be registered. The ACTU proposal is to amend the Australian Industrial Relations Act to provide for registration of organisations of workers in the form of federations so that in one industry one registered organisation could appear representing a group of unions and that federation, as it would then be termed, could hold the award on behalf of that group of unions. This would be, in the ACTU's submission, an interim step in achieving industry unionism or unionism embodying a great number of unions.

I think that is an admirable suggestion. I have not yet concluded my consideration of all the ACTU's suggestions, or indeed the suggestions of other peak bodies, for amendments to the Industrial Relations Act, but of this one I can say that I have had direct experience in Western Australia. The Western Australian Industrial Relations Act provides for a similar facility. It works well, particularly if the federation is an interim and not a final step towards true industry unionism.

To conclude my answer, I am not aware of employer organisations duplicating that-and I do not think it is entirely appropriate-process although it would be more useful for government if employer organisations were bracketed together nationally in one peak body rather than in a number of bodies when presenting views to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. There has been a great deal of talk recently about the Soviet-Jewish immigrants to Israel-their right of entry to Israel and their right to settle in occupied Palestine against the wishes of the Palestinian residents. I ask a question about the rights of another group-the Palestinians who were resident in what is now Israel and who fled or were forced out during the fighting which followed the United Nations partition of Palestine in 1947. What rights do these refugees, and their children, have to return to their original homes in Israel? What has happened to the property they left behind when they fled? Is it still theirs, or have they been fairly compensated if it has been expropriated? What is the attitude of Australia to these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a good question from Senator Hamer which does draw attention to an often neglected element in the tragic situation we are now witnessing in Israel and the occupied territories. I cannot answer his question now precisely as to the formal rights such displaced persons have or may have, but I will seek further information to see what I can say on the record in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: I think Australia's general position on this whole issue is by now well known and well appreciated to the extent that what we are talking about here are essentially political conflicts rather than contests of legal right. We take the view that the situation in Israel and the occupied territories is long overdue for reasoned resolution by a proper, negotiated settlement between Israel, its Government and the proper representatives of the Palestinian people.

We are concerned that all the efforts that have been made in recent times to enable those negotiations to commence, even in the very preliminary way that is involved in the Bush-Baker plan that has run into so much difficulty in recent times-all those possible avenues of progress-have so far come to nought.

Australia's position remains one of very strong support for a resolution of the problem of the Palestinian people in a way that, of course, not only recognises Israel's right to exist within secure borders but also produces a just solution for the displaced Palestinian people. We will continue to add Australia's voice around the world in the appropriate forums and to appropriate governments to ensure that that comes about. I will seek further information and see what it might be possible to add by way of detail to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. The fundamental question I asked the Minister was, of course, a question of fact: what are the rights of the Palestinians who were resident in Israel to return there if they so wish? Will the Minister be able to give me an answer on that before he leaves for overseas again, and will he be able to explain what the Australian attitude is on that matter?

—I am a little puzzled by the repetition. I of course took it to be a question of fact that was being asked about legal rights of the people in the position Senator Hamer described. I will do my best to give him an answer on that question of fact-to the extent that it involves questions of fact-before the end of this week.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister comment on the significance of the meeting between Presidents Gorbachev and Bush to be held in Washington from 30 May to 3 June?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed summit meeting will be a very important milestone, we all hope, in the resolution of a large number of outstanding issues in disarmament and arms controls-as well as of course, hopefully, addressing some of the larger remaining problems associated with the reshaping of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and its position and stance in Europe. In particular, we look forward to the meeting giving further content to President Bush's comment made at the beginning of this month that the revolutionary changes and transformations in Europe are moving us from a post-war era to a new era in Europe, beyond containment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is evident from recent ministerial level consultations between the two superpowers that both sides are committed to concluding a strategic arms reduction talks (START) agreement. Discussions at the 4-6 April Washington meeting between Secretary of State Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze made some progress in that respect.

We now have reports in the last 24 hours that the latest round of such talks, held in Moscow from 16-19 May, did succeed in removing some remaining substantial obstacles to a START agreement, in particular the treatment of air- and sea-launched cruise missiles. President Bush has now been reported as saying that this should allow the completion of the major substantive elements of a START agreement during the forthcoming summit.

Apart from the START agreement, which is of course crucial to nuclear disarmament, there is now an excellent chance, it seems, that a bilateral chemical weapons destruction agreement and verification protocols for the threshold test ban treaty and peaceful nuclear explosions treaty will all be ready for signature at that summit.

We welcome all these positive developments. We hope that some progress will also be made in negotiations on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe, including provisions on the destruction of all treaty limited equipment.

We would appreciate it if we could be notified at an earlier stage of the unavailability of Ministers for that particular purpose.

The Ferntree Gully Recycling Centre is a private company which is seeking to establish a recycling business. It does not receive any funding under the Disability Services Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Disability Advisory Council of Australia has written to the Centre's Mr Damien Wise asking him to retract section 3 of a document circulated by the Centre to generate business. In part, this section states:

We have found a pool of labour in the form of sheltered workshops clients that we can train in a variety of tasks including sorting paper, glass, plastic, scrap metals and simple tool usage. These people are available at a fraction of the normal labour rates and show what is often a fanatical dedication to correctly achieving their tasks . . . SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some comments in relation to the annual report of the Australian Institute of Health. This Institute, as people might know, is not a very old organisation, having been established, I think, in 1987. It is essentially an organisation that deals with statistics relating to health. It is a very interesting read because some of the things it alludes to highlight the importance of such an institute so that we do have adequate statistical databases on which to make the sorts of claims we do and also, very importantly, the sorts of predictions we need to make in the area of health.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the headings in this volume could give one considerable pause but I suppose in some ways if it has been established to address the sorts of issues that are drawn to our attention then it is serving its purpose. I note for instance on page 13 under the heading `CSIRO Division of Plant Industry Laboratory Study' it says that in 1988 the staff in a research laboratory at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Plant Industry became aware of what they thought seemed to be an undue proportion of people who had worked in that laboratory developing cancers of one kind or another. After consultation with staff associations the CSIRO approached the Institute for assistance. A study is now being set up to try to compare the incidence of cancer for those workers to that in the general Australian population.

I am not sure that I have missed somewhere in the report a further development of that study or whether it is in the process of being set up. I would have thought that that kind of collaboration would have been very constructive. The idea of being able to appraise statistical analysis to try to be more accurate rather than working off a best guess is the sort of raison d'etre for just this Institute. Indeed, it is not only occurring in that area. A number of the headings here point out a whole range of studies and proposals that are being put in place. Those of us who have any interest in matters of health in the community would appreciate how important it is to have that adequate data.

One other point that is raised in this report that I would like to allude to briefly is described under its external programs, as reported on page 18. There is a reference there to the national perinatal statistics unit. As I was speaking to the Home Births Australia association very recently and had this matter drawn to my attention I am pleased to refer to it again today. The research studies, under the heading of this unit, deal with things like national trends in obstetrics care by obstetricians and general practitioners, look at national trends of perinatal mortality and, in collaboration with Home Births Australia, analyses data on home births and related perinatal deaths. The unit also surveys neo-natal intensive care units.

I am particularly interested in whether or not the statistics and the data collected by this unit would be user friendly. It is a point that was raised at the Home Births Australia association conference last Friday with me. One of the points raised with me was that the association wanted a breakdown hospital by hospital of obstetric practice in this country and the related statistics. It is not much good knowing that Australia has a very low neo-natal mortality rate but not knowing that one hospital has a rate that is five times that of another hospital. I sincerely hope that the data that is being collected by this unit would be available on a hospital by hospital breakdown.

The reports that have emerged recently include a report on New South Wales findings of hospital studies in that State and, more recently, one from Victoria. While they do provide a lot of very constructive information they do not seemingly give a hospital by hospital breakdown. For the concern and appropriate comfort of anybody involved in seeking obstetric or gynaecological care it is important that we actually have this kind of data provided on a hospital by hospital basis. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I suppose that in some ways this report, the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) report for the period 22 August 1988 to 30 June 1989 is remarkably timely. Last Monday, 14 May, the first of the Australia Prizes was presented in the Great Hall of this Parliament. One of the recipients of that prize was Professor Allan Kerr from the Waite Institute in South Australia. Indeed, on page 14 of the report there is a fairly detailed description of the work of this Committee in relation to Professor Kerr's work.

Reading this report should be of some comfort and consolation to people who are interested in or concerned about the release of genetically manipulated material into the environment-and serious concerns about that matter have been raised with particular pertinence to the recipients of the Australia Prize. It is not as though all of that has happened without the questions and anxieties raised by people in terms of the environmental consequences of the release of genetically altered material being dealt with. They have been dealt with.

This report, giving an outline of the steps that were taken to test as far as possible the prospect of releasing into the environment genetically altered material, is, or ought be, of great assistance to those people who have that anxiety. It is curious to note that this report has arrived in the Senate about a week after last Wednesday's lengthy article in the Melbourne Age about just this matter and the environmental concerns in relation to the second recipient of the Australia Prize, whose name, I think, is Professor Schell in the Max Planck Institute. At the time his prize, for the changes he was attempting in petunias, was being accepted, the environmental lobby and people with great concern about this matter were actually demonstrating outside the Max Planck Institute. There was a lengthy article describing the concern in the community to the point where it was claimed the media of Germany no longer felt confident or free to report scientific matters of genetic manipulation and proper research.

I think they are matters of the gravest concern. First, we have to be properly alert to the consequences of releasing into the environment genetically altered material. We also have to be very concerned about the consequences of one part or other of the community being so prepared to demonstrate that, if the claim in this article is true, the press feels itself gagged in relation even to reporting scientific steps or processes. It is a matter of great importance that we do two things if there are areas of anxiety: firstly, establish a committee such as the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee to try to do the appropriate research; and, secondly, ensure that there is full and frank discussion in our media. I do not know that what was claimed in that article in the Age is true, that any restraint is practised by the German media, for example, as was cited, in reporting these matters. But if the community, and in particular our community, wants to tackle issues of the benefits, let alone the negatives, of genetically manipulated material in terms of increased productivity of food, resistant strains to diseases and so on, we cannot possibly do that if we are cornering certain groups of the community so they do not feel they can speak openly and fully about these things.

If ever there is occasion for the community to act as watchdog through its institutions and media on matters scientific, then it is on these sorts of issues. I commend this report to anyone who has a concern about genetic manipulation or the release into the community of genetically manipulated material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general I think the report of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee is not highly informative, although it is a good starting point, as Senator Crowley has suggested. It is obvious that, because of claims that the information is commercially sensitive and must remain confidential, the public does not have adequate access to the information which is due to it. The whole issue of the public's right to know needs to be addressed. The community must be offered a more active role in evaluating genetic engineering and determining beforehand whether to approve its products.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some specific concerns about this document, related generally to the introductory section. On page 1 the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee's functions are outlined. But I believe this Committee should not only provide advice on safety procedures to researchers, institutions and government regulatory bodies but should also consult with companies. Now that genetic manipulation has moved out of the laboratory and into the marketplace, these companies should definitely be scrutinised. The institutional biosafety committee (IBC) system is weak and open to abuse. A few examples will highlight the problem. First, the IBC was not told of the unauthorised release of pigs at a joint facility run by the University of Adelaide and Metro Meat Ltd in South Australia. Example two relates to the company Bio-care Technology Pty Ltd, which has commercialised the product No-Gall. According to appendix C of the report, Bio-care has no IBC. This raises the question of who is responsible for overseeing the day-to-day work of producing the commercial product No-Gall and reporting to the GMAC as required. Example three: another problem that shows the weakness of the system is that it is usually the researchers doing the work and then seeking approval who are better informed than anyone else; therefore, their advice is essential to approval being given. This obviously creates a conflict of interest.

The next area of concern is the advisory system. Its major weakness is that it relies on weak sanctions and unfavourable publicity to control companies. However, when it comes to reporting accidents or intentional releases of engineered organisms the Advisory Committee does not name the company. Therefore, we question how the company can receive unfavourable publicity. For example, in the pig case, the Advisory Committee has still made no public statement, even though it has known of the incident for some time.

In relation to legislation, the advisory system is also questionable. The so-called responsible authorities at both the State and Federal levels have no legislation which refers to genetically engineered plants, animals or micro-organisms. In June 1989 the Victorian Law Reform Commission recommended that a national system of uniform regulation, based on new laws specifically to control genetic engineering, should be negotiated. No action has yet been taken on these recommendations. The GMAC is simply going through the motions but not doing anything concrete. The enactment of laws is of extreme urgency. When will the Advisory Committee accept the need for new laws? Then there is the question of the Advisory Committee Public Liaison Subcommittee. This Committee has never met and has no agenda for informing the public or receiving public submissions. How long will it be before this Committee is not just words on paper?

My remarks relate only to the introduction of this GMAC report. The whole area of genetic engineering raises many contentious issues in the community, and I am representing some of the concerns of community groups who are lobbying for the establishment of an independent public inquiry into all aspects of genetic engineering and its regulation in Australia. The inquiry would need to have the broadest possible terms of reference. The membership of the inquiry should be very diverse, with public, non-government organisations and government membership. The sources of professional advice to the inquiry must be also broadly representative. The Government, of course, plans for a parliamentary committee on industry and commerce to conduct the inquiry which, as it would set a narrow agenda, focused on the commercial potential of genetic engineering, would not be acceptable in relation the community input that is required. A parliamentary select committee may be a suitable compromise.

Recombinant DNA and other genetic manipulation technologies can be used to alter the basic structures of all living organisms by the transfer of genetic material between unrelated life forms. Their use could have major impacts on both the natural environment and human societies, and many of these could be harmful and irreversible. All citizens therefore have the right to be involved in deciding which applications will be rejected and which approved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak to the report of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee but I did hear a number of comments that have been made to date and I certainly wish to add my comments to some of those. I think the difficulty in this area is that there is a significant amount of misinformation around. This Parliament has enacted legislation with regard to a number of these matters. I think that the previous speaker, Senator Crowley, indicated that there might not be any, but there is.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember during a debate in this place I moved over 30 amendments to legislation-all of which were defeated, unfortunately-which would have given the public the ability to have input regarding the release of genetic material into the marketplace. The problems we had at that time related to alerting the public to the imminent release of, for example, biological control mechanisms which may be directed at controlling a particular disease or a particular agricultural product.

At the moment the public does not get involved. The public does not have to know. I think that when we are dealing with the simple release of biological organisms, whether or not they have been manipulated, the public does have a right to know. Unfortunately, the amendments that I proposed in this place were defeated.

Quite a number of people have come to me-and I am sure they have approached a number of other members of parliament-asking for the very things that we should have included in the legislation when it passed this place, that is, that the public be informed in the normal way in the media, by way of advertisements, well prior to the release of any biological organism which is aimed at controlling any mechanism, whether it be agricultural or otherwise. Members of the public have an inherent right to know, even more so when there is the release, not of an organism which is naturally developed, but of one which is artificially developed. It is not a matter of fuelling paranoia or any element; it is a matter of whether in a democracy it is not inherent in the rights of individuals to have that information prior to the release of any such organism. I believe that it is. I argued for it but, unfortunately, that was not what ended up in the legislation.

I hope that when this matter is looked at by the parliamentary committee system, another look will be taken at the whole mechanism of the public's right to know. If we do not involve ordinary citizens, as distinct from the specialist and those who may have a financial or professional interest in these matters, I believe we are abrogating the rights of those ordinary citizens to be aware of what is happening in that wider sphere. I do not refer only to citizens who may have a generally disinterested position but also to many of those citizens who may have a very interested position. I have had put to me from the rural area, for example, why it is that certain organisms are allowed to be released without our knowing what is going on. I think that is a perfectly reasonable proposition for someone to put, particularly when the release of a certain organism can cause inherent damage to the agricultural product that is being put on the market. I think there should be a prior right to know, so that there can be a prior right to object.

There ought to be mechanisms in place which enable a citizen of this country to object to the release of an organism into the environment, particularly where that may affect them. But even if it does not affect them, I still think that they have the right to object. Objecting after the event is, of course, pointless. In almost every other area the public has a right to dispute what the Government is doing. Unfortunately, in this area, this chamber decided not to give Australians that right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make a very brief comment on the report of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). I will not detain the Senate for long. I agree with a number of the things said by previous speakers. Senator Macklin referred to the fact that we, as legislators, represent the constituents who, of course, are concerned about major matters of public policy. This is a major question of public policy. I agree with Senator Vallentine-indeed, it was also implied by Senator Crowley-that this is a major matter of public policy and it should not be left to be determined by scientific elites or by commercially motivated research.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need not to be paranoid, as Senator Macklin said. One way to overcome paranoia is to be quite open about things and to lay all the cards on the table, and particularly to direct knowledge. Parliamentarians have a responsibility in this area to receive information and to represent the views of their constituents. How can constituents express views if they are not fully and adequately informed.

The document that is before us is a very brief document on the activities of GMAC during the period 22 August 1988 to 30 June 1989. I think that it is rather too thin. There is not sufficient information in this document. Certainly, it does not contain the information that is available to the members of the Committee and I believe it should be made available to the Parliament and through the Parliament to the people.

There is no reference in the report as to when it was written. Normally, the introduction section of other reports that come before us contain a letter to the appropriate Minister and the date on which that letter came from the chairman of the particular institute is shown. The previous report that we considered, namely, the Australian Institute of Health report, was dated 22 December 1989. We do not know whether this report was written in December 1989 or in the first half of this year. It is unfortunate that we are now debating a report for the period 22 August 1988 to 30 June 1989. That may not be the result of any dilatoriness on the part of GMAC; it may reflect the fact that the Senate did not sit until May of this year. Nevertheless, the point that I want to make is that I have noted the membership of GMAC, and I am interested to know why two or three people are on that Committee. I am also concerned lest people on the Committee consider that these are questions which should be reserved for scientific elites. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In this year's Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) report, I wish to address very briefly chapter 5, which deals with accountability and information access, because one of the bodies to which ASIO is accountable is the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO. The Committee was set up under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, as amended, and it began operations in 1986. The Committee has a good reputation in operating in what is a very difficult field. It must be a bipartisan committee; it must operate non-politically; and above all it must have a very responsible approach to the security information that it receives. As I said before, the Committee has operated very well over the last four years.

The terms of reference under which the Committee was appointed are covered by the Act in part Va from section 92a onwards. I was therefore very concerned to read in Saturday's Courier-Mail an article reporting statements by the new chairman of the Committee, Mr Keith Wright of the electorate of Capricornia, and again in today's Townsville Bulletin two articles reporting remarks by the chairman which I believe are quite out of order. I seek leave to have these articles incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The articles read as follows-
FEDERAL PROBE OF OLD ASIO LINKS TO SPECIAL BRANCH
From GLENN STANAWAY in Canberra
ASIO's links with Queensland's former police Special Branch will be investigated by a new joint federal parliamentary committee.

The committee chairman, Queensland Labor MP Mr Keith Wright (Capricornia), said yesterday he understood the branch had given information on security matters to the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation.
Mr Wright said he accepted this was a legitimate role for the Special Branch but he wanted to investigate what files were passed on to ASIO.
As a former State Opposition Leader, he said he had serious reservations about the way the previous National Party State Government had used the Special Branch for political purposes.
`My personal view is the Queensland police force had been totally politicised and the Special Branch was the centrepoint of this politicisation', he said.
`I intend to pursue what records were passed on to ASIO and what records are still held by ASIO that are linked back to the Special Branch's sordid days.
`I think the Queensland people really would like the rest of the (Special Branch) story told.'
The Goss Government has disbanded the branch and thousands of files on the affairs of Queenslanders were destroyed just before the State election.

For years the branch was alleged to have been used to collect damaging information on critics and political opponents of the National Party, instead of gathering intelligence solely for police and security matters.
Mr Wright said that despite police harassment of him and Special Branch inquiries, he was not planning any witchhunt through ASIO.
The committee will also resume its inquiry into the ASIO's obligations under the Archives Act.
The Act requires federal departments to release documents more than 30 years old; but many complaints had been made that ASIO had either blocked or delayed the release of documents.
The committee would also welcome community views on ASIO's operations.
ASIO FILES PROBED
Brisbane-A new Federal Government committee will investigate claims that copies of files kept by Queensland's infamous Special Branch were passed on to ASIO.
ASIO committee chairman Keith Wright (ALP, Capricornia) said last night that if files of non-national importance were being kept by ASIO they should be destroyed immediately.
He said this was one of the areas to be looked into by the all-party committee.
Mr Wright, a former Queensland ALP leader, said this would have to be done before public perception of ASIO improved.
He said he wanted the committee to clarify and put an end to the suspicions.
He said Queensland senior police officers had last year stated publicly that ASIO had accessed Special Branch files.
Mr Wright said he believed files were passed on long before any decision to destroy them was made.
`This committee wants to put an end to this chapter in ASIO's history, and if files not in the national interest do exist they should be destroyed', he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I have not had time to read these articles but I will highlight some of the key points in them. The opening article in the Courier-Mail says:

SPEECH.PARA: ASIO's links with Queensland's former police Special Branch will be investigated by a new joint federal parliamentary committee.
Later on it quotes Mr Wright as saying:
I intend to pursue what records were passed on to ASIO and what records are still held by ASIO that are linked back to the Special Branch's sordid days.
In the Townsville Bulletin this morning under the heading `ASIO files probed' the statement is:
ASIO committee chairman Keith Wright (ALP, Capricornia) said last night that if files of non-national importance were being kept by ASIO they should be destroyed immediately.
He said this was one of the areas to be looked into by the all-party committee.

For Mr Wright's information it is not given to him or any member of the Committee to select the terms of reference for any inquiry of the Committee. The Act is very specific in that. Section 92c subsections (2) (a) and (b) onwards deal quite explicitly with the fact that the Committee can deal only with matters referred to it either by the Minister-who is the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy)-or by either House of the Parliament. It is not possible for an individual to pursue any personal vendettas or interest as a subject of inquiry of the Committee and it is absolutely improper for the Committee chairman to so propose.

Furthermore, it is not possible for the Committee to make public any of the findings of its reports. That again is defined in section 92n of the Act. It is not possible, as Mr Wright claims, to inquire into these matters and make them public. As a member of that Committee, I am quite alarmed that Mr Wright, who is a well-known publicist of emotional issues that appeal to the lowest common denominators in the community, should take it upon himself as chairman of one of the very important committees of this Parliament to go public to pursue what is simply a personal vendetta against the former Queensland Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few remaining minutes of this debate I want to express how disturbed I am by aspects of this report of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation which brings to the attention of the Parliament the fact that in the last year ASIO has detected higher levels of representation and activity by some hostile foreign intelligence services than was previously known. Honourable senators should bear in mind that last year's annual report brought to our attention the fact that ASIO was observing some 50 agents within this country. It appears that the number has now increased, although we do not know to what number. It also brings to our attention `a trend towards more violent activity in the activities of domestic racist groups' and `an illicit attempt by a member of a terrorist group to be granted resident status in Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: These findings, as I say, are of considerable concern to us in a country that has had a history largely devoid, I am pleased to say, of politically motivated violence. But when we read here of the efforts that were made by one person, a member of one of the most dangerous currently active terrorist groups, seeking to get into this country through a marriage whilst he was already married to another-so obviously coming illicitly into this country-one must be worried and ask what the ultimate consequences of this are.

The ASIO report brings to our attention the danger of letting down our guard whilst recognising that there is less stress and tension within the world. But whilst that might well be the case, ethnic conflicts are increasing. I remind the House that the thaw that is occurring in eastern Europe certainly has not reached this end of the world. The bottom line of all that is, as I said, a need to keep the guard up and in ASIO's terms, as it says to us in this report, the likely future demand for a significant additional funding in the years ahead.

People in Australia do not always adequately appreciate the work that ASIO does in helping secure our way of life in this country and I draw the attention of this report to the Parliament for serious debate at some appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the Senate for lunch I was pointing out the vital importance of fixing up the infrastructure in Australia so that we can get ourselves out of this economic mess which the Government has, largely by its own efforts, got us into despite the fact that some Ministers in this Government are pretending that there is no problem. I think most Australians have seen the headlines in today's papers. An article under the heading `Banks rule out soft landing', states:

SPEECH.PARA: Two of Australia's top bankers yesterday contradicted predictions of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, of an economic soft landing, claiming that the economy was already technically in recession and that tough times lay ahead.
The Australian Financial Review, for example, had as its page one lead last week the fact that:

. . . Mr Keating, is fighting a battle with his own senior colleagues to maintain the credibility of his claims that the economy is undergoing only a moderate slowdown as it adjusts to export-driven growth.
Of course, we all saw the headings last week such as, `Button says Labor must try harder' and `Button paints blacker picture of economy than Treasurer'.

There is no doubt that the only way to get ourselves out of the mess is to start off on the policy that the Opposition has been pressing this Government on for years, that is, fixing up the infrastructure, the wharves and the other things that not only add enormous costs to Australia's exports and price us out of markets but also delay those exports and which, as a result of ludicrous go-slow tactics and, in some instances, massive overmanning, create continual problems for our exporters.
It is now becoming accepted that what the Opposition has been saying for years is right. For example, last month Ross Gittins, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald, said this:
The answer to our intractable inflation problem lies as much in micro-economic reform as in better macro management.
He continued:
We need micro reform to achieve higher productivity, increased international competitiveness, higher savings, more exports and fewer imports.
But that's only half the story. We need micro reform to make our economy less inflation prone.

That is the very area in which this Government is not performing. It is the very area in which Senator Button said that the Government had failed to deliver and had missed opportunities. Of course, that is absolutely correct. The last report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) for last year says it all very clearly. It states:
Altogether, sustained real GDP gains-
that is, growth in our economy-
of almost 5 per cent, or just $16 billion a year . . . are projected to flow through in the long term.

These gains will come from the sorts of micro-economic reform that it recommends, namely, transport, communications, electricity supply and assistance to agriculture and manufacturing. The report also states:
These gains accrue from improved productivity, increased competition and better domestic pricing policies.
This IAC report is absolutely damning of the Government's failure to act. For example, it states:

. . . the removal of major inefficiencies in domestic water transport, international liner shipping, the transport and handling of bulk commodities, domestic and international aviation, road and rail transport could collectively increase Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by about $9 billion annually. Improved efficiency in the postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors could provide a further stimulus to GDP of around $3 billion annually.
The report continues:
. . . assistance to the passenger motor vehicle and textiles, clothing and footwear industries-
this is Senator Button's area in which Mr Keating says that he is working too slowly-

continues to impose major costs on the community. If manufacturing and agricultural assistance which will exist in the mid-1990s at the end of the current program of reductions were removed, GDP would increase by nearly $4 billion annually.
There is clearly an urgent need for Australia to go down this track at a faster pace than this Government has managed to. As the IAC report states:
The efficiency gains from opening up currently protected sectors of the economy to competition depend in large measure on improvements in the productivity of labour in those sectors.

I interpose that that is why the Opposition's labour programs, labour policies and industrial relations policies are absolutely vital for the achievement of any kind of real and lasting economic recovery. The report continues:
Overmanning, restrictive and inflexible work practices and inefficient union structures would be more difficult to sustain in a more competitive market environment.
The IAC report states:
These constraints must be addressed if the benefits of microeconomic reform are to be fully realised.
Although the report says that a start has been made in this area, it states:

However, management, unions and government face a major challenge if they are to achieve the labour market flexibility necessary when currently protected areas of the economy are opened to competition.
It is almost as if the Opposition had written this report. It is a shame that the Government has not taken nearly enough notice of it. The report continues:
By highlighting the costs to the community of inefficient arrangements, independent public inquiry can provide an impetus for necessary change.
We hope that this Government will take notice of what the Opposition has been saying. But, this is the problem. The IAC says:
A commitment from all levels of government is therefore essential if the benefits of microeconomic reform are to be maximised.

There is no commitment from all levels of government, not even from within this Government, to this absolutely vital need for reform of our basic disaster areas. As we have seen, Mr Keating thinks that Senator Button has not done enough, Senator Button blames others and there is a lot of finger pointing all round. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), whose area includes the wharves, is, as I mentioned before the break, already finding excuses for why he has not achieved enough in this area and why he will not achieve much.

Nonetheless, by the look of things the Government has some kind of solution to it all. Honourable senators will have noticed in the newspapers recently that a lot of concentration is being placed on the enormous increase in activity among accountancy and legal firms relating to receiverships and bankruptcies that are now inundating so many Australian companies. There is, in fact, a boom going on in Australia and it is a boom in liquidation. One has only to look in the newspapers at the lists of items being auctioned, at the for sale notices, which are the result of people being forced off their land or out of their businesses, to see where the boom is. It is almost as if this huge increase in business for accountants and lawyers reveals the Government's solution to our problems. It is a receivership-led recovery; it is the only booming part of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good for accountants.

—As my friend says, it is very good for some accountants. But many other accountants are having to spend a lot of time advising people, who they know will not be able to pay their bills, on how to cope with the disastrous high interest rates and the credit disaster that they and so many people in Australia now face because they are being forced out of business as a result of deliberate Government policy to dampen down demand through massive high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of this bankruptcy to Australia is quite appalling. For example, the Australian Financial Review of today deals with a story which is headed, `Forced property sales top $3 billion and squeeze prices'. So here we have clear indications of assets being reduced in value. Australians, many of whom have struggled to pay for their home, are now finding that, for the first time, home prices are falling as a result of this Government's deliberate polices. Consequently, their asset against which they have borrowed, is becoming less and less valuable. Of course, this same thing is happening to so many people on the land. An article which appeared the other day in the Sydney Morning Herald reported:
Corporate collapses could cost the Australian economy up to $10 billion . . .
Not only the Sydney Morning Herald is saying that; it is also according to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). The Sunday Age of a couple of months ago reported that:
10,000 companies have gone to the wall since Christmas. Bob Ansett-
who I suppose knows all about that-
says there must be a better way.

A report, I think last week, in one of the newspapers stated that the sheer weight of liquidations and receiverships is up from 4,836 businesses in 1987-88 to 6,189 in 1988-89 and is expected to top 10,000 in the year ending 30 June-more than double what it was only two years ago.

Here we have this dreadful situation of a government that has brought about this kind of disaster by its concentration on the wrong policies. It is a government that cannot even agree within itself about what sort of policies it should be following. It cannot agree on microeconomic reform policies, tough fiscal policies, whether the clear things that this Opposition has been saying should be done to the economy should proceed, or whether the Government should continue in chaos.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. Before I call Senator Olsen, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in this chamber and therefore I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him. I call Senator Olsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to the challenge and privilege of serving my State in the Senate, to serve in my third tier of government at a time when Australia is a fragmented and nervous nation. The electorate at large is searching for a national identity and a feeling of unity to be able to go forward to security. It is surely our duty as politicians to work to satisfy those needs with guidance and with vision. But, as recent State and Federal elections have shown us, the people of Australia feel politicians are more concerned about themselves and with winning and keep power than with the good of our country. The people believe they have been let down. They have been promised the world, but they have been delivered lower living standards. That is hardly surprising in a climate where our Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) owns a unique dictionary which describes acute pain as effervescence.

SPEECH.PARA: Government contracts have been awarded to States and cities where political gain, not people gain, is the criteria. In a time of acute debt problems, when small business is struggling with high interest rates, Federal Cabinet has cynically spent millions of dollars to rescue Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, not as a business decision, but as a purely political decision to shore up Labor's tumbling stocks in Victoria. Is it any wonder, therefore, that we have a disillusioned and confused electorate?

But neither major party has anything to be proud of from the results of 24 March. I firmly believe that the people of Australia are looking for a government of broad vision and balanced judgment to rescue them from the economic trough into which we have sunk. Labor has shown the world that it cannot do it, but has been returned to power by default because, as Liberals, we were not able to show on 24 March that we should be given the opportunity to do it. We must work to repair that view if Australians are to have the government they deserve, a government which will go forward with one united Australia, making decisions for the good of one nation and its people, not decisions based on holding on to individual seats for party power, as has been clearly illustrated in the past few years. We need to prove to Australians that politicians are indeed working for them.

I intend to use my time in Canberra to work towards some fundamental changes-changes that I hope in time should help to deliver a feeling of national unity in working together towards both social and economic goals. They are changes that in time may rekindle a feeling of trust in the work politicians can do.

As a small businessman, it was the excesses of the Dunstan and Whitlam era that galvanised my determination to be part of the political process and influence policy direction. Mr President, that determination is undiminished. In 1985, as leader of my Party in South Australia, I put privatisation on the agenda. It is a policy as relevant today as it was then. The only variation is that it has become more urgent in the restructuring of our economy.

It is unfortunate that vested interest or pressure groups have interfered with the deregulation of our financial and labour markets. Despite John Howard's best endeavours, the last Liberal Government did not deregulate the financial market. After initially opposing the move, to its credit, Labor finally did. But it only did half the job. It has refused to deregulate the labour market because of interest groups, and particularly the union movement, applying pressure to the Labor Party in government. It will take a Liberal Government to balance that equation.

My view has always been that the basic responsibility of government is to help create an environment which is conducive to change, to innovation, to investment, to increased productivity, and to better dialogue between employers and employees where freedom and incentive are the basics. Again, put simply, it should be a government of broad vision and balanced judgment.

However, I come from a State which suffers because that kind of government is not being delivered either on a State or a Federal level. It is a great State, as many of us today in this chamber can attest to, but it could be a much greater State if Australia were governed for the good of one nation-if Labor here in Canberra would stop making industrial and economic decisions based solely on keeping pockets of voters happy for the next election.

A good example of misplaced Federal attention affecting South Australia is the Government's disinterest in the Murray-Darling. It is not a sexy subject for the media, nor is it seen as green vote catching by Labor's environmental gurus. While the green vote is being chased through Kakadu and Tasmania, through rain- forests and pulp mills, the heart of Australia is being left to die. Its main artery is clogged with the salinity and pollution of the States through which it passes, with my State of South Australia, in consequence, condemned by a political inertia to being in effect the sewer of Australia.

Yet the Murray-Darling is worth a staggering $10,000m a year to the economy of our nation. Despite this, its condition has been allowed to deteriorate so much that it has become an environmental disgrace which needs $100m annually spent on it for the next 10 years to rectify its salinity problems. If this valuable resource is not rescued now, it could be too late. With Labor at the helm, it may well be. Where is the unity, and the one Australia identity and commitment to solving a national environmental problem? It is absent, while the Federal Government delivers cosmetic surgery to environmental problems which provide short-term votes and gain media coverage through picture opportunities. Through the Senate, I want to spend some of my time working towards the clean-up of the Murray-Darling.

As well, I am a strong advocate of States rights and will fight for their retention wherever necessary. However, my years as Liberal leader in South Australia showed me that States rights can no longer be used as an excuse for the fragmentation and duplication of the legislation we see in so many areas across Australia. We have gone forward but we have happened rather than evolved logically. Government is causing enormous problems to small and big business alike, and families who regularly change States have been battling with social hassles that are of the Yes, Minister legislative variety. It has been estimated that in the past 20 years, Federal and State Parliaments have passed more than 17,000 Acts, 36,000 regulations, and over 30,000 statutory instruments-many of them unnecessary duplications. We have fragmented, confused and over-governed our nation. Have we really forgotten that whilst we are big geographically we have a small population base?

There is a need to unify and simplify. Can we really excuse, for example, with a population such as ours, having the fundamentals and education systems vastly different in each State-where one can have a South Australian five-year-old who has been to school, can read and write, locked out of school in Queensland until he is over six; or send a NSW junior pupil to South Australia and find she is a year behind in some lessons of a completely different structure and years ahead in others? What do we do with a Victorian senior pupil whose family moves to Adelaide to find the years at senior school are five, not six, and the courses and matriculation so different? When we drive through different States in a day should we really have different speed limits and rules? These issues need full and frank debate not in isolation but in cooperation, with the Commonwealth being the catalyst. From the Senate I hope to work towards making Australia a country free of some of that bureaucratic nightmare of different rules and regulations that is stifling and inhibiting free enterprise in this country. That is not taking away States rights. It is saying, `We are one country; let us be one country'.

In the Senate I also hope to work towards paring down costly Federal and State duplication in the big spending areas of health, education and housing. We can no longer afford to have massive Federal and State government departments undertaking basically the same work. It is a vital issue and surely we are old enough and mature enough to accept that we ought to tackle the issue. Bureaucratic duplication must be reviewed. Doing so will provide much greater efficiency in the delivery of such services. Instead of having governments anxious to maintain and extend their spheres of responsibilities, we must have a comprehensive and cooperative attempt to eliminate administrative duplication.
