We must be one Australia. We must be one nation. That does not mean listening to scare tactics which talk about grabbing all power to a central source based in Canberra; it is a two-way street. It means deciding on the right tier of government for the appropriate service delivery. The end result has to be a better country for all Australians. It means Canberra and the States working together to identify those areas of cost-cutting. We are living in times when politicians are constantly urging electors to tighten their belts. In many instances the States have, but the Commonwealth has not, by example, tightened its belt to the same extent that it has expected and required the States to tighten theirs. We know that Australians are tired of being overgoverned, so we need to be sensible enough to deal with it.

As we go forward thinking of one Australia, we should be able to deal with the problem population pockets in the eastern States, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne. South Australia is one State which would benefit greatly from an increased population. It would benefit from economic decentralisation also. We have country towns and cities ripe for an injection of new blood. We have country towns and cities able to sustain new industry and being able to meet its infrastructure needs. But we have neither people growth nor industry growth. We need government strong enough to commit, to breaking down the monopoly of the eastern States. That area of economic decentralisation is one I want to follow during my time in the Senate.

I will also work towards changes which must be made to ensure a strong and understandable immigration policy. It is my view that South Australia suffers because today it receives just one-third of the share of immigrants that it welcomed 25 years ago. It receives just 4.1 per cent of new immigrants, half of what it should, on a per capita basis. Yet many politicians sit back and wonder at increasing resentment towards immigrants in the already overpopulated cities. How can we wonder when the problem has been created by a lack of broad vision and balanced judgment? Would we have such resentment if the families we welcomed to Australia had been spread more evenly across our nation? We took the easy way out, usually leaving those who wanted to head for our main cities of Sydney and Melbourne, where they claimed friends and distant relatives. That way, without any far-reaching structure for assimilation, we left them to sink or swim with other migrants.

The result in some instances has been enclaves and certainly resentment. Is that any way to welcome immigrants, to make immigrants feel Australian or to make Australians realise the long-term benefits of our immigration policy? To me, it sounds exactly the way to go for flashpoint confrontation. In the Senate I hope to work towards a fairer share of migrants for each State so that it is looked on as a national economic project rather than a State problem. At the same time as I am an advocate of a healthy immigration policy and believe that our 140,000 a year figure ought to be maintained, I also believe that, if we are to aim for a national identity for one Australia, changes need to be made, not to numbers but to methods and as much for the people yet to arrive as those who are already here.

I think we have to now admit that in accepting the tag of a multicultural society we have to a certain degree lost the feeling in the soul of being Australian. That has nothing to do with race or creed; it has a lot to do with saying, `welcome, we are pleased you have come to be part of Australia'. We have left it at that-full stop. We should have gone and we need to go much further. I see it as imperative for the future, if we are all to work together in trust and without fear, that immigrants should become Australian citizens. That is something I hope to work towards achieving. I also believe that for the sake of future generations born in Australia English should be compulsory for immigrants.

We need to build that love of a nation, that patriotism that the United States of America did so successfully from such a diverse group of migrants. It is abundantly clear that so far we have not managed that. It seems logical that those who wish to be part of us need to be seen to be giving of themselves as we work together for the future prosperity of our country. They can make that commitment by becoming citizens. If Australia is the country in which to build one's family and future, it is time to show willing to become true Australians. It means a change in psychological commitment. It is not a case of ignoring the individual customs of each country which have woven such a rich fabric through the Australian way of life and our country. These customs make us a true multicultural society and are to be admired and encouraged.

Migrants are isolated through language difficulties and enclaves because we have no decentralisation policy. So they are literally dumped where they can afford to fall. That should be neither admired not encouraged. I intend to push forward saying, `Let us not forget the future of one's birthland or the culture of one's birthland but let us also be one Australia; let us work together as Australians, not as Scots, not as Greeks, not as Vietnamese who happen to be paying the same taxes in the one country'. I am also saying, `Let us have the courage to debate the immigration issues now without fear of being labelled racist or bigoted and before they reach a flashpoint where the wrong decisions may well be taken'.

While it may be true that we have never at any time had the majority of Australians in favour of immigration policy, perhaps we need to recognise that such policies may never have been explained properly. Ignorance breeds fear. So it is surely government's duty to explain so that knowledge, not ignorance, can be the basis for debate. I have a belief that a healthy immigration policy and a healthy economy go together. Our immigration methods so far, like those which have left us with a fragmented and duplicated legislation, have happened rather than evolved.

I look forward to my years in Canberra. I look forward to being able to make a positive contribution to this Senate and to the Parliament of Australia. If, in my time in the Senate, I can work towards a fairer distribution of government contracts in Australia, the removal, fragmentation and duplication in our legislation, the revival of the Murray-Darling, and the need for decentralisation of our population, and am also able to help keep alive my belief in a strong and considered immigration policy, I will feel that I will be doing what I was nominated to do here: that is, to work for the benefit of Australia, and South Australia in particular. I hope that I can help achieve the government Australia so badly wants and needs-one of broad vision and balanced judgment-so that we can go forward to economic prosperity, growth with style and, above all else, do so with compassion and harmony in Australia.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second time that it falls my happy lot to speak in the Appropriation debate immediately after a maiden speech. The last time I did so was after Senator Vanstone's maiden speech and, as she had ceased being a maiden when she sat down, I felt that she was fair game for contribution from my side. I draw the Senate's attention to some of Senator Olsen's remarks. As they were made in a maiden speech, we listened with dignity, but I certainly take issue with him on some points. However, we congratulate him and welcome him into this place and will keep him on his toes on behalf of South Australia. In terms of economy decentralisation, I am sure that Senator Olsen would want to support the Government's decision to place the submarine project in South Australia-an excellent example of decentralisation to the benefit of South Australia.
—Ha, ha!

—I thank Senator Puplick. I thought it would get a cheer from somewhere. As for the Murray-Darling River, the Government is addressing that issue. In fact, it is a fine and famous South Australian as far as I am concerned, the past member but one for Hawker, Ralph Jacobi, one of those South Australians who endlessly pushed for a change in approach to the Murray River and now for the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission to incorporate both complex river systems and deal with the problems confronting people living along them. Those of us in South Australia know full well the contribution of our New South Welsh and Victorian colleagues because we get to drink it. Fortunately they filter it, but nobody living in South Australia is unaware of the importance of clean, good water because we do not have it.

SPEECH.PARA: Water is a challenge for our State and is the prime concern of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. There is also the salinity problem and the problems of the death of growth either side of the river, the complexity of farming and the chemicals needed to maintain growth and produce. The new Murray-Darling Basin Commission is taking into account the importance of native vegetation and revegetation along those river complexes.

I suspect that we have a long way to go to understand water in Australia. We still do not understand what made it rain this year and not last year, nor yet what makes the rain fall where it does. For those of us who live in South Australia, the driest State in the driest continent, water is something we certainly think about.

The points that Senator Olsen raised are well worth our deliberation. No doubt from time to time we will remind him of what he has said-particularly all that stuff about duplication in appropriate arms of government in regard to doing things. I guess that is the nature of the sport here. One would also say, no doubt, that Senator Olsen is well placed to observe Federal and State differences. We will not say this today, but in the future we may well say, `But did you not in South Australia?'-and he can take it from there.

In my speech today I want to make a few comments under three headings and pick up on the challenge spelt out for us by the Labor Party during the election campaign and by the Governor-General in the Speech he made in this place-the challenge this country faces. That challenge has been spelt out in the Governor-General's Speech in terms of program and priority ordering of Government initiatives for the current term. In particular, the Governor-General-if not the Governor-General then certainly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-alluded to the importance of this society moving from seeing itself as a lucky country to becoming a clever country. I will use that heading to talk a little about the importance of the Government's education policies to this point, in particular its concerns in the area of science.

Before I elaborate, however, I want to highlight what we mean by a clever country or what we must mean. We have to make sure that when we say `clever' country we mean wise country. It is not sufficient to have people with lots of qualifications but no perspective on what those qualifications are for, nor what they address. Any country that is clever but that fails to be caring is in danger of being no better than just a lucky country. By using the words `clever country' we are talking about taking a sense of direction for our own people rather than just benefiting from the good luck that has befallen us to this point. It is very important that the people of Australia appreciate their responsibility for the control, management and care of this country. In particular, it must have care for its people. It is not very clever to be uncaring or to disregard consequences. We have come to that time in our history when the things this community has done over the last 150 to 200 years can no longer be conveniently ignored.

One area that we must face-and I think we are facing it-is the massive disregard for, indeed the acts of cruelty practised on, Aboriginal people. If ever there is a shame this country has to admit, it is that. That is not part of a clever or lucky or wise or caring country. I am pleased to be part of a government that will not tolerate that kind of treatment, abuse or ignorance of its Aboriginal people any more.

Our community still has to come to terms with what we mean by science and what our attitude is to science. We are in two minds about it. We appreciate very much that science is the solution. Science is clever, to be admired, to be appreciated and to be paid for. But at the same time many of us, indeed most of us in the chamber, can say, `But science has also caused the problems'. So we have a great degree of scepticism or suspicion about things scientific.

We talk about the importance of using science to address the problems of environmental pollution; but the greatest pollution this world has known in nuclear weapons. They are clearly the creation of science-perhaps the ill-direction of the achievements of science. But there is no doubt that it is the scientists of this world who have created these things for us, and to this point they have not been asked sufficiently to address the consequences of some of those scientific decisions. We have also seen the benefits and now the enormously damaging consequences of the industrial revolution-the smokestacks and the polluted water; the dirty air and the poisoned ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in the regulated economies of the Eastern bloc.

—I am interested that Senator Michael Baume has interjected in that way. No country can be complacent. There is no virtue in saying that we are cleaner than them, when we are filthy. There is no point in saying that they are dirtier than us-that the Eastern bloc is filthy. It was not the Eastern bloc that poisoned the Great Lakes in North America; it did not bring that pollution on us. It was not the Eastern bloc that had to pay for cleaning up the Thames River, which was polluted over many years. We know who did it. There is no point in Senator Baume attempting that cheap point scoring. He highlights just one of the problems. Senator Olsen was just asking for a bipartisan, bilateral approach to these things. Senator Baume has just shown that his mind is not directed in that way. There is no virtue in working out that we are less evil or more wholesome. What we have to do is define the problems, and the problems are very large.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems have been created by science and now will be solved by science-at least by the wise application of things. But again, we have to be cautious in what we are talking about. We need to be clearer in our definitions. I believe this community is still a little puzzled about what is meant by science-whether it is a good thing or a thing to be suspicious of. That debate is still ahead of us. It requires extensive community education and clear definitions. It also needs to look at the place of science in the scheme of things. For example, I find it very disappointing that if we talk science we are in danger of talking anti-art-that we have a separation of things scientific and things artistic. I do not believe that distinction is valid or useful. Certainly, it is something that we should cease to promote. The breaking off in our thinking of things scientific from things artistic-of things that are human and compassionate and caring-creates precisely the sorts of difficulties that have led to some of the problems we now confront.

I highlight this because of a recent visit to the National Science and Technology Centre, a place of sheer joy and delight. Anybody who walks in finds him or herself caught up in the excitement and interest of finding out about all sorts of things that go on in our community and, in a way that makes the scientific principles, the mathematical principles, underpinning that very accessible. It also highlights the excitement of knowledge for almost anybody who has the opportunity to meet it. Indeed, I hope that our educational system will continue to develop the sense of wonder and excitement in finding out about things.

I certainly strongly endorse the intention and the practice of the National Science and Technology Centre. I think that encouragement for our young people, let alone our old people, to appreciate science and mathematics has to be put into this debate about where science is in our world, what it can do for us and, at same time, the excitement of science also has to be qualified by its appropriate use. We cannot go on totally believing in science or totally opposing it. I believe we have to pick up on the benefits and the excitement of things scientific and develop that into a constructive debate in our community over the next number of years.

One of the things that science brings to mind is the endless discussion about how women are not able to do science. In times past they were defined as not having sufficient or appropriate brains. I probably have not put on the record in the Senate-but I have certainly said it in many other places-that the opposition to women studying or getting to learn at all has been a battle that women have fought over the last couple of hundred years. In Victoria in the late nineteenth century very senior men in the community argued that if women went to university their uteruses would shrivel. That is a matter of the utter nonsense. I do not think Senator Newman or I would like to paraphrase that or even turn it around. We would be laughed out of school for suggesting such a crazy thought. Yet that is the kind of attitude that women have had to contend with in claiming their place in educational institutions and their opportunity to learn and be educated in our society.

Indeed, I think the struggle still goes on. It is partly emphasised by the claim at the moment-it is still very current that girls are not good enough to do maths and science, they do not really have the right approach, and they do not think in a logical and coherent way. I urge honourable senators who are faintly of that view to go to the National Science and Technology Centre and visit the mathematical room. They will notice huge posters on the wall highlighting famous mathematicians down time. Every second poster features women who have made great contributions to mathematics over the centuries. The interesting thing is that women have made contributions but they are not acknowledged in our history books, classrooms, or in our public forums. It is time we actually pull those names out into the public arena and make sure that they become as much household names as any of the men who have contributed to mathematics. I will resist the temptation to cite some names because I do not think I can remember all of them, but I urge people who have the view that women are not good enough to have a look at their contributions.

I also draw the Senate's attention to two women in science organisations that I know about, one is Wisnet, Women in Science Network and the other is WIMS, Women in Medical Science. Both of those organisations have a huge number of very qualified women at all sorts of levels of scientific endeavour and yet they are still not publicly known or acknowledged and their talents are not drawn upon quite often. I think we know that women are able. We have to appreciate that still more encouragement should be given to our girls in primary and secondary schools to take up scientific and mathematical careers if they have the slightest interest in them. I suspect that, left to themselves, many young girls will follow those careers.

In conclusion, and by way of justification for this case, I recently attended the mathematical and computer science prize night at the University of Adelaide. I went partly because one of the prize winners was one of my sons, but I was also delighted to note that 50 per cent of the prizes that night in computing and mathematics went to girls. They were achieving at the highest level in all four years of undergraduate mathematics and computer science and in the honours years. We do have that ability amongst our young girls, as well as our young men. I think that in encouraging further participation in science for our girls we will see a new and extending contribution to the scientific debate into the next decade.

From speaking about girls and science I am pleased to move to the media and the media images of our society as presented to us, particularly in terms of shaping our view of ourselves. Senator Newman is quoted as saying in Portfolio magazine in November last year that she thought in times of economic constraint it was not appropriate to be funding women in sport or worrying about how the media portrayed women. I strongly take issue with Senator Newman on both of those points. If she wanted to argue that sports expenditure was not appropriate at this time, why not cut back funding for both men and women in sport; why pick out women's sport? I think that is a quite inappropriate action and is totally unjustified. Who has won more gold medals for this country? The answer, of course, is women. So women's contribution in sport is absolutely splendid and until recently they had not enjoyed adequate funding or media coverage.

In terms of the media portrayal of women, I think it is absolutely vital that we continue to argue for a fair, reasonable and proper reflection in our media of all the capacities, abilities, and achievements of our women. As the Senate knows, I have certainly fought for a fair representation of women in the media in the area of sport-I have fought in other areas as well-and I know and appreciate the trivialisation, let alone the insufficiency, of the coverage of women in sport. Lest any honourable senator doubt that, I refer them to the recent Stuart Littlemore Media Watch program. He ran my argument very splendidly with wonderful pictures pointing out that if members of the media still want to cover women in sport they can do that only by trivialising or making a joke of it. The media portrayal of our society is very important; the media portrayal of our women is equally as important. If we are to understand the sort of society we live in, and if we do want to advance and understand what it means to be a clever, comparing, compassionate society, we have to ask the media to begin to reflect a whole range of images and not a limited or insufficient selection of them.

While flying the other day, I read a very interesting interview in The Australian Way, a magazine of Australian Airlines Ltd, with Sister Veronica Brady. Many honourable senators would know that she is a lecturer in English at the University of Western Australia. She is also on the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Many of us have been interested to hear or read her views over the years. She is a thoughtful, provocative and splendidly challenging person. She has an extensive view of what society means when it talks about itself, what it means to reflect on society, what sorts of values and attitudes a compassionate society would hold up and what sorts of views Australians would say they were proud of in talking about themselves. I commend this article to people to read. It is a very nifty little summary and has some very useful views. In particular, I was interested in the following quote:
In the Brady view, Australia's self-perception is shaped by the media. And therein lies the greatest difficulty in bringing about change.
`The media monopoly in Australia is profoundly disturbing', she argues. `Since there are only two or three sources, we are told whatever they want us to know'.

The result, says Veronica Brady, is an Australia which sees the outside world through American-European eyes and which is astonishingly ignorant of its own culture and the injustices on its own doorstep.

I do not want to pick up all those points, but I do take the point that Australia's self-perception is very significantly shaped by the media. Indeed, we have to make sure that we keep an eye on the media so that it presents an ever-extending view of Australia's range of talents, the issues that Australians want to raise, and the sorts of people Australia is home to. We should be looking for diversity and a recognition of our range of talents and skills. We should be asking the media to reflect those aspects of Australia, to pick up on the proposals for Labor's fourth term which are contained in the Governor-General's Speech and to indicate what sort of country we are and will become.

I want to highlight some of the Government's policy commitments in the Speech, particularly those relating to women, not just because women are a separate category but because in the past women have been talked about so little that they are not yet adequately reflected in the media's image of Australia or, indeed, in Australia's understanding of itself. The Prime Minister said in another place-I can only paraphrase him-that any country that ignores or overlooks 51 per cent of its people's intelligence, imagination and energy is taking a very big risk and is certainly being very wasteful. Our Government is no longer prepared to do that. With the national agenda for women and particular policies about women, those women with talent, energy, initiative and imagination are being given the opportunity to take their place in the mainstream of Australian society.

The Government's policies for women come under two headings-the ones that benefit women generally and the ones that specifically benefit women. Quite clearly, the economic policies of this Government, which have brought about a dramatic increase in employment, have been of great benefit to women. More than 50 per cent of those jobs have gone to women, and for the first time there is a more than 50 per cent participation rate by women in the labour force. The number of women in our tertiary institutions has risen to 50 per cent plus. We have seen the benefits to society of that unlocking of talent and opportunity. Certainly we see the benefits to women, who in a different way now feel responsible and responsive to their community. I appreciate too the importance of child-care in the Government's strategy for economic restructuring and for rights and opportunities for women. Indeed, the child-care program spoken of in the Governor-General's Speech is a very significant extra development and commitment to the child-care policy that was put in place in the last Budget.

The extra 50,000 community child-care places to be provided by 1995-96 over and above the commitment of 30,000 in last year's Budget certainly makes absolutely clear, beyond any doubt, the Government's commitment to child-care: all this because of its appreciation of the importance of accessible, affordable quality child-care as being critical to families, and in particular women, who want to exercise their opportunities to study, to work and to do a whole variety of things that previously they were not able to do without that child-care assistance.

The Government has also proposed an extension of fee relief to private child-care centres. This will bring on stream a significant increase in the number of places for people who are still looking for access to child-care. Associated with the extension of fee relief will be the requirement for accreditation of all child-care centres so that we can be sure that all child-care places meet minimum standards of adequacy and quality. This is absolutely critical and something those of us on the Government side have been insistent about since child-care first got on to the political agenda.

We need to talk about some of the items specific to women, particularly the ratification of the International Labour Organisation Convention 156 relating to workers with family responsibilities. Quite clearly, that is not limited to women, but it has significant relevance to women in the work force. We appreciate the ratification of this convention as it relates to the rights of workers in the work place and access to child-care. It is interesting that the other day Senator Cook answered a question from Senator Zakharov spelling out just how that is being developed and what further steps will be taken to ensure that Australia conforms to the intent of that convention.

The Government is also concerned about and committed to extending our national school curriculum-partly to deal with points raised by Senator Olsen, though he has not been the first to raise them-so that there is some understanding of the relevance of five-year-olds, 10-year-olds or 16-year-olds moving across State borders. I and my colleagues-Senator Zakharov being one who is in this place at the moment-have put this matter on our education agenda on a number of occasions. Indeed, they are issues that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has already addressed and will continue to address. As well, we have argued that any educational curriculum has to be expanded to make it particularly relevant to girls and young women.

We have also highlighted the total unacceptability of domestic violence. But we have some years to go before society changes its view in large enough numbers so that domestic violence becomes totally unacceptable. Indeed, it is Senator Tate, who is in the chamber at the moment, who is responsible for overseeing the inquiry into violence. This inquiry has taken its own course and gone places that some proposing it were not expecting it to go. It is a remarkable examination of a dimension of our society that perhaps we have not wanted to face up to in times past. Despite changes there are many places where violence occurs more frequently than anyone finds acceptable.

The inquiry into violence in sport took many people by surprise. They were quite shocked that the inquiry looked at sport. We have seen some very bizarre and some very reasonable arguments about the importance of what sport reflects. This particularly relates to my earlier point about the metaphors, its symbolism in our society. Sport is a very important ingredient in how a society sees itself.

Indeed, that inquiry into violence has challenged our sport to see just how violent it has been-if not now, at least in the past-and to make sure it continues to reduce the gratuitous violence in sport and to appreciate that it is no longer an acceptable attitude or standard in our society. Much more has to be done in changing attitudes about domestic violence. Though a number of us would argue that it is totally unacceptable, surveys still show that while attitudes are changing we have a long way to go before we can expect that society regards domestic violence with total abhorrence.

Earlier I mentioned the benefits of science. Last week I spoke to Home Births Australia. I was interested to be reminded that there are places where science really ought to advance very slowly. We have actually turned something as normal and as natural as childbirth into a highly medical and technological event, which is contrary to what most pregnant women find appropriate. Indeed, there have been some quite worrying statistics about the number of medical interventions in the childbirth process. These were reported in a New South Wales Government inquiry last year. While we should look at where science in Australia is going, we should not forget to take with us those things that are of benefit and which have been tested over time. Whether they are traditional, whether they are family inheritances, whether they are tried and tested methods and schemes, whether they are ways of presenting challenges, treatments or managements to the next generation, we must make sure that we do not sell our souls to technology but try to incorporate the best of both worlds.

I hope that further analysis of statistics will help people in the childbirth area to return childbirth to those who manage it best-the mothers. We appreciate the assistance of medical technology-preferably, though, only when it is needed, not as a matter of course. I look forward to this term in government to see implemented not only these ideas but also the full program of reform as outlined by the Governor-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. During her speech Senator Crowley purported to paraphrase from an interview which I gave last year with Portfolio magazine in which she gave us to understand that I said that in difficult economic times the Government should not be spending money on women's sport or on the portrayal of women in advertising. She gave the impression that I was being discriminatory vis-a-vis women's sport and funding for men's sport.

SPEECH.PARA: That is far from the case. My view is consistent and it is non-discriminatory. My view is that spending on sport for men and women and the portrayal of men as sex objects are all serious matters. My view is that in difficult economic times, there must be priorities in government spending and they must be carefully set. If the Government believes that to spend $43m on women's sport, or men's sport for that matter, is a priority--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Newman claims that she has been misrepresented. Leave of the Senate was given so that she could tell the Senate just how she was misrepresented. I think she has done that. She is now proceeding to raise matters that were not raised in the excellent speech by Senator Crowley. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to ask the honourable senator to resume her seat.

—It is quite obvious that Senator Newman has been grossly misrepresented. She has given the reasons for the misrepresentation. She is quite entitled to explain briefly her own view and to put her position in the correct perspective.

—On the point of order: that is exactly what I was trying to do. In fact, I was coming to a conclusion. I could have concluded by now. I was simply setting the record straight as to what is actually my view.
—Senator Newman, have you completed your personal explanation?
—Almost.
—That is not what Senator Newman said. It may be her view, but it is not what she said. I did not misquote or misrepresent her.

—My view is that if the Government believes that to spend $43m on women's sport, or men's sport for that matter, or to spend anything on the portrayal of women in advertising is a priority and that only $3m should be spent on the detection of breast cancer, it needs to be strongly condemned.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is not true that Senator Newman is now explaining her point of view. It is true that Senator Newman is now debating the issue as evidenced by the fact that when I raised the point of order she did not resume her seat immediately. She went on to try to conclude her point of view and the debate. Since she has assured you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that she was actually going to put her view, it is very poor behaviour by her to then debate the issue.
—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I have concluded and I did stick to stating my view in simple terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must assure Senator Newman in passing, that nobody has ever treated me as a sex object, perhaps more is the pity. This afternoon we are dealing with a number of Bills-the Appropriation and Supply Bills. Before dealing with several specific matters which arise out of those Bills, I would like to make some general remarks in relation to the cast of both the Government's and the Opposition's economic policies because recently there has been a great deal of talk about a recession. The Opposition has sought to use the technical observation of `three terms of no growth in the economy' as a basis for the claim that the economy is in recession and, by implication, that the Government is a bad manager and the country is heading for disaster. The converse is also implied, that is, `if the economy was growing, we would not be in a recession and we would be okay'.

SPEECH.PARA: Neither the Government, the Opposition nor the economic commentators in the media seem to be aware that a large number of things which enter the calculus of growth of gross domestic product (GDP) are costs and not benefits. Despite the fact that this has been repeatedly pointed out in this chamber, many senators and most economic commentators seem completely unaware that in the measurement of economic growth we are looking at the growth of GDP. Included in GDP are many things which are costs and not benefits.

All commentators seem to have become so besotted with the index-the measurement of this index and whether the index is rising or falling-that they have forgotten that there is no clear nexus between the index and human welfare. It is the latter around which the economy should be based-not whether the GDP index is going up or down, but whether the quality of life and the welfare of people in this country are improving or not.

Some senators may remember a question I asked of Senator Walsh more than 12 months ago in relation to motor vehicle accidents. I asked him where the costs-I stress the word `costs'-of these accidents appear in the national accounts. After explaining that the costs of these accidents are added to gross domestic product-in other words, gross domestic product is increased by the amount which is spent on repairing the damage to humans and to property caused by these accidents-Senator Walsh went on to recount how removing these costs from gross domestic product `may start a spiral in which the whole of the gross domestic product gradually disappeared'-the very point that I wanted established in that question.

In a like manner, as Sydney and other rapidly growing Australian cities expand and the new arrivals travel ever greater distances to work on increasingly expensive roads, these costs-I stress `costs'-borne by ordinary people, and correctly perceived by them as costs, are added to the national accounts and cause the index-gross domestic product-to grow. A growing economy is not necessarily one which better serves the needs of its citizens. Conversely, an economy in which gross domestic product is falling is not necessarily one in which the lot of ordinary people is being compromised.

As our cities grow, the cost of providing a whole range of services to people on the periphery of those already large cities increases disproportionately. The costs of generating electricity from suppliers of fuel which are ever further distant, transporting that electricity over greater distances, and reticulating it on the periphery of an already large city increase disproportionately. They are perceived as costs by ordinary people, but they enter the national accounts as an addition to the gross domestic product so the economy appears to grow.

I was a bit disappointed to hear Senator Olsen's remarks earlier in relation to the size of Adelaide. At present Adelaide is suffering very acutely from extremely poor quality water which is very expensive. For some months this year massive algal blooms on Lake Alexandrina have prevented the use of that water by local residents. Even farmers have been unable to use the water for cattle. Yet the costs of providing at least potable, safe water, in bacteriological terms, for the citizens of Adelaide add to the gross domestic product. Therefore, they enter the national accounts as an index of growth. I do not think anybody in this chamber would believe that the people of Adelaide are better off because of growth of that sort.

Conversely, if we introduced measures to improve the efficiency with which we generate electricity, the `contribution' which electricity generation makes to gross domestic product might fall substantially. I do not think anybody would argue that we were worse off because gross domestic product had fallen as a result of our using electricity much more efficiently.

So overreliance on this one index disguises a lot that is wrong with the allocation of resources. Money spent on buildings is added to GDP. The more we spend as a nation, the greater the `contribution' which the building industry makes to economic growth. But GDP-even per capita GDP-tells one nothing about the equity of this activity, the equity of building. It is said that about one in every six central business district buildings throughout Australia is unoccupied. There has been furious activity in all the central business districts throughout Australia for some years. Indeed, visit any Australian city at the present time and one sees the skyline festooned with cranes-not of the bird variety but of the mechanical variety-something which the South Australian Minister for Tourism says she rather enjoys seeing. One wonders about the shape of the cranes and whether there is some interesting pleasure that she gets from seeing them.

Meanwhile, there is an acute shortage of housing for ordinary Australians. We have considerable building activity, which is adding to gross domestic product, but we have an acute shortage of housing for ordinary Australians. Indeed, Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia and the National President of the Australian Labor Party, was speaking only over the weekend of having urban ghettos in Adelaide if more is not spent on public housing. He went on to point out that 40,000 people are on waiting lists for public housing in South Australia.

Whether the economy grows or not tells us not one thing about the distribution, equity or fairness of building activity which contributes to that growth. I believe that the cause of the housing problem is not to be found in the growth or non-growth of gross domestic product but in the Government's adherence, with Opposition support, to a deregulatory `leave it to the market' approach.

Again, I was interested to hear Senator Olsen speaking about the desirability of decentralisation and pointing out, as did the Premier of South Australia at the weekend, that Sydney was overcrowded. I am not too sure how he is going to regulate the movement of immigrants into Australia; I would have thought that it was self-evident that people who come into this country are free to move to where they wish, and it would be quite untenable and reprehensible to attempt to direct people into particular areas. I also point out that the second Dunstan Government in South Australia was the Government which bought the area at Monarto-the only serious attempt at decentralisation in this country in recent decades-and that it was Dunstan's successor, the former Liberal Premier of South Australia, who dismantled that project and resold the land at Monarto. So I was disappointed to hear his remarks in relation to decentralisation, in view of that history.

Returning to the point about the market system-much welcomed and desired by both the Government and the Opposition-economists and members of the Government and the Opposition have assumed for too long that the abstracted world of the market is coterminous with both the natural world and the real world of people. The market may be an efficient instrument for the allocation of resources, but it is not necessarily fair or equitable. Efficiency is determined by price-quite clearly, that is how economists have to calculate it-for only by rendering all things into dollar amounts can apples and oranges or houses for people and empty office blocks for speculating entrepreneurs be compared and judged. Human or environmental qualities that cannot be specified in dollars are judged by this system to be either irrelevant or, worse, non-existent.

As I have said before in debates in this general area, it is not just that the Government spends too much here or not enough there; there is a fundamental flaw in the way the Government thinks about the economy. That flaw is shared by the Opposition. It is most unfortunate that the Government's claimed success at `educating' the public in matters economic has, in reality, been successful in hiding the real world behind a great deal of economic mumbo jumbo.

It was interesting to hear the Governor-General's Speech at the opening of this Parliament, because frequently throughout the course of the previous Parliament we heard spokespeople for the Government speaking about sustainable growth. After repeatedly writing to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others pointing out that sustainable growth is an oxymoron, I listened very carefully to the Governor-General's Speech and, despite the fact that there was a great deal of discussion on various economic matters, not once did the Governor-General talk about economic growth, much less about sustainable growth. Perhaps the understanding that there is an absolute contradiction between sustainability and economic growth is slowly percolating into the heads of some Government Ministers.

For a clearer understanding of economic reality-and I am referring here to the claimed success by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of educating the public in matters economic-I suggest that honourable senators read Professor Herman Daly's most recent book entitled For The Common Good: Redirecting the Economy Toward Community, the Environment and a Sustainable Future. I point out that Professor Daly is professor of economics at Louisiana State University and a senior economist in the environment department of the World Bank.

Turning specifically to some of the detail of these Bills before us, I note that this year is International Literacy Year. After paying lip-service to the need and desirability of literacy and, indeed, after an extensive advertising campaign encouraging those with literacy problems to seek help, this Government has not provided funds which will allow people to receive that help. Money spent on education by government is clearly seen as a cost whereas the Democrats believe-and we have pointed this out repeatedly-that education should be seen as an investment in the future of this country.

I notice under the appropriation for education that in 1989-90 there is an additional expenditure of $2m and a further additional expenditure of $40m for adult migration education. While this is welcomed, it must be seen against the fact that, while some 68 per cent of non-Aboriginal students now complete year 12, only 18 per cent of Aboriginal students are so successful. We would certainly like to see a great deal more funding, and more effective funding, going into Aboriginal education programs.

In another matter, the Australian Democrats have consistently attempted to increase the support for those Australians who suffer disability. Indeed, Senator Macklin in particular has repeatedly sought the removal of sales tax on computers adapted for use by disabled people. All senators will recall that he has put up amendments in that area on a number of occasions and each time that proposal has been defeated. It is heartening to see that the Government is providing an extra $22m for assistance to people with disabilities. But in this same appropriation an extra $239m is provided for the Department of Defence. One wonders again about the priorities of this Government when 10 times as much is spent in an area which ultimately, if ever used, will produce much greater levels of disability while such a small amount is spent on treating disabilities themselves.

I would like to turn to another area now, that is, the area of disaster relief. In Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, $25m is provided for what is described as natural disaster relief. Again, I have some difficulty with this word `natural'. These disasters are in no sense natural. They would not be disasters if humans had not intruded into these environments. They would be natural occurrences and they become disasters because human beings happen to be in the way of those events. The Minister's speech makes clear that `the bulk of the assistance is in respect of the recent floods in New South Wales and Queensland'.

Australia is a country in which the chief characteristic of the weather is its unpredictability. We live in a country notoriously subject to drought, bushfire and flood. For most areas of Australia we now have over 100 years of records showing the return times of these-here is the word again-natural disasters and an indication of the costs involved. The proposal I want to mention here is that, rather than set money aside on an ad hoc basis when these disasters occur, it should be possible to create a permanent fund out of which these relief costs could be borne and, thus, smooth out the costs of disaster relief over time. It is especially important, I believe, to clarify and regulate the circumstances for the relief of damage costs associated with these occurrences.

I would like to briefly detail the history of what has happened in South Australia in relation to the two Ash Wednesday bushfires. As most honourable senators will know, there have been two bushfires on Ash Wednesdays-one in 1980 and the other in 1983-in South Australia. The first was found by a coroner to be caused by a fire burning in a rubbish dump used by the Stirling District Council, and the fire getting out of control on a day of high temperature and very strong north winds. Tens of millions of dollars worth of damage were caused and neither the Council nor the owners and operators of the dump had insurance sufficient to cover the damage. The State, unfortunately in retrospect, did not declare the fire a disaster.

Those affected by the fire have fought for 10 years to reclaim costs from the Stirling Council and, indeed, partly from the owners of the dump. The claims have essentially bankrupted the Council. The lack of an established procedure has resulted in a great deal of unresolved anguish all round. Indeed, many millions of dollars and an enormous amount of time have been spent in legal wrangles in relation to responsibility, claims of negligence, counterclaims that those operating the dump and the Council were not negligent, and so on and so forth, all of which has reflected very harshly on the people who in many cases lost everything they owned.
The second South Australian Ash Wednesday fires-and I say `fires' in the

Insurance companies have traditionally called these acts of God-a rather peculiar term which I find a somewhat disparaging reflection on the Almighty. Under these circumstances it would seem appropriate to limit to a reasonably foreseeable level the amount of insurance cover required by individuals and companies to protect against these occurrences, and for a national disaster fund to be created as insurance cover against the additional cost. The way of settling these matters in times when one of these so-called natural disasters occurs would be quite clearly set up and established beforehand. A reasonable level of insurance cover would be borne by the individual and perhaps a further level might be borne by State utilities-in this case, the Electricity Trust of South Australia might be required to carry a certain level of insurance-but beyond that, because the particular outcomes of these circumstances is beyond the control of the owner of the initiating cause, those extra costs should be picked up through a natural disaster relief fund.

I believe that actuarial data already available should allow a calculation to be made as to how much the Federal Government would need to set aside each year. As I indicated earlier, this would smooth the cost of dealing with these things so that, instead of having some years when there would be no costs borne and other years when very heavy costs might be borne, the costs could be smoothed out over time. This procedure would surely be easier than the ad hoc arrangements and, indeed, the very socially damaging arrangements which obtain at the present time for meeting the costs of these national disasters.

Finally, I turn briefly to the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91. We have recently been dealing in this place with the regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act. Honourable senators will recall that these regulations were disallowed on a motion from the Democrats, supported by the Opposition. One of the points that was briefly made in the disallowance speeches was that the costs to be borne by those who sought to have therapeutic goods registered or listed and the costs in relation to inspection of premises and so on would sit unfairly on some of the manufacturers of therapeutic goods.

It was interesting, having dealt with that matter so recently, to turn to this Supply Bill (No. 1). In the discussions leading to the setting of those charges and fees it was stated that the costs of administering this scheme were be be approximately $30m, and that the Government had arbitrarily set the cost for recovery at 50 per cent. In other words, it was expecting industry to pick up approximately $15m and the Government would pick up $15m of the costs.

If we turn to Supply Bill (No. 1) we find that there is information which says that $11.1m is to be provided for the administration of therapeutic goods legislation. I point out that this legislation was clearly drawn up before the regulations were disallowed. The regulations envisaged that this Act and its regulations would come into operation on 1 July, so there is no question that we are not dealing with a full year's costs and cost recovery. In setting the fees to be paid by those covered by the therapeutic goods legislation, the Department claimed that it would recover half the costs; and as these expenses were expected to be $30m, half the cost would be $15m. We have now learnt that the departmental running costs are expected to be $11.1m, almost $4m less than was told to the therapeutic goods suppliers. It would seem from the information contained in the Supply Bill (No. 1) that the Government has somewhat overestimated the overall costs; it certainly overestimated its own portion. Presumably, if we are looking at 50 per cent cost recovery, there can be a substantial cut in the fees to be charged to those who are seeking registration of therapeutic goods while still staying within that formula of a 50 : 50 split.

In summary, I point out that, while it is interesting to look at the detail of these Appropriation and Supply Bills, the main thing that one observes in looking at the Bills is a continuation of an economic model which is based on a misconception of the true nature of society and the needs of society. It is based on an economic model which, as I said earlier, assumes that the abstracted model is the same as the real world-that the abstracted model can deal with the environment because the model is synonymous with the environment; that the abstracted model can deal with human welfare because human society is totally described by the model. That, indeed, is a fallacy. Humans are far more than economic units which relate to each other through market forces. We relate in much more complex ways than that. Attempting to deal with people in that way, as this Government has done and indeed as this Opposition would do even more firmly, not only is wrong but is not going to lead to the improvement in human welfare, improvement in the protection of the quality of the environment, which the Australian Democrats seek.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the debate on the Appropriation and Supply Bills I want to make some comments on Australia's future directions in light of both Government and Opposition policies which seem to promise, at best, a piecemeal approach which is disappointing because ad hoc decisions are inadequate to meet the challenges facing not only Australians, but the global community. The greening of Australian politics is a gradual process that is now firmly entrenched in both State and Federal parliaments. In Western Australia, we have achieved political unity within the Greens movement and we will show other political parties what real grassroots democracy is all about by putting the community needs first on the Federal parliamentary agenda. The Western Australian Greens will turn Green philosophy into political reality-a task that will involve the greening of industry, unions and government as quickly as possible to catch up with the high level of community awareness. The success of the Tasmanian Greens is a role model for other States.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a historic time for the Australian Parliament and for Australian politics at all three levels of government as more independents and non-major party representatives, such as the Australian Democrats, appeal to the electorate. I am happy to continue the work towards linking the environment and the economy in political terms, as the Australian Democrats have worked towards that end as well, and I look forward to continuing cooperatively in that process. Globally, members of the European Economic Community joined in the Green debate many years before the environmental crisis became part of the everyday parlance in Australia. The grassroots Greens movement was instrumental in the western European process of awareness of the urgent need for action. This awareness led to an acknowledgment of the Dickensian industries and terrible pollution of eastern Europe. Concern about this, of course, has been a very significant factor leading to the rapid process of democratisation in many countries in the Eastern bloc.

The Australian Government now has a chance to take a leading role through acknowledging the link between the environment and the economy, rather than continuing to depend on growth economics based on ripping up and exporting primary resources and a reliance on the old order with all its attendant environmental problems and social inequalities. The Government, bureaucracy, industry and the wider community must acknowledge that we do not inherit the earth and its resources from our parents; that we merely borrow it from our children. If the path of unfettered economic growth and industrialisation continues, in economic terms we are borrowing against the capital of the earth-a price neither the Australian public nor the global community can afford.

The Western Australian Greens are working on a new sustainable economic order which incorporates the conservation ethic through a Green budget. Sustainability is about radical changes to lifestyle and challenging the present cancerous rate of consumerism. A Green budget will have a macro-economic perspective but it will also come down to individual responsibility and a new ethical structure for the individual and community. The existing monetarist policies on both the left and right of the political spectrum do not adequately address the environmental crisis or our moral bankruptcy and lack of community spirit.

The Australian Government has not made the hard decisions on the environment. It has made reactionary and populist decisions that the Greens are thankful for but which we see as largely piecemeal. The political agenda for this Parliament, established in the Governor-General's Speech, was to make Australia the clever country rather than the lucky country by funding export oriented science and technologies and boosting employment and training in this area. Traditional science is not the answer, as aware scientists like David Suzuki have told us. When will the Australian Government listen?

Let us look at the history of the nuclear and genetic industries which have through their amoral and technocratic nature got the industrialised world into a fix. We are pumping radioactive wastes into our environment and we are tampering with human embryos. Where will the future take us from here?

I take exception to the Australian Government's belief that science and technology is the best or only way to go. Once again, the Government is demonstrating its shortsightedness and dependence on free market forces without a holistic ecological and social perspective. Ecocare is not just a buzz word of the moment. It means communal approach to sustainable economics and environmental care, an underlying ethical structure which will link global communities from east to west. If our Government continues in its monetarist vein, I shudder to think of the global damage that the underdeveloped world could inflict if it takes the path that Australia has chosen. The cumulative effects of accelerated use of energy and resources cannot be sustained at the present rate. This is not supposition but a fact.

A communal response to the environmental crisis is what is needed based on a new ethical structure which will carry over into government and industry. The Green vision for the future is based on grassroots democracy, social justice, environmental custodianship, disarmament and non-violence. This is a holistic vision for a planet in crisis. It is an exciting process because it is about individual empowerment which can lead to massive and urgently needed changes. If we were to acknowledge the spiritual unity of the Aboriginal community with its so-called economic capital-that is land, water, air and forests-we of the developed-industrialised world would learn of the importance of an ethical structure which sees the environment as an intrinsic part of existence and not solely, or even mainly, as a means of making profit.

The social inequalities of our society with its immense poverty, continued environmental degradation, the alienation of the individual in an empty consumerist world and the waste of precious resources on weapons of mass destruction, all carry an intrinsic message: the old order is destructive and a new order must emerge.

Although there are numerous references these days to sustainable development by government, opposition and industry, there is little attempt to put this reference into a framework of anything new in terms of economic policy. What is being increasingly understood, but not yet by major political parties, is that the economy and the environment are one issue; they are inextricably linked. There are some contradictions in the Government's position which I want to mention. I want to put on record some of the ideas which are now being explored by those Australians who, while they may have given their preferences to the Australian Labor Party in the recent election, first voted Green.

Sustainable development is a term that has been tossed about by politicians and business people from all sides of politics. I would suggest that there are three different schools of thought on sustainability. The first is the productivity or economic school of thought in which the primary concern is to meet society's demands for material goods in a way which yields an economic return on a continuing basis. The second is the stewardship or ecological perspective which is concerned with maintaining the health of natural ecosystems. Thirdly, there is the community or social perspective in which the conservation of social phenomena such as community structures and lifestyles in terms of quality rather than quantity of material possessions is paramount.

These perspectives should not be regarded as mutually exclusive but I want to stress that Green voters will not be satisfied with policies that continue to treat the environment as though it were something inert, as a background in our lives, something to be cleaned up for convenience. This is the point of view expressed by free market ideologists such as Margaret Thatcher who made explicit this idea of property when she said that we have a `repair and maintenance lease upon the planet'. It is indeed a limited view.

The same politicians have also pointed out that the inclusion of environmental costs into economic systems, from which they have hitherto been rigorously excluded, will demand a high price. To afford their price we will need even more wealth making activity. Thus, we are told that economic growth and a life enhancing environment can be reconciled.

Sustainability may be the word of the moment but this version means sustainability without social justice. The term has been either deliberately or inadvertently misunderstood. No wonder it has passed so easily into existing political rhetoric. The monetarist approach can mean only a hardening of present inequalities, if not a significant exacerbation of them. This is why no effort has been spared to obscure the contradiction between sustainable development and a market system that depends upon an acceleration in use of energy and resources in the production of more and more commodities which is what the growth economy is all about. The real costs of economic development have never shown up in balance sheets because such costs, like those to the environment, do not occur in the realm of economics at all.

I would like to outline an alternative Green approach to economics and development but before that I want to challenge the conventional wisdom which lies behind the way in which we measure growth and the values behind the United Nations (UN) system of national accounts. Few economists will acknowledge openly the villainy and incompetence of the UN system of national accounts. However, as Marilyn Waring, a well respected New Zealand economist, has pointed out, many economic commentators openly recognise three areas of difficulty in the United Nations system of national accounts-the hidden economy, the integration of environmental pollution costs into accounting and the measurement of leisure time. The principal objection to this system of accounting is that it reduces everything to a market price and consequently leaves out so much. In Australia, a relatively pollution free environment-I use that term advisedly-clean running water, old forests and the absence of commercial and nuclear power, all count for nothing.

Hand in hand with dismissal of the environment in the account system is the invisibility of women. As homemakers and mothers, if we choose those roles, we are non-producers and so are the increasing number of men who choose a homemaker's role. The work value is now measured only in monetary terms, a total abuse of its original meaning. The things we really value count for nothing in this system. This initial system of accounting was revised in 1968 to add some non-monetary activities but it still excludes the carriage of water, the collection of firewood, subsistence crop production and housework, activities which take up a vast percentage of the time of women around the world. Reasons given by men for their failure to account for women's work are conceptual problems and the practical difficulties of collection data. It seems not to occur to them that if one has a conceptual problem about the activity of half the human species, then one has a conceptual problem about the whole.

It is interesting to note that one exception to this situation is a small west African country which many honourable senators will never have heard of-Burkina Faso, the Upper Volta as it used to be called. Burkina Faso, where a women is the chief statistician, has simply altered its census to record the unpaid work of women, a very timely move in the right direction. Over the years there have been proposals to change the system of general accounting, most of which have gone unheeded. One system proposed by an American economist, Hazel Henderson, views the economy as a layered cake, where the unmeasured non-monetary section of the economy and environmental degradation are not seen as some peripheral part of the economy but as an intrinsic and measurable part of it. Even this proposal could be abused if the top layers are given greater weight than the bottom layers.

I think it is worth considering a model proposed by the Finnish feminist activist Helka Pietila, at the United Nations end of decade conference on women in Nairobi in 1985. Her concept is based on three overlapping circles-the non-monetary part of the economy which she describes as the free economy, the protected economy which consists of production and work for the home market as well as public services, and the fettered economy which covers large scale production for export, the terms of which are determined by the world market. With this system of accounting the nation's annual budget would become a realistic description of the well-being of the community and its environment, a reflection of real wealth and different values.

Such a budget would answer the following questions: who does what work and where, paid and unpaid; what are the positions of the nation's children and the aged; who is not housed adequately; who has the poorest health; what changes have occurred in water and air quality levels and why; what is the nature and what are the causes and regions of pollution and what are the health costs associated with that pollution; what national resources have been harvested or conserved; who relieves the state of the burden of care and dependency of others; what is the scope of subsistence production and what are the nutritional results; and at what price does the nation currently value war and the preparation for war?

What I am driving at is the necessity of viewing the economy as merely one aspect of a whole ecological and social fabric. Economists tend to divide this fabric into fragments, ignoring social and ecological interdependence and the perspectives which we need to see as part of the whole. All goods and services are reduced to their monetary values while the social and environmental costs generated by all economic activity are ignored.

To provide economics with a sound ecological basis, economists will need to revise their basic concepts in a drastic way. As Hazel Henderson has pointed out, the gross national product (GNP), which is supposed to measure a nation's wealth, is determined by adding up indiscriminately all economic activities associated with monetary values while all non-monetary aspects of the economy are ignored. Social costs, like those of accidents, litigation and health care are added as positive contributions to the GNP rather than being subtracted.

It was Ralph Nader who commented, `Every time there is an automobile accident, the GNP goes up'. In the same vein, Henderson insists that the concept of wealth must shed some of its present connotations of capital and material accumulation and give way to a redefinition as human enrichment, and that profit must be redefined to mean only the creation of real wealth rather than private or public gain won at the expense of social or environmental exploitation.

The same could be said of concepts of efficiency and productivity, which have been similarly distorted. It is quite clear that economic and institutional growth are inextricably linked to technological growth, which is patently not sustainable. Growth has to stop somewhere. I borrow a phrase from Hazel Henderson when she referred to macho technology, that is, a technology bent on manipulation and control rather than cooperation, self-assertion rather than integration, suitable for centralised management rather than regional and local application by individuals and small groups.

As a result most technologies today have become profoundly anti-ecological, unhealthy and inhuman. They need to be replaced by new forms of technology, technologies that incorporate ecological principles and correspond to a new set of values. Many of these alternative technologies, small scale and decentralised, responsive to local conditions and designed to increase self-sufficiency, are already being developed, as Henderson testifies in her book Creating Alternative Futures. These soft technologies are so called because their impact on the environment is greatly reduced by the use of renewable resources and constant recycling of materials. As Herman Daly has clearly pointed out, we should be aiming for a steady state economy in which there is plenty of lateral mobility but not open-ended vertical movement in growth because of our need to account for the renewable and non-renewable resources available to humanity in both the short and long term. There is not an inexhaustible supply of resources; neither is there an unlimited absorption of toxic waste churned out by a high-tech society.

Probably the most crucial issue involved in the sustainability debate is that of energy consumption. The key question here is whether it is possible to have reduced energy consumption per capita in the Western world and have economic growth as well. The immediate answer is that it is not only possible but that it has happened in recent years. During the past 13 years many industrial countries saw the energy content of growth fall significantly as a result of increases in energy efficiency, averaging 1.7 per cent annually between 1973 and 1983.

However, it could be argued that we have taken the easy energy conservation measures already and that further advances will be difficult to make. In this debate two schools of thought can be identified. The first suggests that the capacity to reduce energy consumption per capita without affecting national income significantly is so great that ecological sustainability can be achieved without sacrificing the goal of long term economic growth. On the other hand, there is a school of thought that maintains that economic growth and sustainable energy use are fundamentally inconsistent. In this view, major reductions in energy consumption are not possible in the current economic system. As long as there is exponential growth in economic activity, reduction in per capita consumption merely postpones the day on which fundamental energy resource constraints will be encountered.

The questions I have asked about energy use can also be asked of other resources. Here the technical optimists are on a firmer footing than with energy when they suggest we can maintain living standards in the future with greatly reduced material consumption. In terms of employment creation, it depends on one's assumption about the nature of job creation in the future. Barry Jones, former Minister for Science, has suggested that employment in the future would shift increasingly away from making, selling and servicing of goods and towards such areas as education, home-based employment, leisure, tourism, and craft and nature related work, a trend that has fundamental implications for the nature of jobs with which society is currently ill equipped to deal. His view reflect the views of British economist James Robertson, whose book Future Work indicated many opportunities for lateral thinkers who are prepared to challenge creatively the traditional concepts of full employment, a situation to which we cannot hope to return. But we need to rethink our notions of full time work linked to the notion of a guaranteed minimum income.

This issue is crucial, especially for the growing number of disillusioned young Australians who cannot relate to the materialistic lifestyle they have had foisted upon them, particularly if they are, for whatever reason, on the fringe of that materialism. We owe it to our youth to do more than continually put them into training programs, leading them ever onwards towards commercialism and consumerism. We need to be educating our young people for quality lifestyles where their creativity will be encouraged and valued and where they can make positive contributions in community decision making about their own futures. The question is not only what is the product of work in a sustainable society but what is the resulting lifestyle.

Finally I come to the vexed questions which have to do with the relationship between Australia and the rest of the world. The Labor Party's current record on overseas aid is not good. In fact, in setting the agenda for the fourth term of office of the Hawke Government, one of the sad aspects of the Governor-General's recent Speech was that it contained no reference to overseas aid, no reference to the Labor Party's pledge to try to restore our level of overseas aid to a higher level than that to which it has now sunk, and no reference to the recent Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report recommending that Australia's overseas aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GDP by 1992. Obviously the issue is not simply one of the level of overseas aid, but I cite this as an example of the way in which the Government is not prepared to take seriously concerns on aid and international debt raised by members of its own Party, let alone non-government critics like me. The best use Australia can be to the rest of the world is by example.

It is often said that Australia has one of the best chances of any country to develop a sustainable economy because of its natural resources, its low population and its environmentally concerned population. There are two approaches to how this might be achieved. One approach suggests that we need to consider seriously Australia's future optimum population level and our use of resources, to become less dependent upon external forces by becoming more self-sufficient, and to restructure our economy to become more sustainable, behind the protective walls of tariffs if necessary. If we can move towards sustainability here then other countries will see that it can be done and begin to adapt our experience to their own. If we continue to allow unlimited population and resource use to grow and let our economic affairs be determined in international markets, we have no chance of achieving sustainability.

An alternative, and from my point of view more acceptable, view is that it is unethical for Australians to put up trade barriers against the rest of the world in these days of spaceship Earth. The best thing we can do for the developing world is to keep our tariffs low, so that they have a market for their goods, and help them follow sustainable development paths different from the ones the West has taken so that the world's environmental resources are not depleted altogether or overburdened. The crux of the issue appears to be whether there is a beneficial relationship between increased international trade and sustainability. Obviously there will be an ongoing debate on these topics but it is crucial that these international perspectives be central to the debate and not sidelined.

Questions to do with Australia's role in the world also raise the issue of income distribution and its relationship with environmental degradation. Indeed, it is probable that inequality of income distribution is the greatest single cause of environmental damage. In that case we are in big trouble because the gap between the rich and poor is widening, both between countries and within countries. Sustainability for Australia therefore carries with it some thorny international issues. Probably the hardest issue concerns the ethics of Australia's role in a sustainable world. Is sustainability a subtler form of imperialism in which the First World tells the Third World what is best for it? In which case we will probably get some pretty negative responses.

These are the kinds of concerns the Greens will be raising as the debate on Australia's future continues. I would argue that, as far as the mainstream parties are concerned, the debate is simply about continuing unlimited growth and the victory of the free market approach or growth with a certain level of environmental responsibility tacked on.
