I repeat: the environment, the economy and social justice are one issue. The Green approach presents a new option, already under attack, as visionary, cautionary message heralding changes always are. There is a great deal of work being done globally by people whose only vested interest is in rescuing the future, people who want to present a viable vision for the right sharing of the Earth's resources, people who are beginning to convince business and industry that there are lots of opportunities, as well as imperatives, in turning away from the exploitative mentality towards an ethical framework which is truly sustainable in every dimension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address my remarks to a few separate and specific issues in this debate on the Appropriation Bills. Firstly, there can be no doubt that there is an urgent need for electoral reform and electoral education and that the democratic process which we have in this country would be further enhanced by such reform and education. Two key areas in which electoral reform is needed concern how to vote cards and the fact that the right to lie is entrenched in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Honourable senators will no doubt recall that last December the Australian Democrats tried to remove the right to lie from the Electoral Act. It is unfortunate that that amendment was not passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Views have been expressed in the electorate, from representatives of all political parties, that how to vote cards should be abolished. There was a case for how to vote cards in the past because the names of political parties were not permitted to be placed on the ballot paper. However, that is no longer the case and voters can now clearly see to which party each candidate has an affiliation. Each political party could have its recommendations for preferences clearly displayed both outside and inside polling places and, indeed, inside each polling cubicle. The electorate is becoming increasingly informed and sophisticated. The big hoax about preferences and how to vote cards has begun to be understood. People are beginning to understand that preferences are theirs to distribute and to give in the order that they wish and not to be manipulated by political parties. The how to vote card is merely a recommendation by a political party of how it would wish its voters to place preferences.

The preferential system was set up so that each voter could have another bite at the cherry if his or her first choice candidate was not elected. The lower House seats, that is, seats in the House of Representatives in the Federal Parliament, and in Legislative Assembly seats in State Houses, elect single members. They are single member constituencies. If a voter has his or her first, second or even third choice candidate eliminated from the count, their next choice is taken into consideration until one candidate has more than 50 per cent of the vote and is elected.

Political parties have hijacked preferences which in reality belong to the people. Political parties, particularly the two big political blocks of the Labor and Liberal parties, now frenetically negotiate to gain preferences, particularly in seats in the lower Houses in which, of course, the Government is decided. We Australians need to realise that we can decide who forms government by the way in which we place our preferences. Indeed, I am surprised that in the forthcoming by-elections in Western Australia the Liberals are giving their second preferences to candidates who are on the public record as having stated that they are not interested in calling for a royal commission into Western Australia Inc. They are giving their second preferences to the Western Australian Greens. This is admirable because, of course, the Western Australia Greens stand on strong environmental issues which are supported by the Democrats. However, when we consider that the Liberals are standing on the call for a royal commission into Western Australia Inc., this might seem to be a little surprising. It may well be that Liberal voters need to consider and take into account what decisions have been made in this regard. I believe that it is very important that people of independent mind do act as independents in the Parliament and sit on the cross benches, as the Democrats have done very successfully for the past 13 years in the Senate.

In order to ensure that voters are in charge of their preferences the Australian Democrats run for the most part on split tickets in most elections. In this way the voter can choose whether to give his or her further preference to the Australian Labor Party or to the Liberal Party of Australia. Nonetheless we normally also recommend that second and third preferences immediately after the Democrats should go to sympathetic Green candidates who stand generally on environmental and social justice issues.

In some ways it is an insult to the intelligence of voters for political parties to direct the preferences of a voter. It is also difficult for voters if they feel that they have a Hobson's choice. The Australian Democrats also have a tradition of occasionally running on open tickets, that is, in not assigning or recommending preferences as such, but in totally giving back to voters their opportunity to put their preferences exactly where they want to. The Democrats are doing that in the forthcoming by-elections in Western Australia.

Part of the problem that we have in Western Australia, and a very great problem it is, is the problem of Western Australia Inc. This was flagged way back in the early 1980s, indeed as far back as 1984, when the Western Australian Government introduced the Western Australian Development Corporation Act. I was very surprised that that particular Bill was allowed to pass through the State Parliament without any amendment, because it could be quite clearly seen in that Bill that there was no accountability of the Western Australian Development Corporation to the Parliament. In fact it would appear that WADC had more power than the Parliament itself. I am very surprised, considering that the Opposition parties had the numbers in the Upper House, that that Bill was not amended at the time.

I turn now to the subject of electoral education. It is very disappointing that the Australian Electoral Commission does not take it upon itself to conduct more education as far as our electoral systems are concerned. There is a great need for people to be educated in the matter of preferences. The Electoral Commission goes out of its way to show people how to register a formal vote but all too often that vote is an uncomprehending one because too few people understand how the preference system works.

Television is a superb medium as far as education is concerned. I would certainly encourage the Electoral Commission to use the medium of television to educate the people of Australia as to how our preferential system works. In the recent half Senate election a fair proportion of voters in Western Australia chose not to vote `1' above the line, that is, not to surrender control of their own preferences. A large number of people voted below the line and therefore retained control over their preferences and assigned them as they wished to. The statistics here are very interesting. The highest proportion of votes of people who voted below the line, with regard to both the percentage of votes for the party and also as far as the raw scores are concerned, went to the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats achieved over 20,000 votes below the line. Next in line were the Western Australian Greens, with over 18,000 votes below the line. The Liberal Party was next with over 17,000 votes and then the Labor Party with nearly 10,000 votes below the line. A number of people who wished to take control of their preferences voted below the line and therefore placed their preferences where they wished them to be.

A lot of appropriations money is currently spent in the area of public funding of election campaigns. This is becoming inordinately expensive, mainly because of the very high cost of electronic advertising. This is something which has to be faced.

A report was brought out last year by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters of the Parliament and this Committee advocated that this was an issue that needed to be addressed. The report was called Who pays the piper calls the tune. The title was chosen because it was perceived by the all-party Committee-although I must say that not all the recommendations of the Committee were unanimous-that certainly the issue needs to be addressed; that is, if political parties need vast sums of money in order to be able to advertise during election time, the possibility is there for electoral corruption, and this is the last thing that we want in this country.

An issue that I have raised before and raise again briefly today is that of the epidural use of the drug Depo-Medrol. In addressing the Appropriation Bills I want to point out that the financial cost to the public purse of Depo-Medrol epidural injections that go wrong is absolutely enormous. I spoke on this issue last year and I have continued to do a lot of work on it.

Since I last spoke many new cases, including a number of particularly severe ones, have come to my notice. Some of these cases are from States other than Western Australia. I remind honourable senators that this issue relates to the use of a drug for spinal injections which is not approved by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee for that particular use. It is not approved for that particular use by the manufacturer. It is approved for the use of injection into muscle tissue and not into the spine.

One issue of importance is that this drug is being brought into the stores of government hospitals and is being used in these hospitals for epidural injections. Thus the Commonwealth is paying for supplies of a drug to be used in a way not sanctioned by the Commonwealth's own relevant medical authority. Further, doctors who give these injections are currently able to claim payment for the procedures from Medicare. Thus the Commonwealth is paying for the administration of this drug in a manner it does not sanction. Further still, when subsequent to the administration of the drug a patient is affected by serious adverse reactions it is Medicare again which stands the cost of hospitalisation and treatment.

I am aware of one patient-not one of the original group from whom I received affidavits last year-whose adverse reaction was immediate and devastating. His blood pressure dropped to zero. He technically died and had to be resuscitated. During the next several hours he had to be resuscitated on two further occasions. He spent three and half months in intensive care and three full years in hospital before he was well enough to go home.

A rough estimate in respect of this case is that the bed alone cost in today's dollars in the order of half a million dollars. These costs were borne by Medicare, that is, by the taxpayer. It is probable that if all other costs of this one case were taken into account-theatre costs and the costs of consultants, medications and so on, the cost would exceed a million dollars, and this is just one of many cases.

It is high time that we had a major investigation into this particular issue. It must be resolved one way or the other. Either the drug must be approved for that particular use or we must change the way in which it is administered. Indeed, I would state that it is high time we had a major investigation into the prevalence of iatrogenic disease in Australia and the effective measures to combat it.

In talking on that relevant point, I would like to pick up some of the remarks made in the chamber earlier today by Senator Crowley. Senator Crowley referred to a report which was brought out in April of this year, Home Births in Australia 1985-87, a report brought out by the National Perinatal Statistics Unit Homebirth Australia. In order to summarise some of the conclusions in that report I refer to a recent newspaper article headed `Babies less likely to die in home births: study'. It reported that the first comprehensive national report on home births found that childbirth at home was also less likely to involve medical or surgical intervention than that involved in hospital deliveries. The article states:
The analysis of 3400 home births planned between 1985 and 1987 was held by the national perinatal statistics unit based at Sydney university . . .
It found the caesarian rate for home births was 2.2 per cent, about an eighth of the national rate.

The report also found that one in seven home births resulted in the mother being taken to hospital for the actual birth, but even when that happened the intervention rate was very much lower. The article states:
The perinatal mortality rate for home births was 5.9 a 1000 births, compared with a national rate of 10.7.

These statistics are very interesting. The background to the statistics also needs to be considered very carefully. The home birth movement has been severely criticised. It was severely criticised before because statistics were not available right across the board and in every State. Now those statistics are available and they are there to be examined by all and sundry. It is not enough to use anecdotal information; we must turn to statistics, but we must also turn to the meaning of those statistics.

On the same subject-that is of the rate of medical intervention in childbirth in Australia-I refer to a book by Stephen Rice titled, provocatively, Some Doctors Make You Sick. Rates of caesarian intervention are given in the book. It says:
The rate of caesarian section births has tripled in just 20 years.
Further, it states:

A recent Australian study found that of 120 women having their first baby, 23 per cent had a Caesarian section. The study was carried out at a large Sydney teaching hospital . . . Of the women who gave birth vaginally, . . . Some 81 per cent had an episiotomy . . . forceps were used on 43 per cent of the women who gave birth vaginally. At least one reason for this is the widespread use of epidural anaesthesia, which prolongs the second stage of labour and makes it less efficient.

Of course, caesarian sections are necessary on occasions and there can be tragic consequences if a caesarian section is not performed when it is necessary, but caesarian sections are not necessary for all births by any means and the percentage of their use in Australia is particularly high. The book also states:
In Holland, the survival rate of newborn babies is better than in Australia, yet the caesarian section rate is between a quarter and a third that in Australia.
Another Australian study was on infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), this again in a major Sydney hospital. The book states:

Of 116 infants with RDS, 28 were found to have been born premature as a result of elective induction (18 cases) and elective Caesarian section (10 cases). Each suffered severe respiratory distress, and several needed help in breathing . . . The two researchers pointed out that it was becoming increasingly common-and socially acceptable-for doctors to plan deliveries for the ``daylight hours''.
Stephen Rice states in this book:

The rate of surgical intervention can be reduced. With careful assessment and monitoring of pregnancy and labour, one Dublin hospital has been able to significantly lower its rate of Caesarian sections. In 1980 its rate for 8742 patients was only 4.8 per cent.
That is considerably lower than the percentage currently in Australia.

Lastly I would like to direct some remarks to immigration. Tabled today are the two reports put out by the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations and the Government's response. When honourable senators see those reports they will see that the all party Committee in these unanimous reports was very critical of the Government's first draft of the migration regulations. The regulations have already been changed a few times. I commend the Government for making those changes. They were necessary and the Government has made them.

What is not to be commended is that the Government put itself in the unnecessary position of having to make those changes last year by rushing through immigration legislation and the regulations which were part and parcel of that legislation and not taking advice which was given to it from a number of sides that legislation which depended on regulations which codified, or attempted to codify, prospective migrants right down to the very last little dotted `i' and crossed `t', simply cannot work. Indeed, had the coalition stuck to its guns when the legislation was introduced last year and not caved into the Government, the Senate and the Parliament at large would have had the time to consider properly the changes that were brought in.

In fact, the changes were simply a patch up yet again to the 1958 immigration Act and not what FitzGerald and his committee recommended in respect of reforming immigration policy-that is, that it was time we had a new brand of immigration legislation which was not tied to the 1958 Act which, of course, dates back to the White Australia policy days. So this matter is very clearly connected with the appropriations because work which is done, then undone and redone, with manuals having to be rewritten and reprinted, puts an extra burden on the public purse.

The immigration debate is on the public agenda. That debate is welcomed provided that it is full, open and all-embracing and is not limited to single sector interests. One of our problems is that Australia has no population policy as such. We have a sort of de facto population policy which is decided by the immigration officers and immigration bureaucrats of the day. But that cannot be satisfactory and it is to be hoped that a valid policy will emerge as a result of research currently being carried out by the Bureau of Immigration Research. The Bureau is investigating the relevant components and ingredients which must, of necessity, be examined before a population policy can be arrived at.

Obviously, there must be some in-built flexibility to account for changes which will occur both inside and outside Australia. The issue of immigration must be seen as relevant to, but also apart from, population policies as such. After all, population and immigration policies affect all Australians. Population policies are concerned with numbers of people and the associated demographics-where people live and how they live. This has already been touched on by a number of previous speakers.

The Federal Government and State governments espouse policies of decentralisation and regionalisation but these policies are not borne out by positive incentives and actions. Indeed, those of us here from Western Australia know full well that in our State it is very hard to get proper hospital treatment, even in a public hospital, in some of our country towns. In fact, if not privately insured, there is no way that a person will be treated in a hospital in one of our country towns.

As with all policy areas, words are not enough. So despite all of the words that will emerge during this debate on the appropriations, I hope that the Government will properly put into place suitable actions for the reforming policies which it espouses and which have been flagged in the speech of the Governor-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the appropriation debate tonight to raise an issue that I think has implications on Australia's balance of payments. It is only a small issue but it is a fairly relevant one. A number of marine cruise services operating along the Great Barrier Reef, with headquarters in both Mackay and Cairns, offer three- and four-day cruises. Some of these people have been in the business for up to 25 and 30 years. They suffered badly during the pilots dispute and, of course, as with every other small business, they are suffering from the Government imposed 23 per cent interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The cruise rates have fallen from around 80 per cent some five or six years ago to between 20 per cent and 45 per cent now. About 80 per cent of the customers are overseas travellers who go out to look at and inspect the Barrier Reef. One of these Australian cruise operators recently purchased a multi-million dollar cruiser, built here in Australia, which demonstrates that company's commitment to the industry. These operators have been prepared to struggle over the last couple of years, through the pilots dispute and high interest rates that have deprived them of high cruise rates, hoping eventually to realise a profitable return on their considerable investments in the extended cruise market.

This market is over-stretched at present and the current operators are finding it difficult enough to stay in the business without the threat of a government company coming in and taking over, and that is precisely what Qantas Airways Ltd is working towards. A joint venture project has been proposed between Qantas Airways subsidiary, QH Tours Ltd, and Captain Cook Cruises Pty Ltd, a Sydney cruise operator. I have a joint press release which says that QH Tours, which is a part of Qantas, is promoting the ultimate Great Barrier Reef marine cruise. So we have a Government instrumentality building a first-class cruise liner earmarked for service on the Great Barrier Reef.

This joint venture is building a boat called the Reef Endeavour. According to the press release the boat will be 3 3/4 thousand tonnes and will carry 156 passengers on three- and four-day cruises from Cairns to the Reef. The current cruise operators are more than happy to compete with any private enterprise that wants to set up in a narrow market. But they are extremely upset that a government-funded company, such as Qantas, is setting up in their own territory to muscle in on their business. Quite frankly, I do not blame them. It is hard enough to compete in the current market but to have to fight government-sponsored competition from Qantas Airways is quite ridiculous.

I say to Qantas that it should be promoting existing Australian tourism and helping the operators, not setting up in direct opposition to them. Qantas is believed to be the financier of the project with Captain Cook Cruises being up front. Qantas is very worried about the possibility of losing business from Jetabout Cruises which markets its tourism packages. We now find that Jetabout will be directly selling the QH Tours and not promoting the other tourist operators that have been in the market for 25 years. Jetabout is the Qantas travel arm, and it is not likely that once the taxpayer funded cruiser opens for business Qantas will utilise its vertically integrated companies to fly tourists in on Qantas planes, book them on Qantas tours and Qantas cruises, and fly them out again on Qantas planes.

So much for the local Australian tourist operators. They will be squeezed out of the market. Already QH Tours is flexing its marketplace muscle and demanding higher commission fees from the tourist operators. Operators that are now paying a hefty 25 per cent or more commission are now being told to come up with more than 30 per cent commission if they want to retain the business. Yet Qantas and its partners are supposed to be promoting Australian tourism.

There are a number of questions that need to be answered. The local industry believes that this Government funded cruiser is being built in Fiji. I have had it confirmed tonight that the Qantas cruiser-it is not a cruiser but a 3,500 tonne ship, which is quite a considerable sized ship-is going to be built in Fiji because labour is cheaper. It will then cruise into Australian waters.

In fact, what we have, if we boil it right down, is Qantas, which is an Australian Government instrumentality, receiving a $5m subsidy from the Fijian Government to compete against Australian private cruise operators. That is quite wrong, particularly when we are told by Travel Australia, which is a prominent travel magazine, that Qantas is expected to have lost another $150m when its financial report comes down in 1989-90. The carrier could face debts of around $3 billion by mid-year, an airline source said. Qantas has estimated a $100m loss due to the pilots dispute, and a rise in fuel costs has contributed to another $100m loss. In the 1988-89 financial year, the airline reported an operating profit after tax of $177m.

Qantas is supposed to be in dire need of a huge capital injection to keep it flying. We find now that it is diverting its capital into purchasing a boat-I will not call it a boat as it is a fairly substantial 3,500 tonne ship-and it is going to use that ship to compete against Australian cruise operators.

Qantas is facing such financial debts and is building up such debts for the taxpayer that it should be asked why it is investing millions of dollars in a cruise liner to run in an oversupplied market. Qantas is already responsible for blowouts in our import bill with its expensive imports of aeroplanes. Now it is going to import boats. I cannot believe that the Government is letting this happen.

The last thing the cruise operators in north Queensland need is a depressed market due to Qantas elbowing its way in by using taxpayers' money. The local industry is already concerned at the clandestine way that Qantas is manoeuvring into the market. Operators believe that Jetabout has done much of the negotiating to date-particularly with the Fijian Government-to secure subsidies in building the liner. Yet Jetabout and Qantas have appeared extremely surprised, if not concerned, that anyone knows anything about this project.

The local operators say that they would not be able to sustain the competition that Jetabout would cause in the limited market. Jetabout has the financial backing of Qantas and the Government to sustain losses that they could not. The operators are also concerned that Jetabout as a wholesaler knows of their 1990-91 rates and the statistics of past and forward bookings. They wrote to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories at the time, Mr Holding, and received a thank you letter in reply, but nothing positive.

This is a very serious matter. It is not only a matter of governments using taxpayers' money to take over private enterprise, but it is also a matter that should concern the Government when one of its quangos is purchasing ships from an overseas government-in this case the government of Fiji-and that government is subsidising that particular boat so as it can go in and compete against private enterprise; that is, the tourist operators in north Queensland.

I hope the Government does take this on board because this action is quite wrong. It is wrong that these operators in north Queensland have had to maintain their own industry in very adverse conditions over the last six or 12 months of the pilots dispute. They are holding on, trying to maintain their businesses, and there is no way in the world that they can offset a business that is prepared to come in with Government funds and undercut their rates and drive them out of business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this appropriation debate as the Australian Democrats spokesperson on defence to pass some comments about the defence appropriations. I think most honourable senators are aware that since I have been in this place I have been questioning at the rationale upon which we are planning and funding our defence every available opportunity, and I am going to continue to do so this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I will start by stating the obvious: I have not been able to identify anybody in Australia who argues that we should not move to secure our nation and a totally secure Australia. The debate centres on how best to do this. That is the first starting proposition I would like to make-that we all favour a secure Australia.

The second proposition I believe it is necessary to state initially is that we do not foresee any serious threat to Australia in the near future. That is the second proposition which should be underpinning our defence planning.

I think we all acknowledge that there is some possibility of low level instability in our region, but I do not think any defence thinkers and analysts argue that we can foresee a major threat to stability such as we faced, say, in the 1950s with Korea, or in the 1960s and 1970s with Vietnam. In other words, it is generally conceded by the defence analysts and on all sides of this chamber that we are in a period of stability, allowing for the fact that there may be minor instability within the region such as we have seen in recent months in two or three locations throughout the south-west Pacific.

Having made those opening observations, and we are seeing an emerging India-there is no doubt about the fact that India is rationalising and increasing its defence force-but there is no real suggestion form any quarter that India is adopting an aggressive posture in the southern Asian region; we all acknowledge that the Chinese population is exploding, but historically China has not been an outwardly aggressive nation as it tends to address itself internally to the implications associated with its billion or more people; and we all accept that Japan is economically dominant in the region. But even acknowledging these three things, there is general acceptance among defence analysts that we are in a period of stability.

We are also observing unprecedented global military thawing. We have seen unprecedented military de-escalation, as opposed to what we have witnessed in the last decade in Europe. A decade ago it would have been unimaginable that one-third of Soviet troops in eastern Europe would have been withdrawn within twelve months. We are witnessing massive dismantling of defence industries around the globe. In these contexts we have to analyse what is happening in terms of Australia's defence appropriations as they are before this chamber.

I begin by making a couple of factual observations about defence expenditure in this country-right now, today. We spend approximately $8.6 billion a year on a Defence Force which by any standards must be regarded as demoralised and by some standards is regarded as impotent, as of today. In other words, it would be incapable of defending our shores against a major conventional attack. The concept of our defending Australia against any sort of nuclear threat is laughable. We are spending $8.6 billion a year on an impotent, demoralised Defence Force. Members of that Defence Force are voting with their feet and the shrinking of our service numbers has reached crisis point and is occurring at unprecedented rates.

At the same time as the $8.6 billion a year expenditure on this impotent, demoralised Defence Force is occurring, we fund our volunteer coastal patrols, our bush fire patrols and our State emergency services literally by selling lamingtons on street corners. I illustrate this quite dramatically by citing the example of the State Emergency Services in the Newcastle region. I recently spoke to the director of the State Emergency Services operation who headed the post-earthquake operation in the Newcastle region. He told me that literally now-this day-he is attempting to raise sufficient money to purchase a four-wheel drive vehicle and communications systems for the State Emergency Services by selling chook raffle tickets in the pub on Saturday mornings. Yet we have witnessed an unprecedented series of major natural disasters in the last six months. We have not had-or been assured that we have-the capacity to react to a number of disasters simultaneously. We have been fortunate through nature sparing us simultaneous disasters. Were we to be confronted with multiple disasters, we simply would not be able to respond effectively.

I am suggesting that we now have an opportune time during a period of emerging global peace, during a period of regional and global relative stability, to completely rethink what defence is all about as we move into the next two or three decades. On every available opportunity I have urged the previous Minister for Defence, Minister Beazley, and the current Minister, Senator Robert Ray, to seriously put before Cabinet and the Government the proposition that we should be thinking laterally in our defence modelling and our defence funding and completely re-examining what we consider to be the threats to Australia and the needs in terms of defence structures. We have been advocating alternative defence models which would place emphasis upon civil-military defence models as opposed to the prevailing traditional, historical military-civil defence structures which we have had in this country. Now is the time to do the re-thinking. We have never had more striking evidence of the need for such re-thinking as we have had in this country in the last three or four months.

We have this extraordinary situation where our State emergency services are funding themselves literally by selling lamingtons on street corners. We have the farcical situation in respect of the National Safety Council of Australia, Victoria Division, so-called which by virtue of its name undertakes a capacity to respond on behalf of the community to ensure its safety. Quite extraordinary things are alleged to have occurred within that organisation and are now being inquired into. We have the situation where a company which bidded for, and had been chosen by the Government to undertake, the surveilling of our northern coastline was unable to get five aircraft in the air simultaneously on the day on which it was to demonstrate its capacity to the Federal Government.

The realities are that we are locked into traditional thinking and we are undertaking massive expenditures in models which are utterly irrelevant. We are turning away from the essential requirements and not addressing moneys to them. It is a fact that anybody who becomes a member of a volunteer bush fire brigade in New South Wales is required to purchase his or her own protective clothing. Those people take time off work to undertake training in this country-a fire prone country-to defend their local community against bush fires, but they are not entitled to payment for their time. The Government in no way supports them in their training process. Quite obviously, these are ludicrous contradictions.

I would like to cite some of the clear examples of what we, in the Australian Democrats, see as being extraordinarily inappropriate commitments within these military appropriations to undertake expenditures which are massively burdensome upon the Australian community. In recent days we saw virtually a celebration by our Minister for Defence and senior defence officers because we had taken delivery of the last of our 75 FA18 fighters at a cost of about $5 billion-or, it is estimated, as much as $60m each, once they are piloted and provided with the necessary spare parts, basing facilities and operation and maintenance costs, which will be on top of the purchase price of the aircraft. Yet, I am told by the officer who commands those aircraft that it will be nine years before they are all piloted-and then with inexperienced pilots.

It is a ludicrous undertaking on the part of our Government to commit us to that level of expenditure when, as I am also told by reliable authorities, the whole of our Army would be required to defend the airfields from which these aircraft operate, were they dispersed in northern Australia. This is an outstanding example of Australia, having committed itself to traditional models of defence and to the highly potent technological armories that are now associated with the pursuit of those models, being lumbered with this enormous expense of $5 billion. That is an initial outlay to purchase aircraft which are irrelevant to our needs.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was addressing, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, comments towards the defence appropriations. I was arguing that at a time when, globally, levels of threat are decreasing and we are living in a very stable region-although I acknowledge some possibility of low level instability-this is an excellent opportunity for those who are responsible for the defence of Australia to do some profound lateral thinking and to put in place, for the next several decades, a defence structure and defence force which is more appropriately addressed to what we see as the future needs of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I argued that nobody in this place would say that we should leave Australia defenceless. The argument centres around what is the most appropriate defence structure. The Australian Democrats vigorously argue that the former Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, and the current Minister, Senator Robert Ray, have committed us to defence structures which are essentially based on obsolete historical models that conceive armies, navies and air forces as being the appropriate structure of our defence. The Democrats argue that the time has come to shift from a military/civil model to a civil/military model.

I cite the following extraordinary and ridiculous contradiction. In Australia today we spend $8.6 billion a year on a defence force which is demoralised and largely impotent. Yet at the same time we fund our volunteer coastal patrols, State emergency services and bush fire brigades-all of which we use on a month by month, week by week, and certainly year by year basis-by selling lamingtons on street corners. I cited the profound example of the Director of the State Emergency Service in the Newcastle region, the man who headed up the post-earthquake operation, who told me just a few weeks ago that he is currently attempting to buy a four-wheel drive vehicle by running chook raffles in the pub on Saturday mornings.

Whilst we are confronted with those ridiculous contradictions the Australian people have a right to cry out that the time has come for us to seriously address other alternatives. I was citing the fact that Minister Beazley, and now Minister Robert Ray, who is committing himself to the same course of action, have said to Australia, `We want you to undertake massive expenditures and commit us to defence outlays for decades ahead which are largely irrelevant and which cannot be justified'. I gave the example that we celebrated just last week the arrival of our final F18 fighters. We have 75 of them. We have bought them at a cost of approximately $65m each, and yet it will be nine years-so the commander of those fighters tells me-before they will all be piloted, and then it will be with inexperienced pilots.

There is a two-year lead time on spare parts for the F18 fighter. We got our order wrong. We had to guess right. The challenge was to guess correctly what spares would be required for this fighter two years in advance. Our current experience indicates that we have got that wrong and that a considerable number of them will be grounded.

The fact is that these highly technological weapons are like anything. A chain is as strong as its weakest link. The more sophisticated it becomes, the more vulnerable it becomes to breakdown and systems failure. Just a few months ago in this country our F111 bombers, now becoming a little dated but nevertheless still very powerful weapons systems, were grounded because there were no cannisters for the ejection seats. Therefore, pilots could not be expected to fly those sophisticated weapons systems because that sophisticated technological chain was only as strong as its weakest link-a simple cannister to blast an ejection seat from a cockpit.

We have ordered six Kockum-471 submarines which are now being built in Adelaide. The estimated project cost cited by the Government varies from $4.4 billion to $4.8 billion. If basic facilities and other special requirements are added, to the cost of $5.4 billion, according to Department of Defence documents, the total amounts to $900m per vessel. So we have bought 75 F18 fighters at $65m each and we have ordered six submarines at $900m each. This is when we are funding our volunteer coastal patrols and State emergency services literally by selling lamingtons on street corners. Two extra submarines which may still be ordered would cost another $800m at today's prices.

The project cost is certain to continue escalating well above the inflation rate, having almost doubled from the $2.6 billion cited by Paul Dibb in 1986. None of these figures includes the cost of operations, refit or maintenance. Therefore, we cannot begin to truly estimate the cost of that commitment to those submarines. Eight Meko ANZ frigates are to be built at Williamstown at a project cost of $4.4 billion-that is $550m per ship, excluding basic refit operations and maintenance costs. The modernisation of our three guided-missile destroyers is now under way, at a project cost of $570m, that is, $190m per warship. Sixteen Seahawk helicopters are now being assembled for $620m-that is, $39m per helicopter.

Unless the Government cancels major equipment contracts it is locked into the Beazley vision of a high-tech military force structure for decades to come. It is locked into what we would argue is utter irrelevance to the real needs for the defence of this country. It is a force structure at odds with the strategic guidance upon which it is based. It flies in the face of the strategic advice and model upon which it is based. The only conceivable threat facing Australia is of low level harassment and attack. The big ticket items are of little use for chasing small bands of hostile guerillas across the north of Australia. It is a reality that if we disburse those 75 F18 fighters in the northern part of this continent it would take the whole of our Army to defend the airfields, to render then secure for use.

We have committed ourselves, therefore, to a force structure which is designed to fight yesterday's wars-wars which are well away from our shores. In an attempt to give them contemporary relevance, Kim Beazley tried to transform warships and bombers into instruments of peacetime diplomacy in our region.

The realities are that we are not capable of even surveilling let alone protecting our northern shores or the whole of our coast line. At present a total of roughly $50m per year is spent on Coastwatch. This could be increased by about 50 per cent just by retiring two of the existing Oberon submarines. Honourable senators should remember that the figures I quoted earlier were in billions of dollars. Thousands of millions of dollars were committed to the purchase of fighters which are potent, but unnecessary; submarines which are potent, but unnecessary, and yet we commit only $50m annually to the surveillance of our most vulnerable coast.

It is widely felt that the funding for land care should be doubled requiring an extra $300m over 10 years, one-third of the cost of a new submarine. Next year $5.4m will be spent on research into the greenhouse effect and about $3m on renewable energy research, development and demonstration. This compares with over $200m on military research alone. The fact is that this Government is committing us to three decades-former Minister Beazley was particularly responsible for this-of massive debt for the procurement of hardware which is structured within defence models which the Australian Democrats would argue are dramatically irrelevant to the needs of Australia.

We would argue that it would be possible, even within the existing framework of the Army, to create a conservation corps built from and around the Royal Australian Engineers which could undertake the treatment of our polluted rivers and harbours, the desalination of our river foreshores and the planting, for instance, of the one billion trees which Prime Minister Hawke has boasted will be planted in this decade. Yet we have made no provision for these fundamental defences of our environment and resources, nor have we made adequate provision for the day by way and week by week civilian defences of people who are exposed to danger from flooding, fire and earthquakes. The Australian Democrats argue that the funds which were appropriated within these Bills are misdirected and utterly irresponsible for the future needs of the defence of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just 12 months ago I spoke in this place about the fact that Mr Keating's support for a consumption tax in 1985-remember that option C-was scuppered by Mr Hawke and the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the Taxation Summit of that year, and why Mr Keating had gone off that idea. To quote from my speech of 24 May last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Remember Mr Keating's choice of option C at the summit conference that was to introduce a consumption tax of 12 3/4 per cent? We all remember what happened to that. We all know that Mr Hawke, in a motel room, along with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, scuppered that proposal in a hurry and left Keating high and dry. But that did not stop Mr Keating. He has still, very surreptitiously, gone down that road. Sales tax revenue-and this is on top of personal tax-has more than doubled. It has gone up by over 147 per cent under this Government.
I said that just twelve months ago; it has gone up a lot more since then. I note that on 15 May in the Bulletin David Barnett picked up the theme of my speech, and I quote:

The debate on whether we should have consumption tax is highly embarrassing for the Treasurer, Paul Keating. You will recall that he pressed mightily at the Tax Summit in 1985 to bring in a broad-based consumption tax. Then he was rolled by his Prime Minister after a late night talk with the Australian Council of Trade Unions' general secretary, Bill Kelty. So that was the end of the broad-based consumption tax, wasn't it?

Well, no, it wasn't and here lies the source of Mr Keating's embarrassment. He sneaked the easy bits in anyway. He `reformed' the sales tax system in the 1985-86 Budget and he has been reforming it ever since, fixing up `anomalies'.
About one-third of the products for sale in your average supermarket now attract sales tax.

The Government has, indeed, introduced a type of consumption tax-not Mr Keating's 12 3/4 per cent, but a sales tax many items of which are levied at 10, 20 and 30 per cent, and even the proposed 50 per cent. Of course, under this scheme pensioners and other disadvantaged groups have not been compensated for the enormous increase in their supermarket bills as they would have been if a consumption tax had been introduced, and Mr Keating knows this well.

I will just give five examples of the sales tax that many pensioners are forced to pay for items because they are levied at wholesale prices. The first is washing powder. We all wash our clothes in washing powder. One and a half kilograms of washing powder attracts a 20 per cent sales tax. Because it is levied at the wholesale price, when the retailer gets it he puts his profit on the wholesaler's mark-up and a tax of $1.08. The tax component in that price is $1.17. So instead of paying only $5.87 for the washing powder, the pensioner has to pay $7.04. That is a considerable amount on the supermarket bill.

I will just run very quickly through the amount of tax that is paid for other items. Seven hundred and fifty millilitres of washing liquid is taxed at 20 per cent and the tax component is 55c. So instead of paying $2.82, the pensioner pays $3.37. If the pensioner has a pet and is buying dog food, 700 grams of dog food attracts a sales tax of 20 per cent and instead of paying 92c, he pays $1.10. Instead of paying $1.82 for toothpaste, the pensioner pays $2.18. The same thing applies to packs of toilet rolls-instead of paying $3.18, the pensioner pays $3.81.

We are not told about this tax. There are many other items that attract this tax. One of the largest wholesalers told me that approximately 33 per cent of his grocery lines attract sales tax. At the last Budget of the coalition Government in 1982-83, revenue from sales tax alone was $3,490m. The total tax taken was 8.47 per cent. The estimate for this financial year is $10,500m, an increase of 200.86 per cent-over 200 per cent. It represents 11.5 per cent of the total tax for this financial year. When we left government the total tax taken was 8.47 per cent. Sales tax has now gone up to 11.5 per cent of the total tax taken-a 286 per cent increase in revenue.

Total tax for these years has increased enormously. The total tax take by the Government has gone up 32.6 per cent-and that is in 1988-89 dollar terms. I also stress that sales tax has increased this year-I really want to press this home-from 8 3/4 per cent of the total tax taken to 11 3/4 per cent of the total tax taken. Is it any wonder that Mr Keating is not interested in a consumption tax of 12 3/4 per cent? If he did introduce it, he would have to give a pay-off to all the pensioners, low income earners and disadvantaged people. Because the Treasurer has never acknowledged the enormous increase in the sales tax, pensioners have just paid up, blaming the manufacturers and supermarkets for enormous increases. They do not know the Government is applying the sales tax.

To enforce this myth that it is all the supermarkets' fault, the Government set up, prior to the election, a price watch committee of Labor members, which went around the States abusing manufacturers and supermarket owners for the increases, never once mentioning the increasing Government taxes on many of these goods-increases put on by Mr Keating, their Treasurer. The five articles I have chosen are just some in the price watch list which Government members used to berate manufacturers and supermarket proprietors for the price increases. We all remember that Mr George Gear was chairman of that national price watch network. He came to Hobart, had a public meeting at the Town Hall, and he and Mr Duncan Kerr got stuck into the supermarkets and berated them for their large increases. Mr Kerr said that the escalating cost of basic grocery items was an increasing burden on families and that it was important that the ordinary members of the public and interested groups had a say in developing ways of curbing this trend. `Concern about rising prices is increasing and not a day passes without people raising this matter with me', said Duncan Kerr. On not one occasion did either Mr Gear or Duncan Kerr inform the public that it was not the supermarkets increasing the prices; it was this Government, because of a 20 per cent sales tax that automatically went up as the prices went up.

Why was this hypocritical action taken when the Government has extensively increased the range of items covered by this tax? I have touched on only a few food items; there are many other items that the Treasurer has lured into his net, which each year he casts further and further into the taxpayers' pockets. Again, I quote from my speech of last year:

How many of the families are aware that they are paying . . . 20 per cent sales tax on articles such as watches, clocks, cameras, film and slide projectors. There is 20 per cent sales tax on beer and wine. Of course, there is an excise duty on top of that . . . Every time a woman puts on lipstick she pays an additional 20 per cent to the Government . . . Every time she buys a wheelbarrow or garden fork she pays a 20 per cent sales tax . . . When people buy blankets they pay 10 per cent to the Government. If they buy a tea-towel they pay 10 per cent to the Government . . . Every time they buy a packet of potato chips, the Government grabs back 10 per cent. Every time they buy a cup and saucer or a glass they pay 10 per cent. Every time people strike a match they pay 10 per cent . . . They pay 10 per cent on all soft goods such as curtaining . . . brooms, buckets, rubbish bins, fridges, heaters, stoves, kettles, vacuum cleaners, washing machines, sewing machines and knitting machines . . .
Yes, 10 per cent goes to the Government. They are just a few items. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) had added sales tax to thousands and thousands more.

In 1987 Mr Keating took a new direction. For the very first time, he imposed sales tax on services. Sales tax exemptions and customs duty exemptions were withdrawn from many government service enterprises. Australia Post and Telecom Australia are just two. This has resulted in an estimated $320m being added to Government revenue. Again, pensioners and low income earners have not been compensated for the increases caused by those decisions. For example, we know that, since 1987, Australia Post has increased its basic postal rate from 36c to 41c. Another increase is due later this year, bringing the rate to 43c. We all know that Telecom has also been forced to increase its charges. These are charges well above those that should have been made.

As the present sales tax operates, there are arbitrary and very confusing anomalies which result in some retailers having a considerable competitive advantage over others. The big retailers with the wholesale arm are able to purchase goods from the manufacturers sales tax free. They then add the sales tax prior to the sale at the consumer level instead of at the wholesale level. This has a considerable advantage over those that follow the usual method in which the retailer marks up the wholesale invoice price of goods, which already includes the sales tax. The retailer's mark- up applies not only on the wholesale price but also on the wholesale and sales tax component of the goods. So the consumer ends up paying much more for the goods than he or she would otherwise have done.

It is not good enough for Mr Keating to say that he will try to review the legislation by simplifying it to reduce the costs imposed on small business by this tax. This tax also severely disadvantages consumers. It is not only small business and the Australian consumer who have been fleeced by this Government; this sales tax also applies to the inputs of exporters. Consequently, the disincentive to our exporters because of this tax is enormous. Something must be done. The Treasurer must take action to overcome the problems he has created. The burden on those disadvantaged groups is enormous. I have already pointed out that it is obvious that the Treasurer is getting too much tax through this secret method to move to a consumption tax, which would force him to compensate the low income earners and the pensioners. He has already created a sales tax of great proportions-that is, $10,500m to Consolidated Revenue-without any compensation being paid. He is most unlikely to change. However, he must make his sales tax system more just.

Since the election three Ministers have spoken out in frustration, telling the Treasurer he has to change his direction. They have said that he has to start making the hard decisions, that the Australian economy is in a disastrous situation. Yet, they say, this Treasurer will not take steps to bring matters under control. Senator Walsh tells us that he has wasted opportunity after opportunity. Senator Walsh assures Australians that Mr Hawke should have a spine transplant to help him make those hard decisions. What was the name Senator Walsh chose for the Prime Minister? It was Old Jellyback. We are told that Mr Keating is relying on high interest rates as the sole method of trying to stop people building their own homes because they have to import goods to do so.

Senator Button has joined Senator Walsh in a sudden rush of truthfulness. We all know the result of that. We all know how Mr Keating, to press home his superiority and his assurance that he is going to follow Mr Hawke to the leadership, told Senator Button a few home truths and made it extremely public. And now the new Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, has admitted that the Government has made times just too tough for small business. He has admitted that the Government's capital gains tax is part of the hardship of small business, and he has promised to defer the capital gains tax for small business under certain circumstances. He says:
I think it is very essential to defer it as part of making small business grow.

During the election, we told the people of Australia that a capital gains tax would inhibit small business growth. After the election Mr Beddall, in his new ministerial portfolio, said that he would defer capital gains tax under certain circumstances. It is not only Ministers who have been taking Mr Keating and Mr Hawke to task. All the major banks, one after another, have also been berating the Government. In today's newspapers we see the following headlines: `Hard times ahead, says bank chief', `Banks rule out soft landing' and `Warning of interest rate hike'. Today's Sydney Morning Herald reported Mr Nobby Clark, the National Australia Bank's Chief Executive, as follows:
. . . the economy has not bottomed, tougher times were ahead, and interest rates were `highly likely' to rise next year.
He described economic conditions as the worst he had seen in his history at the NAB, and predicted the recession, which he described as `Patchy', would stretch into next year.
Mr Nobby Clark said that people would find various types of landings. In respect of some people he said:

They will find it won't be hard, it'll be terminal. For some people it [the landing] will be hard, for some people it'll be soft, and for some people they'll have a great time and make a lot of money.

He emphasised that for some the conditions would be terminal. I notice the Deputy Government Whip, Senator McKiernan, nodding his head. He agrees with Nobby Clark. I would like to add the Deputy Government Whip to all those Ministers who have been warning the Government of the hard decisions it must make. The best Treasurer in the whole wide world has wrought upon Australia the worst economic conditions that Nobby Clark has seen in the history of the National Australia Bank.

Finally, Barry Jones said today that the Ministers are tired. He said that they have all worked too hard for too long and they are tired. He also said that Mr Hawke is showing the signs of battle fatigue. The new Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, horrified at what his public servants told him about the detrimental effects that the Australian waterfront has on the economy, rendering it completely uncompetitive, has promised to resign if in 12 months time he has not made substantial changes in his policy area. This Government has been in office for seven years, and we now have a new Minister offering to resign in 12 months time if changes are not made. What has occurred in seven years on the waterfront that has suddenly made this Minister so horrified? What has he been told by his public servants? We will see. The Government has never been game to take on the wharfies. While many promises have been made previously, nothing has ever been done.

In the March quarter, the number of bankruptcies in Australia was the highest on record. The figure of 2,142 was 26 per cent higher than that for the last March quarter. Mr Nobby Clark predicted a second wave of middle ranking business bankruptcies following the collapse of a number of leading Australian entrepreneurs. The sad thing is that Mr Keating, trying to save his credibility and trying hard not to back down or admit failure and take a change of direction, will create the dreadful unemployment that we will see in the next few months. Unemployment is increasing daily. As I have said, the March quarter was the worst quarter on record for bankruptcies. We know that they are going to increase in number. We know that we are now in a recession. Unemployment must be the most devastating thing that can happen to any Australian family. For the breadwinner suddenly to find that he is left without a job must be the most devastating thing a man could face.

I hope that the Treasurer does not consider his reputation and credibility to be more important than at last admitting that he was wrong. The J-curve is never going to turn up until he changes his tactics. Unless we face up to that dreadful term `micro-economic reform'-which simply means making the waterfront, for example, perform so that Australian exporters can compete-and unless the Government is willing to take on those challenges, Australia will not recover. Mr Keating will go down in the history books not as the best Treasurer, but as the worst on record.
Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.
