SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak about illegal drugs, about corruption which has been claimed in relation to these drugs and about one citizen's concern that his complaints have not been adequately investigated. One of the privileges of serving in the Parliament is that occasionally one can act to bring the grievances of individual citizens to the Parliament, demand that action be taken upon those grievances, demand that action be taken to follow up any demands that citizens have and, in short, act as a channel for the airing of grievances, the testing of constituents' complaints and the relief of perceived injustice.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not really an easy task. Many of those with whom one has to deal in these circumstances are not easy people to relate to. Sometimes that may be why they have troubles in the first place. Some people are, by nature, prickly; some people are, by nature, difficult. That does not mean that they are necessarily wrong in what they allege. Some people lack balance in their attitudes and views; they lack balance in the way they express things. That does not mean that they are necessarily wrong, although that is often an ad hominem ground on which what they say is attacked. Sometimes the troubles which people have make them difficult. The case I will set out tonight will indicate one person's troubles, and if he was not difficult at the end of it I do not think he would be normal. But, in fairness, I think one has to admit that it is often difficult to remain balanced and reasonable in view or outlook when one believes that one has been subjected to very great injustice.

When one is faced with material which alleges injustice and corruption, as a parliamentarian I think one has the duty, and the opportunity as well, to examine and assess it and determine whether or not it needs to be aired here. I have seen such material, and I have presumed that it should be aired here. I remember my colleague John Dowd airing some material in the 1970s in New South Wales. He was laughed out of the parliament and out of the leadership, but he was proved to be right. We have had in New South Wales in the last few days revelations by Mr John Hatton, who has tried to bring together some of the allegations about drug use.

I have got such a matter for the Senate tonight and, as will become clear, I indicate that I have done Senator Tate the courtesy of advising him that I will be speaking. I have spoken to him personally. He knows what I am speaking about. He knows the case very well. He is not disposed to respond, but I am going to raise it anyhow.

The case concerns a Mr Mehmed Skrijel. He was formerly a fisherman of Southend in South Australia and before that he lived at Digby in Victoria. Mr Skrijel has several complaints which I think should be made known to the Senate. They are so serious that it is not possible to ignore them, and neither is it proper to take them lightly.

Mr Skrijel alleges, first, that he witnessed a fellow fisherman in South Australia picking up drugs which had been dropped at sea off a passing ship. Mr Skrijel saw them picked up and put on a fishing boat which then landed at Southend, the port from which it was operating. He was informed by his deckhand, who knew what was going on, that the package contained heroin. We understand that there was a distribution network extending from Southend into Adelaide. We understand that there was an organised drug importing operation, operating from Southend, in which the drugs were picked up by fishermen. The first allegation is that when Mr Skrijel made this known to the appropriate authorities nothing was done about it.

Second, Mr Skrijel asserts that the allegation was ignored by those who could have done something about it. He says that when the matter was finally investigated it was by policemen, one of whom turned out to be corrupt himself-and I will just take the Senate through that little episode. The then Premier of South Australia, Mr Corcoran, said that some investigations should be carried out, and he sent two policemen to Victoria, where Mr Skrijel then lived, to interview him. One policeman was the head of the Drug Squad, named Superintendent Lean, and he had with him a Detective Senior Sergeant named Barry Moyse. The interview which they conducted, having been instructed by Premier Corcoran, lasted two minutes, according to Mr Skrijel, and they then reported back that the allegations which Mr Skrijel had made had no substance and should not be investigated further.

The third allegation that Mr Skrijel makes is that pressure was brought on him to be quiet, to forget the whole affair, and that when those suggestions were ignored and failed he was harassed and driven out of the fishing town in which he worked. His boat and his home were burned. He was bashed, and his family was harassed.

The fourth thing that Mr Skrijel alleges is that he was then framed by the police. I had better say something about that. Mr Skrijel was certainly arrested by police in Victoria. He was certainly charged by Victorian police with growing cannabis at his property at Digby and with an explosives offence. There is no doubt about that. He was certainly convicted in the County Court at Ballarat on 1 April 1987. He was certainly sentenced on 10 July 1987 to serve two years imprisonment with a minimum of nine months to serve in gaol. He certainly served a prison sentence for that offence. But he says that he was innocent, that he was framed by the police, and he alleges that they were police working with the involvement of the National Crime Authority (NCA)-a most serious charge.

What else do we know with certainty? We know that Mr Skrijel appealed against the conviction. We know as a matter of fact that the appeal succeeded, that the conviction was set aside and that a retrial was ordered on 6 May 1988 by the Full Bench of the Supreme Court of Victoria. We know for a fact that the conviction was quashed and a new trial ordered, and we also know for a fact that the Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria has now entered a document known as a nolle prosequi, which means that there will be no retrial of Mr Skrijel's case.

So here is a man who is arrested, charged, tried, convicted, sent to gaol and has his conviction quashed, but who is told that there will be no retrial; there will be no chance for him to test in public again the allegations against him. Mr Skrijel alleges that not all his property held by police or the NCA has been returned to him. In particular, six tapes prepared by a private investigator named Matthews who was commissioned by Mr Skrijel to prepare the tapes, which contain vital information, were taken by a Sergeant Iddles and have not been returned. Receipts are held for them. Correspondence exists concerning the tapes, and we understand that they are in the possession of the National Crime Authority. They have not been returned to Mr Skrijel, even now that we know there will be no retrial. So where are the tapes? The tapes are very serious.

Mr Skrijel has served a term in gaol for a conviction now set aside. I imagine that his legal advisers would now wish to discuss with him the real questions as to whether he has any right to compensation. But it is up to them to pursue this matter; it is not a question for the Senate. He has had no recompense of any kind. I believe that the policeman, Barry Moyse-I do not know the rank he finally held-is now in gaol. So one of the police who interviewed Mr Skrijel and said that there was nothing to his allegations is now in gaol-I think, from memory, serving a term of 25 years for drug related offences. But his dismissal of Mr Skrijel's original allegation still stands; it has not been rejected.

I do not for one moment hold myself out to be an Emile Zola or anything like that, but I cannot help remembering that history of the Dreyfus affair where a scapegoat went to prison until someone would speak up on his behalf. Honourable senators will remember the story of Alfred Dreyfus, an officer in the French Army who was accused of selling state secrets to the Germans, was convicted and sent to Devil's Island but who continued to maintain his innocence until the matter was re-examined and he was cleared completely. Other culprits were identified and he was restored to a place of honour.

We really cannot ignore this material. We have had in Australia a mass of occurrences-leaving the Skrijel matter to one side-which have involved official and police corruption. What I am talking about follows a mass of episodes of corruption around Australia. The latest has been the behaviour towards Mr Harry Blackburn by his fellow police officers. That is now a matter of public record. I have already mentioned that as long ago as the mid-1970s my friend John Dowd was detailing corruption in New South Wales. He was laughed out of the leadership then, but he has been vindicated since. Of course, he is now the Attorney-General in New South Wales and investigating these matters with some vigour.

We have had demonstrated to us in this country over some years that there is corruption in the police-well demonstrated; corruption in politics-well demonstrated; corruption in the magistracy-well demonstrated; corruption in the Australian Customs Service and corruption at judicial level. It has all been demonstrated. It is not as if what I am suggesting is new. We are seeing today the fallout from investigations in Queensland and we have yet to see the end results of the investigations carried out by the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales. We should start from the premise that it is more likely that there is corrupt behaviour going on than that there is not. The inquiry into the Winchester murder remains incomplete. I do not know what result that is going to reveal. Mr Hatton raised last week in New South Wales other matters which should concern all Australians.

Mr Skrijel believes that the system is corrupt and that he has been treated unjustly and unfairly. He believes-and, on the surface, with good grounds-that the corruption which affected him is related to drug importation. He believes that the corruption which has affected him involves the police force in South Australia, the police force in Victoria and the National Crime Authority. That is what Mr Skrijel believes.

He believes he was set up deliberately with false evidence and perjury and that this was done because his determination to air his original observations of a drug pick-up at sea was inconvenient and threatening. That is why he thinks he was set up. That is why his boat was burned. That is why his house was burned. He believes, further, that his claims to this effect have been ignored, turned aside, trivialised, given only scant and superficial investigation or dismissed because he is seen as a prickly and difficult person. He believes he has been given bland assurances without any good reasons to accept them.

Mr Deputy President, I have an enormous series of letters here which I will come back to in a moment. I am going to seek to incorporate some of them in Hansard. One is a letter dated 3 February 1989 from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to Mr Berthelsen, who was the attorney for Mr Skrijel, setting out Senator Tate's view that there is nothing in Mr Skrijel's story and containing, in the final paragraph, Senator Tate's assurance as follows:
I wish to make clear that the Government has full confidence in the integrity of the National Crime Authority.
I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Justice
Senator The Hon. Michael Tate
3 February 1989
Dear Mr Berthelsen
I refer to your letters of 6 September 1988 and 10 November 1988 concerning the trial and conviction in the Victorian County Court of Mr Mehmed Skrijel for drug and firearm offences.

As you stated in your letters, the Full Bench of the Victorian Supreme Court, in upholding Mr Skrijel's appeal, ordered a retrial. I am advised that no decision on whether to proceed has been taken by the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions. As this is a State matter, any further queries should be directed to that office.

Your letters also contained allegations of corruption in the National Crime Authority's handling of Mr Skrijel's case. The information concerning alleged illegal activities in Southend which Mr Skrijel provided to the Costigan Royal Commission was passed to the National Crime Authority in October 1984. The Royal Commission had made preliminary inquiries but did not undertake any further investigation of the matter. In November 1984 the National Crime Authority resolved to undertake an ordinary investigation into the allegations. The outcome of that investigation is of course known to you.

I note that your letter of 10 November 1988 (paragraph 11) implies that there was inaction by the Commonwealth Government with respect to Mr Costigan's recommendations for a Royal Commission into the matters discussed in confidential Volume 7 of his report. The facts of the matter are that the Government passed these matters to the National Crime Authority under formal reference for full investigation. The outcome of this investigation was several successful prosecutions of key drug trafficking principals with resultant lengthy goal terms and current legal action directed at the recovery of the proceeds of their criminal activity. I should add that there is no mention of Mr Skrijel's allegations in Volume 7 of the Costigan Report.

At the specific request of the South Australian Government and following full agreement by the Commonwealth and all State Governments, the National Crime Authority has recently established a full time office in Adelaide. The Governor-General has appointed Mr Mark Le Grand as an additional member of the Authority specifically to investigate allegations of corruption including drug trafficking in that State. Mr Le Grand's appointment commenced on 1 January 1989 for an initial period of twelve months. In the circumstances, I have decided to forward a full set of your documentation to Mr Le Grand for his attention.

With respect to penalties for drug trafficking, the Government is satisfied that penalties ranging from life to ten years for indictable offences depending on the nature and quantity of the drug involved, are appropriate at the present time. Sentencing of offenders is a matter for the courts and it would be improper for the Government to interfere in that process.

Finally, I wish to make clear that the Government has full confidence in the integrity of the National Crime Authority. I have no evidence to suggest the need to conduct an inquiry into its activities in relation to Mr Skrijel's case or any other matter.
Yours sincerely
Michael Tate
Mr David Berthelsen
GPO Box 1991
CANBERRA ACT 2601

The second letter is also from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, dated 13 October 1989. I interpolate here that there has been a fair bit of correspondence going backwards and forwards on this matter over some years. This letter again is an effort by Senator Tate-who has tried to respond to some of these representations-to set out some of the matters raised by Mr Skrijel. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Justice
Senator The Hon. Michael Tate
Dear Mr Berthelsen
I refer to your letter of 10 November 1988 concerning allegations by Mr Mehmet Skrijel against the National Crime Authority (NCA).

As I indicated in my letter of 2 February 1989, I passed a full set of the documents you provided to the National Crime Authority for their advice. As a result of my request, the NCA undertook an internal review of the allegations raised in your letter. The Authority is of the opinion that nothing in the material forwarded by you justifies it commencing a new enquiry into either the allegations concerning drug importations and corruption in South Australia made by Mr Skrijel or the allegation raised in your letter that evidence put forward in the trial and subsequent appeal of Mr Skrijel was fabricated by the NCA.
In addition, the NCA obtained the advice of Mr Ian Robertson, a Victorian Counsel, on:
(i) whether there had been any failure on the part of the National Crime Authority to properly investigate the Skrijel allegations; and
(ii) whether there is any evidence of a `frame up' by officers of the National Crime Authority in relation to the offences in respect of which Skrijel was charged and stood trial.
After reviewing the whole of the material, Mr Robertson has concluded in respect of (i)

``Because of the extraordinary difficulties surrounding the investigation of the Skrijel allegations I found it exceedingly difficult to sort out fact from fiction, or perhaps even from fantasy. This factor must have presented as a formidable obstacle to the investigating officers.

In my opinion no further investigations into the allegations made by Skrijel are warranted but I have no doubt the file remains open in the hope that at some stage some substantive evidence might be obtained to support the allegations and thereby warrant further investigation.

Whilst I have the greatest sympathy for the tragic plight of Skrijel and his family I have the distinct impression upon reading the material that many of his problems are of his own making, influenced by his diagnosed mental condition''
And, in respect of question (ii):

There is absolutely no evidence from the documentation before me to suggest a `frame up' by officers of the National Crime Authority. Neither is there any apparent motive for such a frame up on the part of such officers.

If indeed there was a `planting' of evidence on Skrijel it would seem to me to have been a pretty amateur attempt, and lacking all the hallmarks of organised crime. However, I repeat that in my opinion there is absolutely no evidence in support of such an allegation, which allegation is commonly raised by way of defence in criminal trials.

In view of the long and complex history of this matter and in view of Skrijel's obvious and stated distrust of all members of law enforcement agencies I am unable to recommend any further investigations into Skrijel's allegations of a `frame up'. Such an investigation at this stage would I feel be totally unproductive and would not in any event satisfy Skrijel.''

I am further advised by officers of my Department that after reviewing the above mentioned reports they are in agreement with their substance, and recommend that no further action be taken on this matter. I accept their advice.

As I mentioned in my previous letter, the question of Mr Skrijel's retrial is a matter for the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions to determine. In the circumstances, I do not think it appropriate to enter into any further discussions concerning Mr Skrijel's allegations at this time.
Your Sincerely
(Michael Tate)
Mr D. Berthelsen
GPO Box 1991
CANBERRA ACT 2601

What has happened to the claims made by Mr Skrijel has an uncanny resemblance to the treatment meted out, say, to those who first raised claims of corruption in Queensland or New South Wales-claims that have been shown subsequently to have some substance. The people who raised them are not necessarily wrong. I put this to the Senate: If Mr Skrijel did see some drugs being picked up off Southend, why was that not investigated with more vigour? Why will anyone not acknowledge that there is some substance to it?

Mr Skrijel complained to the police in South Australia again and again about the drug-running operation. He complained again and again about the harassment of him personally, he complained about the harassment of his family, and he complained about the damage to his property. He says that this was all due to his refusal to become part of the system and to take part in an illegal business of drug-running.

There was actually a coronial inquiry into the burning of Mr Skrijel's home and his boat. The coroner, Mr Kevin Rheam, stated on both occasions that it was not accidental, but was arson caused by persons unknown. That does not sound like a person who does not know what he was talking about. Mr Skrijel was right. He was the subject of the deliberate burning of his home and his boat-that much has been determined in a coronial inquiry. When Mr Skrijel finally had his claims investigated by the South Australian police, one of the men in that team was a man now in gaol for a long time for his own involvement in major drug affairs. Why should Mr Skrijel have any confidence in that investigation? I do not.

It was soon after this that the police managed to raid Mr Skrijel's home in Digby, Western Victoria, to arrest him, to charge him with marijuana cultivation and trafficking and to have him convicted. But then they were unable to have the conviction stand and, when the case got to the Full Bench of the Supreme Court in Victoria, that conviction was quashed. But Mr Skrijel served a sentence in prison. I will read what one of the judges said in allowing Mr Skrijel's appeal. Of the evidence used to charge him with cultivating cannabis, the judge said:

. . . wholly circumstantial and the defence was that the applicant had been set up by persons anxious to discredit him as reliable in his constant and vociferous allegations of heroin smuggling by sea in the area.
The point is that the judges believed Mr Skrijel and they set the conviction aside.

At the trial when he was convicted, Sergeant Iddles, one of the police officers, told the court-and this is in the transcript-that he had actually investigated 26 allegations made by Mr Skrijel. He said:
Some things he says I've substantiated as being correct.

The police themselves acknowledge that what Mr Skrijel was alleging in court had some truth. That was sworn evidence at the trial and it is available in the transcript. It is not as if there is nothing to the allegations. With the jury absent, the Crown prosecutor, Mr Lee, acknowledged that the events described by Mr Skrijel had occurred; he only questioned Mr Skrijel's interpretation of them. And that is an open matter.

Why is it that the Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria has decided not to take the matter further-not to have a retrial and not to give Mr Skrijel the opportunity to have a verdict of not guilty entered? Why was that decision made? That would have required the various witnesses to be cross-examined again. A nolle prosequi is a neat way of ensuring that there is no further court appearance on this matter in this case.

What we are concerned about here is whether those whom we have set up to protect us are themselves free of corruption. Those of us who are Latin scholars and have studied Juvenal will know the phrase quis custodiet ipsos custodes-who is to guard the guards themselves? This is a very apt phrase. We are told when we ask questions about the National Crime Authority that we cannot be given any detailed answers-that the operations of the Authority are matters not to be aired in the Parliament. I do not necessarily disagree with that. I happen to have high regard for the Minister, Senator Tate. I know that he has been concerned about this case. I say to Senator Tate that it does not compute, it does not add up. It is not sufficient just to say that this is a difficult, prickly man; of course he is. I would be difficult and prickly if I had gone through what he has gone through. It is not enough to say that there will be more investigations. There is a difficulty. I understand that Senator Tate would say to me, `I cannot release the operational details of the NCA operations in public'. I understand that.

What I am asking him is what is going to be done to investigate what seemed to be quite serious and not unfounded allegations by a citizen who served a term in gaol unnecessarily without a conviction standing against his name? What is going to be done to investigate those allegations now when the man believes that the NCA has been part of the frame-up which caused him to go to gaol. If the NCA is afraid of what he is saying, that is one thing; but I do think it is. What we have to find is some mechanism by which it is possible to investigate Mr Skrijel's allegations properly to ensure that he is treated fairly, and to ensure that the authorities against whom he has made the allegations have to explain what they have done.

I want to propose to the Minister that he might consider finding some independent party, acceptable to both sides of the argument-acceptable to the NCA, acceptable to the police and acceptable to Mr Skrijel-so that that person might be able to get a complete briefing on the allegations made by this citizen and to advise both Mr Skrijel and the Parliament, perhaps, as to whether there is any substance in them.

Mr Skrijel has different wishes. He has five wishes: First, he wishes to appear as a witness before the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority; that Committee exists and he wants to appear before it. I will certainly pass this speech on to that Committee. Secondly, he wants the National Crime Authority to report on all his accusations and allegations in detail, rather than just send us a brief letter such as the one we received from Mr Justice Stewart-again a person I know personally and for whom I have a lot of regard-that simply says in half a page that there is nothing to it. Mr Justice Stewart has sent me a letter as well, and in about half a page has said that there is nothing in the allegations. We want a detailed response to each of the allegations. Thirdly, Mr Skrijel wants the NCA to list each of the allegations and to respond to each allegation separately, because he thinks at the moment that he is just being given the flick.

Fourthly, he wants the NCA to return to him the six tapes which are legally his and which are held by the NCA-tapes which Mr Skrijel paid for when he commissioned a Mr Matthews to make them but which have been taken and held by the NCA. Fifthly, he wants to ask a question about one particular piece of property; it is a shotgun. It is a shotgun which Mr Skrijel does not own but which the police seized; they say they seized it from his property. What is interesting is that he was arrested on 29 October 1986 but the gun appeared only some three and a half months later. Why do they allege it is his gun? He wants to know where it came from, whose it is and what it has to do with the case.

I have used the occasion of the Appropriation Bills to raise a question of a very serious grievance on behalf of a citizen. I have done it after about a year of soul-searching. I cannot investigate adequately to any end point the allegations of Mr Skrijel. I cannot decipher the claims, counterclaims and details. I do not try to; I am not a lawyer. What I do ask is that this Parliament take seriously the claims of this citizen who believes that he has been ill treated by authority and who believes that there is evidence of official corruption in what has happened to him. If the Parliament would do that, I would be well satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take some time tonight, in speaking to the Appropriation Bills before the Senate, to deal with the appropriations for the Department of Defence. I will make a general point at the start and then deal with several specific points as they relate to capability and equipment for the Australian defence forces. I welcome the appointment of the new Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). He will be a much more rational Minister than his predecessor, Mr Beazley, who had a charmed life with the press, whereas the reality is that few people have done more damage to the Australian defence forces than Mr Beazley did as a Minister because he was driven by his emotions and an ideology he had, not by the evidence presented to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley had such an infallible belief in his own judgment that he could not brook any criticism or debate about what he was doing. One of the sad consequences of this is that he has locked Australia into a way of responding for the decades ahead by the massive equipment purchases he made, some of which are quite inappropriate. He has narrowed the response capability that Australia can make in a defence way in a totally unacceptable manner for the years ahead. I know Senator Robert Ray reasonably well. I have a lot more confidence that he will be led by the evidence that is before him and not by his emotions.

The other thing I welcome is the appointment of both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate because the Senate traditionally, is the home of these two issues, with its more inquiring air and more time to debate the issues, as opposed to the tyranny of numbers which prevails in the House of Representatives. One must remember that under our Westminster system many of the decisions relating to defence and foreign affairs are traditionally matters of executive judgment and flow from the executive of the day. In a democracy it is proper that they are debated. It is very hard to run a decent debate if the Minister is not in the chamber. Decent debates are impossible in the House of Representatives because, as I have said, of the tyranny of numbers. They are possible in the Senate. I hope that now that we have both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Senate, we will see the development of debate on these subjects which really are very important to Australia because the most fundamental of all tasks of the Government is the security of the nation. It is one thing for the Government to have a view on what defence capabilities the Government should have and what actions it should follow in its foreign affairs, for the security of the nation. But the matter goes beyond that because it involves the development of the will of the nation so that when the Government speaks on an issue it knows it has the support of the community. The support of the community can be developed only if the community understands what is going on and it is absolutely essential that debate on defence and foreign affairs matters takes place.

In Australia we have a very modest defence capability. There is a need to improve that. Because of the changing circumstances that the world finds itself in that need is more pressing than it has been in the past. It will be a lot harder for the Government to do that in the years ahead. We are going to have a campaign run by the heirs and successors of the peace groups campaigning in the public arena for a reduction in defence expenditure. It is not only a matter of entering the debate and countering that by the Government; it is a matter of staying in it for the long haul. One of the things the Labor Government is not good at is staying in something for the long haul. One only has to look at the way it handled the narcotic drug debate in this country. We had a great splash some years ago on the drug initiative. All that money was wasted on a splurge of advertising campaigns based on a scare technique rather than developing understanding. What has happened? There has been a crashing silence since then. We simply cannot afford that in either the defence of this country or issues such as the drug education programs.

It is true that there has been a lowering of superpower tension. Australia has played a very honourable part through the last 45 years in supporting the Western democracies and in opposing communism and its expansion around the world. Despite vocal minorities at the time of the Korean war and the Vietnamese war, the will of the Australian community has basically been unquestioningly to support the Western democracies. Now we are seeking the success of that with a breakdown of communism in eastern Europe and around the world. That reduction in superpower tension will hopefully lead to the point we have always argued for on this side of the chamber, to merit mutual, balanced and verifiable reductions in arms amongst the superpowers. But that does not apply to Australia. As I have said before, our capabilities at present are inadequate.

The other problem we face is that whilst things may be approaching a level of stability in Europe they are certainly not approaching any stability in the region in which we live. If we look at the revolt in Fiji, the troubles in Vanuatu, New Caledonia, the recent problems in Bougainville, the wars that are going on in the Philippines tonight, to say nothing of the reckless expansion of India in the South Asia region, we cannot come to any conclusion other than that all the cardinal signs are out, that instability is brewing in the region. I cannot predict what form it will take or at what time it will occur.

Quite apart from the signs that are emerging at the moment, we see the Pacific Rim as an expanding and rapidly developing economic area. History tells us that economic rivalry often leads to military tensions and military conflicts. It would be a very foolish person who looked at the region in which Australia is situated and did not see and take some prudent action to protect Australia's essential interests through the next decade or two.

The responsibility of the Government is to enter the debate against the disarmament groups that are at present running around the Australian community. The anti-nuclear groups are no longer fashionable but they have shown their true colours. They used to react very much in the debates conducted three for four years ago when they were accused of being unilateral disarmers and pacifists. They denied that very strongly at the time but it is the same group who have now come on the public scene talking about the reduction in superpower tension and talking not about the reduction in armaments, but about the total disbanding of any defence capability at all. They are using precisely the same arguments they used to deny they possessed at the time they were running the anti-nuclear campaign.

This argument is an irrational one. I was in the United States and the United Kingdom in January. The degree of irrationality by some of the proponents of the disarmament cause in the United States, and to a lesser degree in the United Kingdom, is really quite staggering. The Secretary of the Defense Department, Mr Chaney, in the United States is talking about marginal reductions in expenditure over the next five years. In total they are of the magnitude of $7 billion or $9 billion. Given the size of the American defense budget that is really just trimming the edges. It is not a massive winding back at all. There are people out there in public places with the expectations of up to $300 billion or $400 billion a year suddenly being available to put everyone in luxury and ease, to get rid of every bit of sickness and hardship within the community. It really is getting a little out of hand.

The lessons that this Government should draw from that are that it has to get into the public educational field and put a rational case for Australia to maintain and, indeed, improve, its defence capabilities. At the end of the day a mature society has to accept the responsibility for its own security. That security cannot be developed when trouble starts. Just as one must insure one's property, not wait until the floods come or the house is on fire, and pay an insurance premium for many years of which one sees no return, at least one has the security of mind of being prepared when the worst eventualities occur.

The only thing that Senator McLean did not say earlier tonight as part of the new disarmament group was that Australia was embarking on a new round of militarism. I suppose he left that for Senator Vallentine. The Government has rationally and cogently to put the case for Australia to look after its own security. I am reminded of the problems we had five years ago when the peace movement was at its height. This Government just sat on its hands and did nothing at all. The battle against the peace and unilateral disarmers was carried on by the Liberal Party. It was the Liberal Party that organised the national peace through security campaign. It was organised on an individual State basis with an agreed central philosophy, talking about the importance of deterrence and about the need for mutual, verifiable and balanced reductions in arms. We held public meetings and wrote articles and the rest of it and fought the case and won it but nothing was done by this Government. My fear is that precisely the same position will take place unless the Government sees the danger of the position it is in and starts to move in a sustained and coherent way to educate the Australian public and gain their cooperation for the need for maintain our own security.

There are a couple of specific points in relation to defence estimates that I wish to deal with. These have been triggered off by some of the discussions that took place in Estimates Committee B. The first point I want to talk about is the retention of the Chinook helicopters. Much has been made about the way the Chinook helicopters could have been used in the recent floods in April in western Queensland and western New South Wales. As the Minister said, the reason for retaining helicopters is for their military use, not for their civil use. If we have them for military reasons certainly it is possible and proper for them to be used in an emergency such as a flood, cyclone or something like that.

Having been involved in the floods in western Queensland and having seen at close hand what the Australian defence forces did it would have been useful to have the Chinook there. It may well have been cheaper for the Government to have used those helicopters and not the other airlift facilities-the Hercules, the Caribou and the Iroquois-but maybe it was not. Certainly no-one's life was lost and no property was damaged because the Chinooks were not used. It just may have been more convenient if we had them.

The most important thing that came out in the Minister's public statements about the use of those helicopters was the fact that their sale is under review. I applaud the Minister for this. He has taken a very important decision there. I would argue very strongly the case to retain all of those Chinook helicopters. The Minister is quoting the Department of Defence and saying that the proposition is to explore whether it is feasible to keep three or four and upgrade them to the later standard or whether to get rid of them. But it is simply not practicable to retain only three or four. The Chinook CH-47C is a successful helicopter because it is a heavy lift helicopter. It will lift a great deal more than the Iroquois, which is the other common service helicopter. We can get roughly six fully armed soldiers into an Iroquois; we can get better than 30 into a Chinook.

The trouble with the Chinook is that it is a bit of a mechanical nightmare, it is very manpower intensive to keep flying, and it is expensive. Because of that the rest of the air forces in the world have changed from using them. In the early 1980s the United States Air Force did an upgrade program when it converted the three C models to D models. Essentially it doubled the horsepower of the engines, put in new transmissions, rotors and instrumentation, and ended up with a helicopter which had twice the lifting capacity of the C model and therefore gave about twice the range, and required about half the maintenance man-hours in supporting it. This is a very successful helicopter. There has been a great demand for these helicopters around the world and most of the C models have been converted to Ds.

The original project study was done in the early 1980s and USAF and other air forces have seriously got into it from about 1987 onwards. The proposition that the manufacturer, Boeing Vertol, put to the Australian Government was that it could convert the Cs to Ds at a cost then of about $9m per aircraft. Even if it is double that, it is still very cheap. If it costs $16m or $18m, we must remember that the Black Hawk helicopter the Army is getting is costing around $14m. The Government said it simply could not afford that sort of money. That is not correct. Out of a Budget of $8 billion a year it can certainly afford a couple of hundred million for helicopters. Under this Government the budget for defence has been contracting and it is simply a cost saving exercise.

On 22 May 1989 the then Minister announced that the helicopter squadron, 12 Squadron, would be disbanded on 1 July 1989. There was no reason for the squadron to have been closed down then. We would have had enough spares holding in the country to have kept it in operation for probably a year or two before it would have run down. It really was a cost cutting exercise. The squadron was closed down on 1 July 1989 and the aircraft have been mothballed at Amberley ever since, pending sale.
In answer to a question in the Senate last year Senator Richardson put the Government's point of view. He said, amongst other things:

The majority of the Chinook's tasks can be performed by the Black Hawk or by other elements of the force in being . . . the retention of the Chinook can be neither afforded nor justified. The Chinook costs about $7,080 per hour to operate, and the serviceability rates, despite the best efforts of the RAAF, have been very low. Australia's new battlefield helicopter, the Black Hawk, which will provide improved troop mobility, costs only $2,390 per hour to operate . . .

He went on to say that the project cost to upgrade the 11 Chinooks would be of the order of $200m. I think the figure would be considerably lower than that but I am quite happy, for the purpose of debate, that that figure be accepted.

It is really very dishonest for Senator Richardson-and he is only quoting the figures in a press release from the then Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley-to say that it cost $7,000-odd an hour to operate a Chinook and only $2,300 to operate a Black Hawk. The point is that if he were operating a truck it would be cheaper still. The fact of the matter is that the earning capacity or the work capacity per hour of a Chinook is very much more than two or three times that of a Black Hawk, and a Black Hawk simply cannot do the job. The Chinook is an essential part of the Australian Army's operational system. It is the only helicopter we have which can lift the M198 155 millimetre Howitzer, a gun that weighs 7,163 kilograms. The present Chinooks, without the upgrade, will lift a gun, its crew of 11 and 35 rounds of ammunition. It is an essential part of the Army's mobility. Since we do not have any self-propelled artillery, it is essential that we have that mobility.

Another thing about it is that it lifts heavy loads-heavy pallets of ammunition, very big rubber bladders full of fuel-and can deploy them at reasonably high speeds over considerable distances. The whole of the Australian Army's mobility pattern is built about having the Chinook. The new one will operate at a gross take-off weight, if the upgrade takes place, of 22,000 kilograms-somewhere in excess of 50,000 pounds that is; all up weight at take-off. The Black Hawk has a maximum take-off weight of only 9,900 kilograms. Its maximum payload is less than 5,000 kilograms. It is simply not in the same league, and there is no way we can equate two or three or four Black Hawks with one Chinook. They are simply designed to do different tasks, and we have a requirement for both. We have a requirement for a Black Hawk and we have a requirement for the Chinook.

The thinking behind the Minister's proposal-that we modify only three or four and sell the rest-is that what we get for the seven we sell will pay for the update of the other four. That is not a feasible thing to do. If we have only four helicopters, even though the maintainability of these will be very much better and they will last for 25 years when they are modified, we could not expect to have more than two on the line at any one time. If we start using them intensely we will lose one. We just do not have a viable fleet size to do anything with at those numbers. It is also economic nonsense to try to support only three or four aircraft. We cannot do it. By the time we train the crews, the maintenance crews and spares holding, the whole thing becomes wildly unbalanced. We have to do the eleven. It is simply a matter of rearranging some of the equipment priorities. We can easily find that $200m, even if we only space out the equipment delivery.

One of the other things that emerged in the defence estimates was debate about a helicopter platform. The Chief of the Naval Staff is pushing this rather strongly at the present time. I have spoken many times in the past about the need for maintaining the amphibious capability we had in this country which this Government has now disbanded. But it is quite wrong, in my judgment, to be talking about buying a new purpose-built ship. The correct procedure would be to modify not one but a number of the bulk carriers or container ships that are used around the Australian coast and to pay a subsidy to the owners to modify those ships so that we can put modules on board in an emergency which will provide the stores, the accommodation and the helicopter platforms for the operation of these ships in a supporting role.

Quite clearly, with the new ships that are being built-and we will be building new ships for the Australian coastal trade, as economic arguments about lower crew size, more efficient hull forms and the rest of it take place-the Government should be talking to the owners of these ships and, at the design stage, paying them a bounty to incorporate modifications which enable those ships to be used in an emergency as a helicopter support platform for an amphibious capability for the Australian defence forces.

We in this country have not had a very good record of using civilian assets for the Defence Force, but if we go back in history to the 1920s and 1930s it was quite common for the merchant marine in those days to be paid a subsidy by the government of the day to build in some defence capability. To a limited extent the Navy is doing this at the present time with COOP, the craft of opportunity minesweepers program, taking trawlers and modifying them slightly so that in an emergency they can be used as minesweepers. It is by far the preferable course, if we are in the market for a helicopter platform, to be looking at a civilian hull rather than a dedicated naval hull. It is far more cost effective to be doing that; but the provision of a helicopter ship happens to be a low priority.

The highest priority we have at the moment is the one that the Government does not address-that is, knowing what is going on in the air and sea space around our shores. I first spoke in 1979, and I have spoken consistently since then, on the need to develop and acquire an AEW capacity, that is, an airborne early warning capability, or preferably, an AWACs capability, that is, an airborne warning and control system. In 1982 I visited the Grumman aircraft corporation to look at its AWACs aircraft. In 1983 I visited Boeing to look at its E3A program and I have been twice to Lockheed. There are systems available to us.

The Government keeps saying that it would cost far too much and it would be beyond us to buy an AWACs aircraft. But I do not believe that. We do not have to buy the capability that the British, French and Americans need for the intense electronic warfare atmosphere of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries. We can get by with a simpler and cheaper system. I estimate that the cost for a fleet of four would be somewhere around $800m, which is not an enormous amount of money when one looks at the amount being expended. At the present time the French are buying four E-3D AWACs aircraft from Boeing at a project cost, all in, of $US715m. That includes the price of simulators, spares, ground support training and the rest of it. That would be the upper limit of the cost to us.

The provision of an AWACs capability is absolutely essential for all three Services-the Army, Navy and Air Force-because we must know what is going on around this country, even to use properly the new FA18s, the order for which was completed last week. That is the best contract the Government has ever entered into. It was written by a Liberal government after exhaustive investigation. The contract was delivered ahead of time and below cost. Despite the fairies at the bottom of the garden talking about a cost of $60m per aircraft, the true cost was about $24m per aircraft and it was extraordinarily cheap at the price. The only tragedy is that we did not buy more. It would be quite easy to pay for an AWACs capability by cancelling, or spreading out, the Navy contracts that we have at present. There is absolutely no argument for adding to the present order of six submarines, and the Government ought to kill that straight away. We certainly do not need a fleet of eight antique diesel-electric submarines.

In regard to the eight Anzac ships for which we have signed a contract, that contract has a break point in it at four. Those ships have a rather unfortunate design. They are simply of no use for what we require of them in the Pacific region. They are very expensive and functionally quite useless. They have a representational role. When Mr Paul Dibb first wrote his report and called for patrol frigates what was envisaged was a ship costing one third of these and about half their size. It would be quite proper for that program to be either spaced out or preferably reduced to four ships because our top priority is to be able to have knowledge of what is going on in our region. Unless we know what is going on we cannot effectively use the forces that we have. It is absolutely crucial, with a land, sea, and air area as vast as Australia's area of essential interest, that we know precisely what is going on, otherwise we dissipate all our forces by chasing will-o'-wisps over the whole area.

The primary need in relation to the Defence vote is for the Government to embark on an educational campaign regarding the need for this country to look after its own security. It should not only embark on a program, but sustain the argument and develop it, because we are going to be arguing this case for at least the next 10 years. I also propose to the Minister that he reassess the priorities that he has inherited with respect to the equipment program. Some of the equipment he has inherited is inappropriate. Clearly, we do have higher priorities. Even if the Minister is not prepared to cancel some of it, he, as the Minister, certainly has the ability to see that it is spaced out to allow more essential equipment to come on line at an earlier rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the lexicon of political terminology a new meaning has been given this year to the term `decisive mandate'. This Labor Government has made much of the fact that since 24 March it has achieved an `historic decisive mandate'. I would like to point out to the Senate just what this mandate represents. Final figures are not available yet, but Malcolm Mackerras estimates that, Australia wide, the Australian Labor Party obtained 49.4 per cent of the vote and the Liberal and National parties 50.6 per cent. In other words, Labor once again failed to obtain the majority of votes in percentage terms, with the coalition winning about 60,000 more votes than Labor. Of the first preference votes Labor won 39.7 per cent of the primaries, its lowest level since the 1977 election. The coalition gained 43.3 per cent-the Liberals 34.9 per cent and the Nationals 8.4 per cent. A decisive mandate? These are not precisely the figures I would have used to describe the word `decisive'.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia today there are six Labor governments and five of these won government with a minority of the vote in percentage terms. In the last Victorian State election Labor received 49.5 per cent of the two party preferred vote; 47.5 per cent in Western Australia; and 48.1 per cent in South Australia. In Tasmania, which has a different voting system for State elections, a minority Labor government in terms of seats governs with the support of Green Independents. In South Australia the Liberals recently won 51 per cent of the primary vote and could not achieve government. In Queensland, in the most recent State election-and I remind honourable senators that it was fought on exactly the same boundaries as the 1986 election-Labor won 51.4 per cent of the primary vote and gained 59 per cent of the seats.

Lest anybody quickly resurrects that dreaded beast the gerrymander, let me remind the Senate that in the last election in which my husband led the National Party to victory in Queensland, in 1986, it gained 39 per cent of the primary vote. The two party preferred vote never dropped below 51 per cent while my husband was Premier and, indeed, went as high as 59 per cent. It averaged 53 per cent during the 20-year period of government-a record unparalleled in Australian political history. We have to remember that in the Senate, where one cannot gerrymander the electorates, the swing to the Opposition is clearly shown by the fact that three coalition senators were returned in each State except New South Wales, where Senator Chris Puplick lost by only 450 votes.

Bob Hawke at present rules this nation with a comfortable majority on a primary vote of 39 per cent. Clearly, at the national level, and in Labor States, there is a gerrymander through the one vote, one value system. But where are the cries of gerrymander from the media? One could even be sarcastic and suggest an inquiry into this matter. Let us put to rest once and for all this gerrymander nonsense. I only trust that this Government will use its so-called `decisive mandate' or `comfortable majority' to recognise what the true majority of Australians need and are asking for.

At the end of the present three-year term of this Government I believe that even with one vote, one value the people of Australia will indeed vote for a change of government. I fear that this Government is already presenting a despairing future for the livelihoods of our fellow Australians, whether they be in the cities, provincial towns, or rural areas. As my colleague Senator Tambling described it, this Government has come up with a barren and bleak vision for the future, one that offers more to Cambodia and Antarctica than it does to northern Australia.

Only recently this Government failed to truly acknowledge the impact and cost of the recent devastating floods in western Queensland and New South Wales. This is on top of the fact that since coming to power in 1983 it has consistently failed to acknowledge the escalating costs of living for families in rural areas. It will be weeks before the full extent of the flood damage is known because over one million kilometres, the size of Germany, France and Britain combined, were flooded and significant additional areas will be flooded in the next few weeks as the floods move down the Cooper Creek into northern South Australia.

The severity and extent of the floods was highlighted by the need to evacuate Charleville and Nyngan; Cunnamulla almost suffered the same fate. There has been a magnificent response by the State Emergency Service, police, armed forces, council personnel, farmers and volunteers generally. Evacuees have shown courage and forbearance. Unfortunately there has been significant loss of crops, particularly vegetables and cotton, thousands of cattle and already thousands of sheep, with more to come.

Evacuation would have been easier and fewer livestock lost if the Government still had Chinook helicopters available. There is widespread support for retaining two or three for national disaster work. Unfortunately, 11 Chinooks are mothballed at Amberley air force base and the Government has advertised for a management consultant to sell them and their related spare parts. I was very interested too to listen to Senator MacGibbon, who spoke just before me, giving us some very important and interesting details about the Chinook helicopters, particularly of course in relation to their defence capability as well. However, I want to take this opportunity to thank Senator Robert Ray for his commitment in answer to a question that I asked him the other week to review the sale of these helicopters.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said the Australian Taxation Office will be sympathetic to requests by farmers and small businessmen for extensions of time to pay tax or complete provisional tax variation applications. However, there are two areas of taxation which are of considerable importance to the viability of the affected farmers. The first is the ability to obtain provisional tax rebates, even after the tax has been paid, as the floods have dramatically changed the potential income of many graziers, and a more realistic tax deductability for new fencing following a natural disaster such as flood or fire. In relation to that, I know from experience the tremendous damage that can be wrought to fences after a flood because we suffered the same problem on the Mackenzie River with a flood just a few years ago.

These floods are of course only a continuation of the trials that rural Australia has been facing in recent years. This Government proudly proclaims that it is in tune with the man on the land, that it is listening to and heeding the calls of average Australia. I say that it is not. As I have noted in the Senate many times before, there is not much point producing a product if it cannot be sold profitably. Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that eventually we see the demise of the family farmer, the person who spends unrecognised hours and efforts producing that end product.

The primary industries and energy sector of our economy is usually represented by regions far outside Australia's major population centres. They represent about 80 per cent of Australia's merchandising exports which have a major role to play in meeting two important national challenges: these are the current account deficit and related foreign debt level and the management of our natural resources to provide for ecologically sustainable longterm development.

As honourable senators would know, I represent a State which is very proud of its place in helping Australia to meet its economic challenges. Queensland is a very decentralised State. It is a State which is at least 1,500 miles to the north and then 1,000 miles to the west. I have made many trips over the years throughout the State and realised the value of primary industries and the tremendous contribution they make to the economy. However, it saddens me that too often people, especially many in the Government, fail to realise the tremendous cost to rural industries in trying to meet the challenges of giving Australia a buoyant economy.

This Government chooses to penalise those who work in our primary industries and sometimes, I think, deliberately, fails to recognise not only the physical hardship of working in that environment, but also the tremendous financial burden being placed on the shoulders of the man on the land. Perhaps I had better say on the woman of the land too in most cases, because the woman really does stand behind the man in rural Australia.

It is all very well to have the land and the seed to grow the crops or allow the livestock to graze, but often what is forgotten is that to get to the end product, to make ends meet, the man on the land has to rely on things over which he has no control. First of all he has to hope that he has rain to let the crops grow. He has to hope that there will be good markets and prices for his goods, that interest rates will not cripple him, that fuel prices will not be prohibitive and that the roads to transport those goods will be passable. After he plants the seed and waits for rain, the farmer then would possibly have to clean up the crop for weeds and spray for bugs. Finally, if he does get a crop to harvest he either looks at using large machinery which costs an enormous amount of money to buy or otherwise employs workers to come in and help with the harvesting. This is where a lot of expenses come into being on the land.

So many expenses are often multiplied by the cost of fuel. If all the tax on fuel were used on roads, rural people, indeed people everywhere in Australia, I believe, would feel much better. We all recognise that road funding is becoming increasingly critical to Australia as the consequences of the current government cutbacks are becoming more and more apparent. These consequences do not show up in the short term. They occur progressively as a result of lower maintenance standards and an inability to increase the capacity of the roads system to meet growing demand. Ultimately they produce higher vehicle operating costs, less efficient industries, and more road deaths and injuries.

Unprecedented publicity campaigns by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ) and the Queensland Local Government Association show the seriousness of the situation at grassroots level. I am sure that many honourable senators are aware of road deficiencies in their own localities, which need urgent attention. Cuts have had a major impact, particularly in country areas. It has become impossible to keep up with the demand for new and improved roads to cater for the needs of the transport industry and the individual motorist.

Earlier this year the RACQ undertook a State-wide survey of roads and found that country roads are so rough that motorists are often forced to drive on the shoulders rather than on the potholed bitumen. It found that many roads become impassable when it rains and that they are deteriorating more rapidly than city and shire councils can repair them. Existing networks are rapidly falling into disrepair because of the decline in maintenance allocations. While the Federal Government continues to tax road users at discriminatory levels it must take major responsibility for funding roads.

About half of the money spent by motorists on petrol goes to the Federal Government. For every litre of petrol or diesel purchased, the Government takes about 23c in tax, returning only about 5 3/4c to the motorists in the form of road funding. This has a particularly draining effect on the financial capacity of people in rural areas to survive. Not only do these people pay higher costs for that fuel, as it has to be transported to them, but they use far more fuel in order to travel the further distances. Yet I am sure that if most Australian motorists were surveyed we would find that they would not complain at the high level of tax they pay for every litre of petrol if they knew that that money went into improving our current road network. However, sad to say, it does not. Instead, it goes into Consolidated Revenue, never to be used on roads but rather on social engineering programs of a dubious and, perhaps, questionable value.

Often, when assessing the rural industries, we talk only in terms of how much they have contributed to Australia's growth and not of the effort made to achieve exports. However, I would like to remind the Senate that in an effort to achieve low cost internationally competitive industries, the Government has to be aware that it could be killing the goose that lays the golden egg. If in the process to achieve cost efficient industries we push the small family farmer off the land, we, in the long run, are serving no real good purpose for Australia.

Only late last year many honourable Senators would have read of disturbing figures which show that farmers are losing money fast with costs increasing at twice the rate of income. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics September quarter index showed an average 1.2 per cent increase on prices received, whereas this was heavily outweighed by a 2.1 per cent increase in the costs paid out. This has occurred under a Labor Government which then has the effrontery to claim that farmers are pleased with the Federal Government and that it is aiming to provide a cost efficient farming sector.

I do not know what criteria the Government would use for such a claim but I can assure honourable senators that if a person's income is being steadily eroded at a rate where the costs to earn it are twice the rate of actual income, any thinking Australian would know that that person is going backwards and would not be too happy with that situation. Perhaps that is what this Government means by cost efficiency in the rural sector! I do not believe that any honourable senators in this place would be happy to see their income eroding quickly like that.

We should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to replace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today and it is at the expense of one of the most important sections of our community-the economic survival of the small family farmer. I am very pleased, indeed, to have this opportunity in the Senate tonight to put down some of the problems that so many rural people are experiencing at the present time.

I come from the south Burnett region where a task force has had to be set up to look at all of the problems of the peanut industry, the navy bean industry and the soya bean industry. We have had so many bad seasons in that area that farmers are unable to find enough money to carry on. They are in a situation where they really need some substantial financial help. If they cannot get it from the banks I would like to think that the Government would be willing to help in situations such as that.
