DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1990SALES TAX (Nos 1 TO 9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate is debating cognately a series of Bills relating to sales tax. When governments amend sales tax legislation, they must actually amend a series of Bills to conform with the constitutional requirement that separate taxing Bills are necessary for each item subject to tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the Senate tonight must be described as unusual. I use that word for a particular purpose, because this legislation offends the Government's own dogma in two important respects. Firstly, this legislation runs counter to the Button car plan, which is about the lowering of tariffs. The legislation before us actually introduces a new level of tariff. That is effectively what it does. Secondly, it is in breach of the guidelines of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which are set out in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Handbook, to the effect that legislation by press release is only to be, to use the words of that particular handbook, issued under the Prime Minister's pen and justifiable to correct an abuse of or a deficiency in revenue laws. The principle in that is that, inherent in legislation by press release, there is a retrospective practice which is to be abhorred by all who wish to be governed by the rule of law. Legislation by press release makes a mockery of the rule of law. Tonight, before we debate this legislation, it offends on two counts: it runs contrary to the Government's own Button car plan and it is in breach of the Government's own guidelines in respect of the need for a press release to conform to the rule of law.

These sales tax Bills were not part of the 1989 Budget, but rather were part of a so-called February economic statement following an accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) which was approximately accord mark six. This was produced in a hothouse atmosphere leading up to the last election. It is often referred to as the politics of envy. The success of these so-called accords which I have referred to is rather dubious. The Institute of Public Affairs has reminded us of the following:

Latest OECD figures show that during the period of the Accord the rate of growth in Australian labour costs increased much more than in other OECD countries. After falling below the OECD rate in 1984, the growth rate in Australia's labour costs has now jumped to twice that for the OECD.

Other results of the research show that, although the average growth rate in Australia's labour cost was slower during the Accord period than in the previous seven years, OECD labour costs slowed even more. As other OECD countries did not have accords, this could suggest the Accord may not have been a significant influence in reducing labour costs.

The legislation before the Senate increases from 30 per cent to 50 per cent the rate of sales tax on motor cars and station wagons, which also includes four-wheel drives, with a wholesale value of over $28,793. When calculating depreciation values, this is an upper limit of $42,910. It has a brighter side, in that the legislation also contains provisions to reduce from 30 per cent to 20 per cent the rate of sales tax on motor vehicles that have been specifically fitted out for the transportation of disabled persons who are seated in wheelchairs. These vehicles are generally referred to as metrocabs. This reduction is indeed welcome.

The legislation should produce a net revenue gain of $105m in a full year. However, the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries and the Motor Trades Association of Australia believe that the revenue effect will be neutral because of an expected downturn in sales arising from the increased tax. This tax was to have first applied from 1 April. It has been deferred until 1 May, the date in the proposed legislation before the Senate.

There are problems so far as the industry is concerned. It is not surprising that the industry is complaining that it cannot impose a tax at the higher rate until the legislation is passed, yet will be liable for the tax when the retrospective law is passed. However true this may be, the Australian Taxation Office has intervened and indicated that no penalties will apply to dealers who impose the higher charge because the new impost will be easy to avoid for some months and it may even provide some windfall gains to some unscrupulous dealers, as I will explain later.

Because of these particular problems with the commencement date, I now foreshadow an Opposition amendment which will be moved during the committee stage and which will delete the operative date of 1 May. This will have the effect of the Bill coming into play 28 days after receiving royal assent.

It must be remembered that the sales tax is levied at the time of the last wholesale sale-that is, from wholesaler to retailer. Car dealers for many years have deferred sales tax by adopting what is known as a floor plan arrangement whereby the dealers do not obtain legal title to the vehicles until immediately before they sell them. However, if the dealers buy the luxury vehicles before 1 May, the new sales tax will not apply even though the car may not be sold to a consumer for many months or even years afterwards. Indeed, some not necessarily unscrupulous but perhaps forward thinking dealers could overcome the problems of future sales by this mechanism. But some unscrupulous dealers could even charge customers the full 50 per cent of tax even though they bought the vehicle at the current 30 per cent impost, as a result of the arrangements which I have mentioned before, through the operation of separate wholesale and retail companies. The Government would be blamed, with the car dealer making enormous profits.

The luxury car market has surged prior to the announcement of this imposition date, with many prospective sales crystallising prior to 1 May. A severe lull is now expected, except for those who purchased forward using this mechanism of interposed companies. The legislation actually runs counter to the Button car plan and causes certain legal problems faced by dealers. I wish to draw attention to the article in the Australian by its legal correspondent David Solomon, which stated:

It would appear that the Government has put Australia's new car dealers in an impossible position. Apparently if dealers charge the 50 per cent tax rate due to their customers, they are clearly acting illegally and would be subject to heavy penalties. If they charge customers only the existing 30 per cent they will be later hit by the Tax Office for a retrospective tax of 20 per cent and possible penalties which they cannot legally recover from their customers.

It is just not good enough for the Government to put dealers in a double jeopardy situation by trying to make them collect taxes from consumers which are illegal and must remain so until and unless the Parliament legislates to change the present law.

Therefore, the Opposition proposes an amendment that has the effect of deleting clause 2, which means that the provisions of the Bill, if it is passed, will come into being 28 days after the Bill has received royal assent. It is indeed an inequitable tax. It is very selective. It is a tax of envy. It is a tax to placate the traditional Labor vote, brought in not at Budget time but immediately before an election. Why does the Government not choose other commodities-champagne, perfume, caviar? Why cars at a certain rate? The legislation will cause a number of problems.

While we are debating this item of sales tax, I must say that it is pleasing that the Australian Taxation Office is rewriting its sales tax rulings to remove so many of its inconsistencies and to standardise the rulings in line with the current law. The Government should go a long way further. Sales tax needs a complete revision because of its arbitrary classifications, its ad hoc composition and the difficulties of finding a proper wholesale value in an age when wholesale merchants are so few in number compared with, say, 20 years ago.

I believe that the Opposition has rightly put on the agenda for community debate the reform of the indirect tax base. In fact, the coalition leadership shows in this consumption tax debate that the coalition continues to set the political agenda. Debate on our side of politics acknowledges that pensioners and low or fixed income earners need to be appropriately compensated in any discussion relating to a consumption tax.

While this Government is peddling the admirable concept of simplifying the tax laws, we have before the Senate legislation which adds a new dimension, a new scale, a new rate. We are lifting the sales tax on luxury cars from 30 per cent to 50 per cent-an election ploy, as one newspaper said, to consolidate Labor's traditional vote. But it is another example of a quick fix solution to the hard task of trying to mend an economy that is increasingly moving into recession. Unfortunately, this quick fix mentality, appealing to traditional voters, is no way of overcoming the current dilemmas faced by the Australian community.

The announcement during the election campaign of the imposition of this dramatic increase in the sales tax on luxury cars is a prime example of a practice which has caused much concern. The choice of the effective date-1 April, moved to 1 May-all the complications and legalities that dealers will have to face and the unfortunate but necessary intervention by the Australian Taxation Office to indicate that it would not be implementing penalties make for a bad case of tax legislation; it is a bad example of tax administration.

This example of legislation by press release under these circumstances is most abhorrent. It is abhorrent because it runs counter to the principle that we should not have retrospectivity, particularly in areas where there is no special justification for it, for example, to correct an abuse or deficiency in revenue laws. Not all would agree with that concept, but the Labor Party does. It runs contrary to its own written statement, to its own dogma. So we have an example of legislative expediency which makes for poor legislation.

Only two makes of cars produced in Australia fall into this category, the Ford LTD and the Holden Statesman Caprice-vehicles that do not have a high share of the luxury car market. The effect will be a new tariff imposed on cars, although it is written into sales tax legislation. It will raise the cost of imported cars because they are a large component of the Australian luxury car market.

But this is bad legislation. It was introduced through press release. It is retrospective in nature. The concern is that the new level of tax may not raise anywhere near the amount of revenue claimed by the Government. It could have a negative impact on employment and business viability. The practical effect of it will be to impose a de facto tariff on imported vehicles in direct contravention of the Button car plan. The new tax may also impinge on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations which this Government has been so proud of in raising Australia's profile. I believe that the introduction of those Bills is unfortunate. It is bad legislation and it is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sales tax on certain categories of motor vehicles which the Government seeks to introduce through the legislation we are debating this evening is an arbitrary imposition without any justification whatsoever. It represents all that is bad about government to introduce a tax in such an arbitrary manner. It mirrors the decision by a previous government to place an upper limit on the price of a car which can be claimed through depreciation, coincidentally the very same level at which this iniquitous tax cuts in, which for this financial year will be a retail price of $42,910. That was a limit without any justification when it was introduced, just as is this proposed legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is described as `a tax on luxury cars'. I would say `so-called luxury cars', because what really defines a luxury car? Is it to be price? The price of the cars on which this tax will be imposed, with a couple of exceptions, is set by the Federal Government because they are all imported. There is only one reason why most of those cars are above the threshold for the imposition of the tax and that is the effect of tariffs and quotas which are increasing the landed cost of those vehicles.

So what, in effect, we are saying-through the imposition of this legislation to increase this tax-is a tax on a tax. Do we define a luxury car by the quality of the car, by the standard of safety or performance or equipment that the car provides? Is it the lack of equivalent quality in Australian vehicles? Is not that lack of quality in domestically produced vehicles one of the major problems of the Australian car industry? The cars which are to be attacked by this tax represent that to which the Australian product should aspire-the quality of performance, the quality of safety and the quality of equipment and finish which those cars offer.

Clearly, the use of the term `luxury' with regard to the cars which will be affected by this tax is a pejorative attempt by this Government to arouse the politics of envy, as my colleague Senator Watson said a few moments ago. It is an attempt to justify the introduction of this iniquitous charge. As I said, this arbitrary imposition of tax is totally without justification, just as was the earlier introduction of the limit on depreciation.

It is worth referring to the issue of the depreciation limit as part of this issue. Just as this new tax is totally unjustified, so is the continuation of the limit on depreciation. The new cars to which that depreciation limit now applies under the fringe benefits tax and substantiation rules, which this Government introduced, no longer can be used to escape taxation in the way that applied when the depreciation limit was introduced. So those vehicles ought now to be fully depreciable. Instead of increasing the present 30 per cent sales tax on those vehicles above the price limit which applies-the $42,910 retail price, as is provided in this legislation-the Government ought to be legislating to reduce to 20 per cent the level of sales tax charges, which is the rate charged on all other motor vehicles. At the same time, it ought to initiate legislation to withdrawn the depreciation limit on those vehicles.

To justify the imposition of this tax, the Government has to answer three questions. They are three questions which it totally failed to answer in the debate in the other place on this legislation before it came up to the Senate for consideration. Firstly, is an increase in what is already a discriminatory tax on quality cars justified? Secondly, is the tax consistent with the direction provided for the car industry in the Button plan, although one wonders, with the events of last week, what the direction of that plan really is. Thirdly, are the revenue assumptions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) correct with regard to the imposition of the tax? The short answer to every one of those questions is no, no and no.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death: Mr C. T. Oliver-Family Law-Land Development: Mount Jerrabomberra-Adjournment Debate

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to place on record the contribution to the labour movement of Cecil Thompson Oliver-better known as Charlie Oliver-who died on 24 February this year at the age of 88. Charlie's life was, in modern terms, an amazing one. If it were offered up as a film script it would probably be rejected for being too far fetched. Before he settled full time into union politics he had been a farm labourer, steel worker, fencer, well sinker, gold miner, horse breaker, and farmer.

SPEECH.PARA: He was born on 23 December 1901 at Bangor in Wales. As a boy he also lived in Chester and Ellesmere Port near Liverpool. His life centred around unionism and politics from the age of 13 when he joined the Agricultural Workers Union after leaving school with a permit to work on farms driving horses for, as he said, two and six a week and all his tucker. Even at this young age he worked from daylight to dark and, remember, this was as recently as the First World War. At the same time he attended his first British Labour Party meeting and although he was too young to join, this marked the beginning of his life long commitment to Labor's cause.

As a teenager he also worked at the steelworks at Ellesmere Port where, as was common, he lost his front teeth in the acid steam of the mill. Just after the First World War, when he was in his late teens, he and his elder brother Jack decided to come to Australia. Jack had been seriously wounded at Gallipoli and they thought that Australia's warmer climate would assist his health. They disembarked at Albany in Western Australia and Charlie started work in the goldmine at Meekatharra. He was an active member of the Miners Union there and became a delegate to the Murchison District Labor Council of Unions. His career in the Australian Workers Union (AWU) began in 1923 when the Miners Federation amalgamated with the AWU. He was secretary of the Murchison District Trades and Labor Council by 1928 and a member of the AWU Executive in 1934 and then Secretary of the mining division of the Australian Workers Union from 1944 to 1948.

It is well worth noting, as former member of the House of Representatives, John Armitage, did when he delivered Charlie's funeral oration in February, that Charlie Oliver started the fight to gain adequate compensation for the many miners he saw around him suffering the dreadful consequences of silicosis. This becomes doubly significant when we know that Charlie himself contracted silicosis and, in fact, finally died from its effects.

In 1948 Charlie Oliver was elected to the Western Australian Parliament. He easily won the seat of Boulder-in fact that was Labor's safest Western Australian State seat-and in that election he defeated Billy Mackie Snedden who was later to become the Federal Leader of the Liberal Party and also Speaker of the House of Representatives. At the subsequent general election Charlie Oliver was re-elected unopposed.

Last week I read Charlie's contributions in the Hansard of the Western Australian Parliament and I was struck by the consistent theme of empathy for the battlers in our society. Of course, he continued through the parliamentary forum to fight for the rights of workers to decent wages and working conditions. His commitment to Aboriginal people was already evident in his speeches and this commitment continued throughout his life. For example, he was a board member of Tranby Co-Operative College for Aborigines in Glebe until his death.

In mid-1951 Charlie Oliver resigned his seat in the West Australian Parliament, at the request of Tom Dougherty, the General Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, so that he could become Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the AWU. He moved to Sydney and back into the trade union movement full time. As John Armitage said at the funeral, Charlie's first love was the Australian Workers Union. I might say that there are not many politicians who would resign their seat in Parliament to serve the trade union movement, and Charlie Oliver was certainly a rare breed.

Charlie Oliver served as an officer of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party from 1956 to 1960 and as President of the Branch from 1960 to 1970. He also served on the ALP's Federal Executive for many years. Right through the 1950s and 1960s, Charlie Oliver played a pivotal role in Labor politics. When I got to know him in the early 1970s he still exerted considerable influence in the Party. In 1975-I am sure you would recall, Mr President-he was responsible for ensuring that the Party conference in New South Wales remained a large and significant forum and his resolution to maintain the conference was carried against the opposition of both the established right and left wing factions of the New South Wales Branch of the ALP.

In June 1975, when I was a young delegate to the State Congress of the New South Wales Branch of the ALP, Charlie Oliver gave me this booklet, which is the official report of the sixty-ninth annual convention of the Australian Workers Union held in Sydney from 24 January to 4 February 1955. I treasure this rare booklet. In my view it is, without doubt, the best expose I have read of the activities of the industrial groupers-also known as `the Movement'-that operated in the ALP in the early and mid-1950s. It contains a very long address from Charlie Oliver who was at that time New South Wales Branch Secretary of the AWU. Over the years I became used to long speeches from Charlie Oliver. Charlie spoke regularly at the New South Wales ALP annual conference and he was such a dominant figure that no-one in the conference from any faction, be they friend or foe, would object to the length of his speeches even though he usually was in breach of the conference orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't feel the need to emulate him tonight, do you?

—No, I do not. Charlie, like all other delegates, was entitled to a five minute speech but usually spoke for over 20 minutes before some courageous individual got up to move for an extension of time. But in the AWU conference in 1955 he delivered a stinging attack on the activities of the industrial groups. His speech at that time must have taken some three hours to deliver as he dissected the groupers and their activities bit by bit. Like a number of others, including some from the Left of the Labor Party, who became bitterly opposed to the policies of the groupers, he initially supported the Groupers because of his anti-communist feelings. However, in the mid-1950s he became appalled at their comprehensive and ruthless grab for power in the union movement and the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Charlie Oliver was hardly regarded as a lefty within the Labor Party, so I think it is important to place on record that he played a significant role in preventing the Groupers from gaining total control of the New South Wales Branch of the Labor Party and influence in the Australian Workers Union.
What also came through in Charlie Oliver's speech was his extraordinary commitment to the labour movement. He said:

It is only right and proper when you are given a position of trust in the labour movement, you should carry out its policies; don't you think it is reasonable to expect that of people put into high positions. That is our task-to straighten them up.

Charlie Oliver was a man who believed in balance in the Labor Party. He was always uncomfortable with those of the extreme left or the extreme right. He fought against any faction or tendency gaining untrammelled power. He summed up his philosophy in these words:
I go straight up the middle. If the Labor Party swings left, I go right. If it swings right, I go left.

This is why it was so difficult to put a simple ideological tag on Charlie Oliver. He was a tolerant man. He accepted that differences in views and emphasis were part and parcel of Labor politics. I maintained a personal friendship with Charlie for many years, even though we often differed in our political views.

I also wish briefly to pay tribute to Necia Holloway. After Charlie moved to New South Wales, he was always able to depend on the support of his secretary and friend, Necia Holloway. Necia's great commitment to Charlie continued right through his retirement and she nursed him with loving care until his death. Charlie Oliver was a towering figure in the Labor Party in New South Wales. His contribution to our Party will never be forgotten by those of us who were privileged to know him and who have benefited from our association with him over the years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very rarely that I use the adjournment debate. When I do, it is to air views or issues that I believe are important. Tonight is one such occasion. I wish again to draw the attention of the Senate to my call for a parliamentary inquiry into family law. Those who involve themselves in this subject generally fall into one of two groups-professional interest or personal interest. I have no training in law and I have no involvement in the Family Court of Australia. My interest over the past 12 months is simply as a result of the many hundreds of calls, letters and visits that I and my office have had from people who are so thoroughly disenchanted with the administration of family law that they have urged me to do something.

SPEECH.PARA: I could recount to the Senate horrific tales of injustice. I could regale honourable senators with long, detailed histories of the most unbelievable, cruel and petty acts perpetrated by people seeking revenge. I could show the Senate legal bills from otherwise thoroughly respectable solicitors who have managed to take in fees people's entire property settlements and still not achieve a result for the people they are meant to be helping. These stories appear daily in newspapers across the country. They cause great headlines for a day but few people bother to look behind the story and remember that it is not some soap opera being played out but a real life drama. Frankly, it seems that society has become either desensitised to these things or bored with the frequency of the stories.

One such story appeared in the Sun of last Saturday, 19 May. I will not go into the details but, in essence, a man cut short his legal battle to win custody of his son because he could simply no longer afford to keep fighting. That does not alter his belief that the child's mother is unfit to have custody; it simply came down to what he could afford. He was told that it would cost another $75,000 if he prolonged his action. That is simply out of the reach of the average Australian. The wife was told it would cost her the same amount. That story is not particularly unusual. Some of the aspects of the case made it sensational, but it or a version of it occurs daily in our Family Court. I have evidence of another person who has already spent $160,000 and has been told that it will cost at least another $100,000 before his case is concluded.

People are now finding that it is too expensive to fight for justice. This is not just a criticism made by dissatisfied litigants. Justice Elizabeth Evatt has also publicly questioned the zeal with which some solicitors fix their fees for family law matters. We are told that in family law there is a notion that the interests of the child are paramount. Clearly, the child's best interests are not always paramount. In the case I have just quoted, the child's interests were buried amongst the side issues and the cost of the matter. The criticisms of the Family Court are not just of its costs. We are told that, on the issue of custody, the Family Law Act does not favour either parent. Yet I have on file literally hundreds of letters from fathers which, if only half of them were true-and I am not suggesting for a minute that any of them are false-would give rise to grave misgivings about our system of justice. Lest it be thought that I am promoting the cause of fathers at the expense of mothers, I add that I have also had similar, but not as many, letters from women who have had difficulties with custody. For women with custody the complaints concern maintenance. The difficulties in obtaining maintenance from fathers who do not wish to pay are equally frequent. Again, the present system has failed them.

We are told that under current family law legislation access is provided for and can be set down as a ruling of the court. Yet, once again, I have hundreds of letters that detail breaches of access orders on which no action can be or has been taken. Last year I called for a thorough review of the administration of family law in Australia. I know that I have the support of many honourable senators in this chamber for such an inquiry. The Opposition parties felt sufficiently strongly about it to have it specifically written into our law and justice policy. I have no hesitation in saying that had we won the election the inquiry would now be a reality.

There are thousands of people outside this place waiting for such an inquiry to be called so that they may air their grievances and put to us their views on revision of the Act. Their ideas ought to be heard. While ever they are not, we are allowing a volcano to build up in the community. I call on all parties in this chamber to do more than mouth platitudes. We have been elected to this place to represent our constituents. Establishing an inquiry into family law administration would be responding to our constituents in a positive manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate and the people the regrettable situation that exists in New South Wales, where the State's environmental planning procedures and the responsibilities of State environmental agencies are being undermined by the actions of the Greiner-Murray Government. These concerns are illustrated by the involvement of the New South Wales Premier and his Ministers at various stages in the consideration of a proposed residential development on the slopes of Mount Jerrabomberra, near Queanbeyan, promoted by one Mr Alex Brinkmeyer. Mr Brinkmeyer was until recently the President of the Queanbeyan Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia. At least four other office bearers of the branch have held substantial shareholdings in a company which owns land on Mount Jerrabomberra, promoted by Mr Brinkmeyer as the Jerrabomberra Heights Estate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mount Jerrabomberra covers an area of about 300 hectares. During European settlement, disturbance to the vegetation on the mountain has been minimal. This is reflected in the number of original species present and a limited invasion by weeds. Detailed studies have revealed Mount Jerrabomberra to be an environmentally significant area, supporting communities of natural grasslands. The mountain also supports Rutidosis leptorrhynoides, a rare and endangered plant, and the largest population in existence of Diuris semilunulata, a rare orchid. Other significant plant species are Grevillea ramossisima and Dillwynia cinerascens, the rare parrot pea plant.

The mountain also supports rare woodland associations and has an intact understorey. These diverse plant communities support a wide variety of wildlife, including 94 species of birds, 16 species of reptiles and 15 species of mammals. The natural and other heritage values of Mount Jerrabomberra are of such significance that Mr Michael Calkovics, the Secretary of the Mount Jerrabomberra Preservation Society and a resident of the Australian Capital Territory, has nominated the site for listing on the Register of the National Estate. I understand that the Australian Heritage Commission will soon be considering the nomination for an interim listing. In addition, I have been informed by Mr Calkovics of the concern of his Society at the likely effects of the proposed development at Mount Jerrabomberra on the adjacent Jerrabomberra wetlands, which provide habitat for the latham snipe, one of a number of migratory bird species which the Commonwealth has an obligation to protect under the provisions of the Japan-Australia migratory birds agreement.

As long ago as December 1963, a request was made by the Queanbeyan municipality to J. W. Sieffert, MLA, to establish Mount Jerrabomberra as a national park. In May 1964 the district surveyor from the Lands Department, Goulburn, sent a report to the Director of Parks Services in the Lands Department recommending resumption of the area for `passive recreation' purposes. This recommendation was supported by the Minister for Lands, the Yarrowlumla Shire and the Queanbeyan municipality. The value of the 632 acres of Mount Jerrabomberra in 1964 was put at #10,500. This was to be paid in equal parts by the Lands Department, the Yarrowlumla shire and the Queanbeyan municipality. The proposal, unfortunately, did not go ahead due to insufficient funds within the Yarrowlumla shire. The land was not purchased in subsequent years due to insufficient data on the biological status of the area.

In December 1986 Jerrabomberra Estates Ltd, whose principal was Mr Alex Brinkmeyer, made a submission to the Queanbeyan City Council for the development of a housing estate on the slopes of Mount Jerrabomberra. This development, if allowed to proceed, would affect about 200 hectares of open woodland on the mountain. Within this area there are several important plant communities. These are, firstly, button wrinklewort-Rutidosis leptorrhynchoides-which is listed as an endangered plant species. A report by Anutech Pty Ltd, consultants to the developer in 1988, confirmed that about 300 to 400 individual plants of this species occur on Jerrabomberra Heights Estate. All are on the lower slopes and within the proposed development area and would be largely eliminated by development. Secondly, the orchid Diuris semilunulata which, according to Anutech, is likely to be listed in the near future as a rare species. Mount Jerrabomberra is the type locality from which the species was originally described. Thirdly, the parrot pea Dillwynia cinerascens, which I am informed by Mr Calkovics has only recently been discovered in New South Wales, the only know locality being on Mount Jerrabomberra. Fourthly, the golden wattle Acacia pycnantha which is Australia's official floral emblem. I am informed that Dr John Briggs of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Plant Industry has expressed the opinion that whilst uncertainties remain regarding the taxonomic status of the Mount Jerrabomberra Acacia pycnantha, there is certainly merit in preserving the population. Fifthly, the Grevillea ramossisima which, according to Anutech, occurs only at Mount Jerrabomberra in the immediate region. It does not occur, according to Anutech's knowledge, in a proposed reserve which is to protect 100 hectares on the summit of Mount Jerrabomberra.

Anutech further reported that if the development was to proceed there appeared no possible way of mitigating the loss of vegetation on the eastern and southern fringes of the development, which are already surrounded by areas of land put to agricultural and urban use. These consultants said that as far as fauna is concerned the values of minimising the clearing of native vegetation were of paramount importance.

To offset the effects of the proposed development, an area of 100 hectares on the summit of the mountain was proposed to be set aside by the developer as an environmental protection area. This proposal was outlined in the draft local environment plan (LEP) under which the rezoning of the land to permit residential development was to be effected. That draft plan is known as draft local environment plan No. 54 for the City of Queanbeyan.

However, I am informed by Mr Calkovics that a submission was also made by Mr Alex Brinkmeyer's company for a major tourist complex on the same land and was rejected by the Department of Environment and Planning in 1987. I am informed that the Department rejected a proposed cable car with tourist facilities on Mount Jerrabomberra after coming to the view that a certificate was unlikely to be issued for a plan permitting such a use.

Nevertheless, there are large water storage tanks and associated clearing of vegetation for pipe laying has been carried out on the proposed summit reserve with undetermined environmental effects. This work was carried out by the Queanbeyan City Council.

On 17 May 1985 the Queanbeyan Age reported Mr Alex Brinkmeyer as saying he wanted to `apply for initial rezoning of the land below the 640 metre line'. However, I am informed that in a submission to the Queanbeyan City Council relating the draft LEP for the rezoning, a rezoning of land up to the 670 metre line of elevation was contemplated. Concern that the environmental significance of the area would be seriously compromised led to the formation of the Jerrabomberra Preservation Society by Mr Calkovics and other concerned citizens of Queanbeyan and surrounding areas.

I am informed that when Mr Alex Brinkmeyer's company originally purchased the land on Mount Jerrabomberra it was comprised in an estate which was subdivided in 1928. This was only a paper subdivision. The land was zoned under Yarrowlumla interim development order No. 1 as rural 1 (a) which gave no development rights on individual lots. When the Mount Jerrabomberra area became part of Queanbeyan, a local environment plan was implemented. This was local environmental plan No. 27. This plan identified and protected land on the mountain which was considered to be environmentally sensitive. It provided for preservation of hillscapes and ridgelines and the protection of Jerrabomberra Creek. The subsequent draft local environment plan of May 1988, draft LEP No. 54, changed the zoning of land which was previously zoned for environmental protection and upon which residential subdivisions were prohibited to land zoned to permit residential subdivision.

Mr Brinkmeyer's company sold land to the public before the land was rezoned to permit residential development. The contracts of sale with purchasers stated that in the event that rezoning approval was not obtained owners would be able to rescind the agreement, but at a cost. I am informed that in the event that there were more lots sold than were permitted under the zoning of land the company would effectively be charging purchasers for their speculation at the rate of $500 or more per block. Large numbers of blocks are involved which could mean a substantial windfall to the company from a paper subdivision at the expense of unwary purchasers.

While this situation may be a case of caveat emptor-buyer beware-such an approach is questionable, I believe. The Council could face enormous problems in having fragmented ownership over a large area with no urban potential while the owners press for approval to develop in accordance with a premature subdivision of 1928. I suggest this may be a case warranting the attention of the New South Wales Department of Consumer Affairs.

The environmental study submitted to the Queanbeyan City Council supporting the rezoning of Mount Jerrabomberra was prepared by a consultant, Don Fox Planning Pty Ltd. The principal of this company, Mr Don Fox, was as at 18 February 1988, the owner of a substantial shareholding in Jerrabomberra Estates Ltd, owner of the land which was the subject of the environmental study. The environmental study prepared by Don Fox Planning Pty Ltd has been criticised by the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service for inaccurately describing the vegetation on the subject land and for failing to mention fauna.
The environmental study prepared by Don Fox Planning Pty Ltd in its assessment of the land's vegetation said:

Whilst the land has not been formally developed, it is traversed by an intricate network of informal roads and tracks, with the inevitable rubbish dumps and introduction of `exotic' species, resulting in extensive modification of the indigenous vegetation. As a general rule vegetation on the steeper slopes (generally above Jerrabomberra Hill Road beyond the water reservoirs) retains marginally better integrity than the lower, more accessible land.

The Don Fox study also said that `the high degree of disturbance demonstrates that the significance of the vegetation cover is aesthetic only'. I am informed that no public notice was given for the exhibition of the environmental study and although it was exhibited it was not properly identified as an environmental study.

In October 1987 the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service notified criticisms of the environmental study to the Queanbeyan City Council. The criticisms were made on the grounds of inadequacies in the flora and fauna study. The National Parks and Wildlife Service in its objections noted the lack of any description of the fauna in the study area despite the fact that Mount Jerrabomberra appeared to the Service to be a refuge for many species of wildlife, including native mammals, reptiles, amphibians and many bird species. The Service also criticised the study on the basis that only broad vegetation alliances had been listed and no mention had been made of either the understorey or ground cover communities or of particular species of significance.

The Service expressed the view to the Council that vegetation communities on Mount Jerrabomberra were of interest botanically, with at least two plant species of special scientific significance being present. The National Parks and Wildlife Service went on to describe the endangered daisy and parrot pea. The Service advised the Council that there were many other plants in the area which are of botanic interest and that it was quite possible that other rare species may be found in the study area and also that certain communities themselves may be of a high conservation status.

The Service informed the Council of its continuing objection to the exhibited draft local environmental plan until it was given the opportunity to review any detailed flora and fauna studies and the specific measures proposed to protect significant biological values identified in those studies.

In December 1987 Anutech completed and submitted a further environmental study of Mount Jerrabomberra to the Queanbeyan City Council. This was, I believe, as a consequence of complaints about the inadequacies of the previous environmental study prepared by Don Fox Planning Pty Ltd. Anutech was commissioned to do the study by the Queanbeyan City Council.

In January 1988 the National Parks and Wildlife Service sent a letter to the Queanbeyan City Council commenting on the Anutech fauna and flora study. The Service described the study as helpful but, in view of the impact on residual vegetation communities, it disagreed with the Anutech recommendation that the development should proceed. The Service retained its objections to the proposed development and sought further consideration of the protection of the plant and residual animal communities on the site. I believe that the National Parks and Wildlife Service was not alone in maintaining its objections, similar reservations having been expressed by the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning.

In February 1988 the Jerrabomberra Preservation Society nominated Mount Jerrabomberra to the New South Wales Heritage Council for protection under the New South Wales Heritage Act. On 24 February 1988 the Society requested that the draft local environmental plan not proceed due to what it believed to be misleading information in the plan and the inadequacies in the environmental study.

In March 1988 there was a State election in New South Wales. The Greiner-Murray Government was elected. Jerrabomberra Estate's fortunes improved noticeably thereafter. I am informed that a meeting was held on 30 March 1988 to resolve differences between the developer, Alex Brinkmeyer, and the Queanbeyan City Council concerning the extent to which the draft local environmental plan would protect the rare and endangered flora. At that meeting Mr Brinkmeyer stated:
Nick Greiner has given me the undertaking that this development will go ahead.

Later Mr Brinkmeyer authorised the bulldozing of part of his company's proposed development site at Mount Jerrabomberra. The work was carried out on 6 April 1988, and I believe that areas in which rare flora occurred were affected. Although the New South Wales Heritage Council recommended in April 1988 the making of a temporary heritage order under section 136 of the Heritage Act, and one was made, it remained in effect for only 10 days.

Near the time that the bulldozing of part of the subject land took place the new New South Wales Minister for Planning in the Greiner-Murray Government, Mr David Hay, intervened in favour of Mr Brinkmeyer's proposed development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I am sure that this is an interesting diatribe that is being delivered with the staccato chatter of a machine-gun, but as Senator Dunn is only reading her speech I wonder whether she could just table it or just make the speech without reading whatever it is.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. I wish to continue with my copious notes and my remarks. I appreciate that the hour is late but it is an important subject and I shall not delay the Senate any longer than I have to.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 April 1988, the Minister for Planning, Mr Hay, met with Brinkmeyer and Peter Cochran, the National Party member of parliament for Queanbeyan, in the absence of any departmental officers. The National Parks and Wildlife Service was at that time interested in preserving the plant communities on Mount Jerrabomberra and were considering purchase of the land. In the event of the failure to acquire the land, the Service considered seeking an interim protection order under section 91b of its Act. The interim protection order would have prohibited any disturbance to the site in question. Had such an order been made, it would have been the first implementation of this new provision in the Act.

Throughout the Jerrabomberra controversy the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service gave every appearance of support for preservation of the mountain's environmental values and pressed its concerns about the proposed residential development with the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to standing order 187, which says quite precisely that a senator shall not read a speech. For 15 to 16 minutes we have all been sitting here closely observing the fact that Senator Dunn has not been referring to copious notes but reading her speech and, as Senator Sheil has already said, at a staccato pace which could not possibly be delivered by a senator giving an extempore speech. She is clearly in breach of standing order 187 and I ask you to rule accordingly.

—I remind Senator Dunn that the Standing Orders do state that a senator should not read a speech. I notice that she has said that she is using copious notes. It is very difficult from where I am sitting, of course, to determine that, but she should not read her speech.

—I am surprised that members on the Opposition benches do not make the same remarks and have the same objections about senators on their own side who also read from copious notes, and whose remarks are in fact improved by their doing so. However, I shall continue to make remarks from my copious notes, and I thank you, Mr President, for your indulgence.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a meeting on 20 April 1988 involving Peter Cochran, the State member for Monaro, Alex Brinkmeyer, an employee of Don Fox Planning, an officer of the Department of Planning, and Mr Tim Moore, New South Wales Minister for Environment, who attended unaccompanied by any National Parks and Wildlife Service officer. Mr Moore gave every indication that the National Parks and Wildlife Service would not press for the establishment of a reserve. The Minister accepted the addition of a clause in the draft plan which provided some rights for the Service to be consulted about the development as it proceeded. On 6 May 1988 the New South Wales Planning Minister, Mr Hay, made the Queanbeyan local environmental plan No. 54.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, I draw your attention to the fact that I have been watching Senator Dunn ever since you ruled on my last point of order. She is continuing to read her speech, despite her protestations to the contrary, and I ask you to rule her out of order and sit her down for good.

—This is a very difficult matter that I have had to rule on in the past. I have always come down on the side of the honourable senator making the speech, but I must say that Senator Dunn is giving the impression of reading her speech.

—Mr President, the more interruptions there are, clearly the longer the Senate will be detained. I have not got much longer to go, and it is my right as an independent senator in this place to use the adjournment to make my remarks and represent the people who have made protests to me. So the sooner that Senator Newman stops her objections, the sooner I will be able to complete my remarks.
—Order! Continue.

—On 9 May 1988, the New South Wales Premier, Mr Nick Greiner, left the opening of Federal Parliament which he was attending, to open Mr Brinkmeyer's Jerrabomberra housing estate. On 19 August 1988, Mr Richard Jones, a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council, filed an application in the New South Wales Land and Environment Court seeking a declaration of invalidity of Queanbeyan local environment plan No. 54. Later in the year, on 23 September, Mr Michael Calkovics applied to be and was substituted as the applicant in place of Mr Jones by order of the court. Mr Calkovics then applied to the court on his own behalf and on behalf of the Jerrabomberra Preservation Society.

SPEECH.PARA: The allegations of the applicant in his points of claim were many and substantial. Among these were, firstly, that the environmental study was not objective and was so inadequate as not to amount to an environmental study; secondly, that the Minister in making the local environment plan failed to take into account numerous relevant considerations, many of them raised by New South Wales Government agencies; thirdly, that the Minister took into account irrelevant considerations, including the relationship between Alex Brinkmeyer, the Liberal Party and the New South Wales Premier; fourthly, that the Minister acted in breach of the rules of natural justice by secretly meeting with Alex Brinkmeyer on 20 April 1988 to consider objections to the draft plan without affording the Council or the objectors the opportunity to make submissions; and, fifthly, that the map with the local environment plan did not properly describe the land to which it applied.

The last, and the least substantial, of the points that I have just listed has the appearance of being seized upon by the respondent Minister as a means of avoiding a searching investigation of the other allegations in a court. The Minister admitted the invalidity of the local environment plan due to the lack of an adequate map, and the court made a declaration to that effect on 19 September 1989. The court victory was not won without considerable effort and sacrifice by those concerned over those two years. Scurrilous and unjustified remarks have been made about Mr Calkovics for his efforts on behalf of the Jerrabomberra Preservation Society.

While he has been subject to verbal attacks, they are not the worst attacks that have been made on Mr Calkovics. In the latter part of 1988 Mr Calkovics was admitted to Queanbeyan Hospital after an incident which occurred when he was out driving in Queanbeyan with his uncle, who was visiting from overseas. In a statement to the police Mr Calkovics said that he and his uncle were stopped by another vehicle which drew up in front of them. A person then approached the driver's side of his car and punched through the closed window, smashing the glass and striking Mr Calkovics on the face a number of times. Apparently, no statement was taken by the police from Mr Calkovic's uncle, who witnessed the incident and was available at the time but who has since returned to his homeland. Charges brought against Mr Calkovics based on a statement from the other party to the incident were later dropped.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a point of order. I would normally be the last person to get to my feet on this particular point of order because there are so many senators who do, of necessity, from time to time, read speeches. But I must say that I do take a little offence at the honourable senator's claim that she is reading from copious notes when she is not only reading from a prepared speech but also doing so in a very staccato fashion that is almost impossible to understand. I think that perhaps a sensible distinction could be made in respect of read speeches in the adjournment debate. It is understandable that honourable senators read from copious notes on legislation, particularly on technical Bills, but I must say that it does try the patience of everybody when this sort of speech-which, in fact, if it is written out can be sensibly incorporated in Hansard to precisely the same effect-is read out at this late hour and for such a long time on the adjournment. I am moved to raise this point of order as Senator Dunn did tell us seven minutes ago that she was about to conclude.

—In reply to you, Senator Collins, I have never, in the period that I have been in the chair, applied the relevant standing order because, as you say, so many people from both sides of the chamber take advantage of it. But I must say that I think this is the worst example that I have been asked to rule on. I do not know how much further you have to go, Senator Dunn.
—Mr President, I am quoting from a great many documents as part of my copious notes, you understand.
—The situation I am placed in is that I have to believe that Senator Dunn is telling me she is using copious notes, and that is the way I rule.
—Thank you, Mr President.
—I would ask Senator Dunn-not that I am doubting her veracity-to table the document she is quoting from.
—It is in order, when Senator Dunn finishes her speech, for you or another senator to move that, Senator Collins.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am sorry that this may be boring to honourable senators present, but I am sure that it will be very interesting to a great number of people outside the Senate, particularly those in Queanbeyan whose properties are affected.

SPEECH.PARA: On 23 February 1990, that is, just recently, a circular was sent by Jerrabomberra Estate to people who had purchased lots from the company's proposed Jerrabomberra Heights Estate explaining what was termed in the circular a `short delay' in the issuing of titles. This was due, it was said, to the uncovering of a `trivial technical flaw in the legal documents'. The circular went on to state that the Queanbeyan Council had `immediately assembled a task force of its most senior officers and aldermen to oversee the preparation of a new local environmental study and plan to correct the flaw', and estimated the rezoning `may be completed by the middle of this year'.

In view of the impending consideration of the Jerrabomberra nomination by the Australian Heritage Commission and the possibility that the site may be listed on the interim listing of the National Estate register, one hopes that the proposed development will be reviewed in a substantial manner by the authorities concerned and by the proponent. One could even hope that, in the event of listing, the Commonwealth Government might do more than sit on its hands as it has done so often in relation to National Estate matters and, particularly, National Estate in the south-east of New South Wales. However, I am not particularly optimistic about this matter.

Finally, Mr Alex Brinkmeyer, the principal of Jerrabomberra Estate, resides in Queanbeyan and controls substantial holdings in the ACT and the Queanbeyan area. Senator Collins may be interested to know that he controls as much as 90 per cent of the available residential land in the Queanbeyan area and more than 30 per cent of the available residential land in the ACT. He apparently also controls very substantial holdings in Florida in the United States of America. I note that he must be an Australian citizen because his name is on the electoral roll at a Queanbeyan address. His willingness to be involved in community affairs is evidenced by his membership of the Liberal Party branch at Queanbeyan. A gentleman of such substance and with such influence in civic affairs would of course be sensitive to community opinion, and could not fail to appreciate the importance of the environmental and heritage values of Mount Jerrabomberra. I look forward to seeing some evidence of this in the near future.
Motion (by Senator Newman) agreed to:
That the document quoted from by Senator Dunn be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your indulgence for one moment to say that there ought to be some reconsideration of the processes of the adjournment debate-not because the time allocated is used improperly or ought not to be available, but because Senator Dunn has opportunities, as does her soulmate Senator Vallentine, to present their arguments, however discursive, however inadequate, however incompetent and however failing in logic, during the normal course of the day's proceedings. I am reminded, as I stand now, that on the one occasion that Senator Vallentine had an opportunity to be here to speak and vote-on the South Pacific nuclear free zone legislation-not only was she not here to speak, but she was also not here to vote because she was over in New Zealand--
—This was 1985; get it right.

—She remembers clearly when it was. She was in New Zealand haranguing the poor souls of that nation. Senator Dunn and Senator Vallentine are now abusing Standing Orders or, at least, certainly using the Standing Orders to allow themselves to circulate their speeches and, in the process, abusing-and, certainly, in many respects, in my view, misusing-the essential elements of decency, the goodwill of the President and the cooperation of the Senate for the purpose of putting down a political statement. They do so not because they much care what the Opposition or the Government thinks, or what is thought by those who might be damned by the rare occasion they would read their speeches, but rather for the purpose of circulating their propaganda.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, there is an argument that a speech on the adjournment is a speech which dwells on a particular matter expressing the manifest views of a senator on that occasion, and that there ought to be, more particularly, a reinforcing of Standing Orders in respect of the reading of speeches. Under normal circumstances, in particular matters, copious notes might be acceptable during a debate.

It is not unreasonable to expect, when honourable senators rise on the adjournment because they have a matter of passion, care, concern or something, that they be able, at least, to articulate it without reading every single word of their research officer's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Crichton-Browne. That is the distinction-every single word.

—I have to say that as long as we have a couple of free-loading mavericks that are flitting across the political horizon, for the short but difficult period that they are here, they ought at least to be on record as having pumped out this typewritten propaganda for no purpose other than to circulate it, and for no reason other than to abuse the ruling of the President. For my part, I am certainly tempted, at least, to reconsider my position in terms of how we ought to deal with the adjournment in the future. I can only say that God blesses us with having removed 50 per cent of the problem; hopefully, in a short time we will get rid of the rest.

—I think this matter should go to the Standing Committee on Procedure. The Committee may consider any matter relating to the procedures of the Senate referred to it by the Senate or by the President. Given the length of the adjournment debate, the length of speeches on the adjournment debate and the types of problems that I had to encounter tonight, when I was placed in an impossible position of trying to rule on the reading of that speech, I fully intend to refer those matters to the Procedure Committee.
